They're definitely not trying to fill you up on carbs, leaving you plenty of room to really enjoy the fish. Wako has also brought upon my appreciation for uni. I've never really had good uni before this meal, and the uni nigiri with the shiso leaf tucked in between the rice was perfect. The brine y flavor wasn't overwhelming, but I still got a great flavor of the ocean. Another highlight was the crab nigiri, which was so tender. It was a simple bite, but the perfect way to highlight the crab. The meal is finished off with a housemade strawberry mousse, maintaining that light quality that connected the entire omakase. The fresh strawberry chunks made it refreshing, and the mousse itself wasn't at all heavy or creamy. They also serve a complimentary piece of chocolate that they also make themselves, finishing off with a bit of decadence that you didn't realize you wanted after an amazing meal. Wako Sushi is without a doubt one of my favorite Japanese spots in San Francisco, and I highly recommend it to anyone, sushi lover or not! Enjoy some expertly cut fish and delectable small plates. Koji marinated grilled King Salmon was suburb as were all the mounds of perfectly temped rice with slivers of flesh atop. No other cuisine pays such great attention to details, so just let Atsushi and Tomo take care of you. They will. Hello Wako! To me you are Maruya in the mission minus the big bill! I went here couple days ago and I had a late lunch around pm and went in around  so my friend and I decided to opt for the smaller course Omakaze. Before our official course meal started, we ordered a SEASONAL mushroom soup  this mushroom grows in Japan (also seattle and canada apparently) only under pine trees and because they grow and are at optimal in taste during this time, Wako only offers this soup in Oct/Nov months. Their smaller Omakaze menu doesn't change, but they will change up their menu close to quarterly basis for their bigger Omakaze. Courses:#: Tofu and salad Tofu was super soft (possibly home made) but a bit bland and wasn't too special for me. #: Miso glazed sea bass Pretty good but it's not unique to Wako and there isn't anything phenomenally outstanding#:  Nigiri Beautifully made and very tasty! I have to say. . the rice is better at Maruya but the cut of the fish and how it is prepared is exceptional! I LOVED IT. My favorite was (and if you don't do omakaze try this at least) red snapper with cherry blossom leaf, salt and lemon. It melted in my mouth and I think I had a tear in my eye. ;) #: Finished with red miso soup which was great and unique. #: mini home made chocolateI highly recommend it and it will not break your bank. Outstanding overall in taste, presentation, service and thoughtfulness behind the meal. My hubby and I went here on a whim last night, after being so busy at work and not remembering to find a decent reso for our anniversary. This has been book marked for quite sometime but due to the mixed reviews and higher price point, havent had a chance to take a leap of faith to go just yet. . . . until last night!We both opted for the four course omakase, consisting of other reviewer's similarly served items:) house made tofu with wasabi, dashi stock & seasonal vegetables with bamboo and chestnut refreshing, a good starter, but best housemade tofu by far is still raku in las vegas. ) grilled black cod fish cooked to perfection, one of the better cod's ive ever had, no bones like previous reviews, excellent and buttery!) nigiri korea halibut, chinook salmon with yuzu gelee, bluefin tuna marinated in jalopeno so, pike mackeral, kani with crab butter, seared hokkaido scallop ) red miso soup with himeki mushrooms. Good shari (rice) to fish ratio, edomae style sushi where they paint on the sauce so you dont need soysauce. Everything was very fresh, and delicious favorites were the bluefin tuna marinated in jalopeno soy, so flavorful, and the tuna a very good quality grade tuna. Scallop was also high on the radar, considering normally I dont like scallop, this says a lot. The searing added a good texture to the normally mushy scallop. . . delish!add ons to make our belly full!A wagyu nigiri, x  $ a pop, but totally worth it. Beef comes cooked (seared I think so eat it while its warm) buttery & so tender$ hokkaido uni chawanmushi,  almost as good as aki san at sushi sho in el cerrito! except this one was highighted due to the hokkaido uni included inside! so precious and yummy$ ankimo  the best ankimo weve ever had. Most ankimos have the gritty taste in the middle, but this one was SUPER smooth, velvety like foie. OMG!fried mackeral fish bone  on the house, one of our favs$ tamago so good, get it last for dessert, not a traditional tamago but has hints and notes of vanilla or coffee, almost like cake!$ matcha daifuku house made mochi with redbean and matcha inside. heavenlyblueberry panna cotta $  good, not mind blowing, mild tasting like most japo sweetsgrilled hokke $ this grilled fish was such a pleasant surprise. Its a grilled fish filet with bones, grilled over charcoal. You can tell the care the cook used to grill this fish to perfection, its normally a "dry cured" fish and they grill it so it comes hot, but it was the most moist and delicately seasoned fish. Comes with a side of yam. so delicious and healthy. Hubby is generally a hater of small foods, and was pleasantly surprised at the japo chefs behind the counter. ( I thought they were chinese owned) He said overall the quality and presentation was great, and tomosan the main chef you can tell he cares a lot about his restaurant, the customer experience and thought is put behind each and every bite and it shows. $ out the door with  small asahi beer. experience, priceless! not necessarily a normal day type of meal since it is pricey but for those days you want to splurge. . . . for those haters who gave it  or  starts and complained, sorry yall but you dont know what good traditional japanese food is supposed to be about. go eat your jive ass rolls elsewhere in the marina =) Dainty, tiny little overpriced portions.  Extremely limited selection of fish. The fish itself is not bad, but there is much better around for more reasonable prices.  Other reviewers seem to love this place, maybe I am missing something??Nah. More to comeENJOYWarning:  RESERVE . . . I regret posting this . . . now it will be even harder to get in . . . sigh . . . Cute little Japanese restaurant. Friendly service. Make reservations. I just ordered some small plates and ngiri off the menu. The house made tofu was ok. I had one at Raku in Vegas before, which I liked, but this wasn't the same/as good. The raw squid was NO BUENO though. It was like in this bitter sauce. The pieces of ngiri are a bit more expensive than what I'm used to in Seattle. $ $ sure, but I got some tuna belly, uni for $ each! That's pretty hefty! The quality was pretty good, but not my favorite spot or anything. I ended up spending ~$ w/ tax/tip. Been there more than  times already . tomo さん is one of the best sushi chef in the Bay Area . never get disappointed . not even once . always enjoy the service and food there. always make a reservation before you go Thank you Wako for a wonderful, top notch dining experience!  My first visit will definitely not be my last.  Looking forward to retuning sooner than later.  I've really fallen in love this place!  I usually stay away from Clement St. bc parking is such a hassle.  For Wako, I will make the trek across town and deal with it.  It's worth it!   The other half and I arrived at pm on Saturday evening, having made a reservation.  The waitress immediately lead us to the sushi bar where we met Atsushi san and Tomo san.  The sushi bar seats , making it a very intimate experience.  Throughout the service, the patrons at the sushi bar talked and toasted with Atsushi san and Tomo san.  They were so personable and made us laugh with their lighthearted conversations.  They introduced themselves to everyone and asked us our names.  It was a joy to watch them as masters of their craft of preparing authentic sushi by showcasing knife skills and displaying culinary creativity.  We even got to practice speaking a little bit of Japanese with Atsushi san.      Wako is a small space with a pleasant, modern sheik ambiance to admire.  The wood sided and tiled walls are simple and classy.  You can appreciate the thought that was put into designing the interior.  Besides the sushi bar seating, there are small tables available as well.  The service is impeccable.  Besides having Tomo san and Atsushi san taking care of all the sushi bar patrons, all of the waitresses are incredibly attentive, professional and friendly as well.  Whenever a cooked course came out of the kitchen, the waitress would go into detail on what she was serving us and teach us how to eat them.  I really appreciated the extra effort.  Our plates were removed promptly.  Our glasses were constantly being refilled even if they were still half filled.     The other half and I wanted to try an array of what Wako had to offer, so we both ordered the  course omakase ($ pp).  It included  small plates,  pcs sashimi,   bincho grill,  tempura,  pcs nigiri, miso soup and dessert.  I won't go into detail about everything that we ate, but I will confirm that everything was exceptional!  In terms of quality, presentation and taste   stars for sure!  I've never had such exceptional tempura.  All the cooked dishes were simply amazing.  Grade A fish selection was melt in your mouth goodness.  They also have real miso soup offered in white and red.  We tried one of each and they were equally delicious.  The omakase was filling and we certainly great value for the price.  Our total tab of  omakases and an order of hot sake ($) came out to $. We already plan to return to try the beef tasting course.  Next time, we'll opt to order sashimi and nigiri on the fly.  The market selection changes daily, so this will surely keep us coming back.  Also, will be happy to see Tomo san and Atsushi san!  Wako is a wonderful addition to the neighborhood!  I wish you continued success and hope Wako is here to stay for a long time. this is my new favorite sushi restaurant in the city. amazing service, ambience, food, presentation. my new spot. [heart] Although the name sounds a tad awkward in English, Wako is definitely a place to go and go again. I know Tomo (the Chef) from his years with Sanraku. Here he truly delivers a top notch experience. I truly felt in a restaurant in Japan. Style, simple elegance, essential design in the food. He even remembered my name when greeted me. I took the most expensive Omakase menu because I trust him.  I got blown away. Take a look at the pictures and you will fully understand. The best sushi I've ever eaten, and I eat a lot  of sushi! A lovely place to eat and very friendly staff. So pleased we happened across it. Will definitely revisit. My experience with Wako is good.  Came here with  others and service is there.  We paid $/pp with drinks.  Wako is good but not great comparing to few other places in san francisco.   I believe the reason is the quality of the fish.  They charge quite low for omakase and it was very fulfilling.    The size of their courses are huge comparing to others.   If we didnt spend that much on drinks, the bill will be around $/pp even with a la carte added.   For the price,  this is one of the hest omakase theme sushi restaurant in sf.  My favorite is the homemade tofu. . . reminds me of the tofu I've had in kyoto.  Will recommend for friends and will come back as well! I would love to give this restaurant more stars! It just recently opened, but I have been here twice already. Both of the times, they went above and beyond my expectations. My family and I got the  course meal for the two times we were here. I believe it was $ for a  course meal, but let me tell you, IT WAS WELL WORTH IT! Dish # was a three part appetizer: sesame tofu, mushroom medley, and okra and shishito pepper tempura. # maguro and seared hamachi sashimi # kyoto style grilled belt fish # hirame tempura # seven different nigiri sushi # miso soup # dessert. We also got chawanmushi in addition. It was the best chawanmushi I've ever had in the bay area. It was $ and it had all sorts of things in it which included a fat piece of uni, white fish tasted like tai fish (not sure), snow crab, and it was just a whole lot of YUM. Not only does the food taste good, I love their presentation. It makes the meal enjoyable through the palate as well as the eyes. I know this place will never disappoint. If you are thinking about trying it out, you should do it soon because it just opened and it's already super busy. Weekends are pretty much reservations only because of their limited seating. Tuesday  Called at :pm to make a reservation for Sunday at :pm. Very accommodating over the phone. Please do make sure that you call during their reservation acceptance hrs. On Saturday, I had to call in to make a last minute change to add  more people to the party. Again, they made it happen and we sat at the sushi bar. Our pleasure and first time was given to Tomo san who serves around the corner are of the sushi bar. Tomo san started joking with us when he found out that one person was late. He said, "Is the person here? Looking for parking?" I said, "yes". He said, "oh no. . . Good luck!" hahaha! The friend ended up spending  mins looking for parking. They didn't rush us to order since our timeframe was blocked off specifically for us to enjoy the dinner. Our party for  did the  course omakase for $/head. Seven Course  small plates (), sashimi (pcs. ) bincho grill (), tempura (), nigiri (pcs. ), miso soup, dessert. The four piece sashimi included King Salmon and Hamachi. Honestly, nothing special for this plate. . King salmon wasn't buttery or creamy enough. Just wasn't a big wow factor for this. I'm going to skip the grill stuff and the tempura stuff. Right down to the nigiri, because this is what I like about the place. Best fish of the day is what's this is all about. No soy sauce beyond this point. Everything was lightly prepped without heavy taste. This is where you find out if the fish is fresh or not. My favorite of the nigiri was the Snow Crab. Very close to what I had in Hokkaido Japan. Then there was scallop which was lightly seared. Very juicy and almost melted in my mouth (like tofu, but it has a nice caramel scallop taste). Then it was the toro. . . and finishing the authentic Hokkaido Uni. You can actually see that the box had hokkaido sticker on it. Very sweet! We also had a drink with Tomo san. . Be sure to order up the Banana Beer that they have. Nothing better than drinking up with the sushi chef and talking about food. Tomo said he loved izakaya's in San Mateo area.   ~Note~We requested one of the omakase to have more seared and more cooked items since our friend wasn't a big raw fish eater. Tomo san was nice and served up some specials for her. He made sure that each item was okay and that she liked what was served. Wish the server were more prompted on refilling tea. We had to ask for a pot since we kept asking for refills. If I were to do it again, I would do  course meal, use the $ difference and order some different stuff on the menu. You might get more bang for the buck if your a nigiri person. Oh, don't miss out on the housemade dessert and the chocolate. seriously though. . on a serious note. . if yelp was to let us rate a  star for one place and only one place. . itll be this place right here. came here for the boyfriend's birthday and ohh my gosh. . let me tell you it is so worth it. this place is very tiny. its half the size of my room. . . lol jkjkmake sure to sit at the bar if you choose to get the  course dinnerfor a small girl, i have a very big appetite and this place not only made me fulfullingly full but i enjoyed my experience here. like really enjoyed it. i have NEVER ever went to a sushi restaurant and experienced the freshness of seafood like this place. for a lil less than$ for  people. i wouldnt mind doing this every month if they were closer to methe sushi chefs are such sweethearts! they really made me experience incredible. thanks for everything Neither my husband nor I can think of anything we didn't like.  It's a pretty traditional, small sushi place.  Not much else to say than that.  It's definitely pricey, but what good sushi place isn't? Wako has woken me up from my slumber of finding lackluster Japanese restaurants. Sure my wallet took a $ hit, but it was worth it. Since I'm kind of a food snob, I went ahead and chose my own dishes. Like creating my own Lego creation, rather than settling for their Omakase. Here's a rundown of what I had and my opinion, though I'm sure you know it was great since you've already seen the  stars. negi toro : Fresh and deliciousakadashi / red miso, sesame tofu, nameko, mitsuba: Tasted like a hearty broth, an acquired taste since it is red miso, but liked it nonethelessgoma dofu / house made sesame tofu: Great homemade dishankimo ponzu: Yummy with that delcious glazekaisen sunomono: Crunchy and refreshingen chawanmushi: My favorite out of everything. Digging into the various layers was like finding edible treasure at every turnkisetsu no kakiage: fresh but passable. I really wanted more of a shrimp tempura dish instead of a fried pancake thing. All the sushi I bought was super fresh. I ordered one of each seasonal piece nigiri style. (See pic of the menu and of my sushi attached). Each piece was around $ $ and was as good as my other favorite Japanese restaurants. The blueberry panna cotta was small, but had a good creamy texture, and a tart blueberry aftertaste. We enjoyed it immensely. The service was great, and the teapots were cool. Steel, and each table had a different one. Reservations strongly recommended, as we saw people getting turned away left and right. Would I come back again?Do fish need water?Hell yeah! I have conflicting feelings on my experience at Wako. While the food is high quality I feel like the environment and service aren't up to par. Wako is definitely a small restaurant. The center of the restaurant is a sushi bar. Table seating is relegated to about five. Even though the restaurant is very small it is easily a five dynamite stick experience. I've been to party sushi restaurants that are quieter. It's a strange dynamic when you're eating high quality food with the soundscape of a super bowl tailgate. The food is broken down into grilled pates, appetizers, small plates, rolls, and nigiri. This isn't a cheap restaurant. Each piece of nigiri goes for $. But the nigiri does melt in your mouth. The fish has a really high level of luscious fattiness to it. Two of our party, including me, opted for the pre fixe menu. They don't specifically state what you'll receive. It just says the amount of nigiri, small plates, etc. The prix fixe menu is a relatively good value, I think it'd be best to order exactly what you want and adjust as needed. While the food is good overall I feel like it's lacking a bit of that "oh" factor. The one standout dish is the chawanmushi. Service is questionable. Even though there seem to be many servers, the experience felt like an ordeal for both staff and customers. One of the difficulties stems from the number of plates. There are so many plates! For the nigiri they even combine customer's orders on one plate. Then the waiters have to discuss each and every piece to the customer. I feel like the waiters would have a much easier time if the restaurant weren't so cramped. We were never really checked up on, but it was mainly because they were so busy trying to bring us our plates and take away the ones we were finished with. _High caliber Japanese cuisine that you'll most likely forget about thirty minutes after leaving. Chaotic service and atmosphere. Is the food worth the hassle? I'm not sure but it's great on its own. Incredible! Best sushi in SF that I've had (or maybe anywhere?)I walked by this place and the decor was so clean and wood y that I needed to come here. DO set a reservation because every single seat is taken! They fill it up to maximum capacity!We ordered  seven course omakase and some separate orders of nigiri. Everything was so fresh and perfect. Service was amazing  our server was attentive and even told me what not to eat (there was an odd plant on the plate). She refilled my teapot like x. The dishes are also very unique (vs. other sushi places that are a bit generic). I need to come back asap. Oddly, they do not serve any soda. . . I came here a couple weeks ago without a reservation. Unfortunately they were all booked up, but one of the ladies there was nice enough to offer us a table if we could eat in an hour. Since we were there already, we thought, why not try it?! We were sat at a table. Since we only had an hour, I couldn't get the seven course omakase and settled for the four course. The roommate got the chirashi sushi. Each came with the following. Four course ($)   small plates,  bincho grill,  pcs nigiri and miso soupChirashi sushi ($)   small plate, assorted fish of the day on sushi rice, miso soupI really enjoyed the  piece nigiri that came with my omakase. Each piece melted in my mouth!  And I loved that each piece has it's own sauce brushed on it! So good! The small plates and bincho grill were good as well, but I didn't love it as much as the nigiri. The roommate wasn't really impressed with his omakase. He said the fish quality was average and the sushi rice wasn't very good. His family owns a sushi restaurant so he probably knows better than me. But he thought it wasn't worth the money. I didn't really agree with him, but he have very different tastes. I also got a glass/cup of sake for $. I told our server I like dry sakes and this one was perfect! I don't remember the name of the sake, but my receipt said IZUMI so I guess that's what it was called. I really wish we had more time since I wanted to try so much more! Since this restaurant is so small, I think it would be smarter for them to not take reservations. That way they wouldn't have an empty table for over an hour waiting for a reserved party. I probably would have ordered A LOT of food if I had more time since I really wanted to try a bunch of things. But it was really nice of them to fit us in. A good  star experience! Hands down, the best sushi I've had in SF. Tomo, who used to star at Sanraku, takes it to another level here. I am very picky about which nigiri I eat, but I had faith in Tomo's mastery and ended up enjoying fish I previously hated  like ankimo (monkfish liver) and pretty much any white fish in the sea. It's expensive and you won't find any dragon rolls or any mayo slathered Americanized stuff (which I actually found to be refreshing for a change), but you won't find better sushi in the City. Plus, Wakako U. (aka Wako) loves the name!I used to complain that San Francisco was something of a second rate sushi town. No more! If you have every seen "Jiro Dreams of Sushi" and wanted to experience it. . . this is the place.   Recently we went with dear friends who own their own restaurant and had heard good things about this place.  All four of us sat at the bar and had an incredible evening. The service, environment and food far exceeded our expectations.  Each piece of sushi was presented upon preparation and was not only a visual pleasure but an incredible tantalizing delight. I had a wonderful and memorable dinner at Wako on a Saturday night. It's a small restaurant stuck into a crowded part of Clement Street, so find it and make a reservation. You won't want to miss this. We enjoyed fresh butterfish and sweetfish nigiri sushi, plus several other items from the menu, which changes daily depending on what fish they can get as fresh as they can. Among other things, we had the roasted seafood and vegetables, which were served in an abalone shell. I brought my girlfriend there for her birthday dinner, and while we were not late for our reservation, we didn't have time to go home and dress appropriately for our dinner. I was dressed in long shorts and felt embarrassed to go into such a classy restaurant, but the waitpersons could not have been more gracious and accommodating to us. Thank them  for such a wonderful and memorable dinner. We enjoyed every taste and dish we had, but especially enjoyed the black cod with eggplant, and loved the grilled fish collar, which is sometimes butterfish but happened to be salmon that night. What an elegant, gracious, lovely meal. What a neighborhood gem!  Be sure to make a reservation, a couple was turned away at opening.  Choose the sushi bar, you'll get all the perks and attention you need.  Definitely go with the  course option for $.  You get the  nigiri if you go with the  course also, but it's not the top tier stuff.  LOVED: housemade tofu tempura fig aji aji fried bone salmon nigiri toro chawanmushi, perfect, crab pieces embedded throughout and mochi choco bites at the endWould skip next time: uni crabRequested, but not available: kohada chutoroAdd ons: gindara, beautifully buttery and smoky Drink: try the akitabare, smooth.  Tea comes in a cast iron pot, really heavy, be careful.  If you use your fingers for the nigiri  no finger towels, use your napkin. Improvement: timing of the courses, we had grilled items at the same time as nigiri and before I was even finished with the first course of tofu, tempura fig and veg, the sashimi was waiting for me.  Made me feel rushed and didn't feel like I was doing the food justice, as nigiri should be eaten immediately.  Not only do you get the savory aspect for $, you get dessert & little choco bites. Highly recommended, a bit below the other edomae choices that have sprouted up around town, and leans more on kaiseki, but high quality and supreme service. Made a reservation yesterday. Got in today. After eating, made another reservation in  weeks! (YES that says a lot for me) Probably my first really authentic, traditional "sushi" experience. Got the omakase  course with extra appetizers and nigiri and of course lots of alcohol! I must say everything looked delicious and it tastes just as pretty as it looks! If you lahh dat uni, damn their Hokkaido uni. . . So fresh, so god! That sesame tofu. . . Godness, I can die and go to heaven. I lovee tofu in general and their tofu was seriously the tastiest I've ever had! Service was excellent and the atmosphere was comfy and homey! See you in  weeks! A suggestion  make reservations. . . I saw them turn away all walk ins. Do it now or regret ever. :) When I finally spend the time to write a yelp review, then the experience must have been mind blowing.   I eat alot of sushi, and this tops any sushi restaurant in the bay. I was a fan of the sushi chef and owner, Tomo, when he worked over at Sanraku in the metreon building.  He is both a fantastic chef and food artist.  When I heard he left to open his own restaurant, I knew it was going to be great. At Wako, I was a single diner, so they were able to fit me in at the sushi bar, but reservations are highly recommended as many people were turned away at the door.   It's fun to sit at the sushi bar because you can see these two chefs make their magic.    Tomo would explain each course to me, and the waitresses would also tell me where the fish came from.  It was either locally caught, like the salmon and black cod, or it came from Japan.   They also said that they make the wasabi there, from fresh wasabi root.    Their were two Japanese women sitting next to me, and they were both telling me that this restaurant was very authentic.  I believe them. I went with the  course meal.  Everything melted in my mouth.  EVERYTHING! So if you want to treat your mouth to something orgasmic, go to Wako. Go here. Now. Before it becomes impossible to get in. After the Chronicle wrote this week that: ". . . we were a little late to the trend, [but] Japanese flavors are taking center stage in Bay Area restaurants" we decided to try one of the new, more authentic sushi restaurants that opened recently. We wandered into Wako not knowing what to expect, but with each bite and every attentive bit of service, the dreary mood from the wind storm outside faded away. They should rename this place "Transcendent Sushi. " I'm not exaggerating. I will remember our dinner at Wako as my first true sushi experience and one of the best meals of my life. The fish was the highest quality, the preparations were impeccable, and the entire omakase menu was perfectly thought out. We were also thrilled to learn that the chefs / owner came from Sanruku. We recognized some of the recipes (like his luscious sesame tofu), but the food was at a whole other level. This is a joyful place, in a restrained and beautiful way, and I can not wait to go back. We're making our next reservation so that we have a return visit to look forward to. I realized that EDOMAE is a new trend in SF!  In Japan, Edomae is a kind of niche style which chef usually put the sweet sauce on sushi. The sauce here was a bit more salty so I do not have to put additional soy source at all. This style is good fit with Omakase because I do not have to worry about what kind of sauce I should put on to each sushi. Anyway I am so happy to have Edomae in SF! I had high expectations eating at Wako for my first time since my boyfriend came here before me and told me it was amazing (he has high expectations for Japanese food, so no doubt I would not be disappointed). This place is a tiny yet elegant restaurant. We made reservations  minutes before luckily they were able to make it since it was a Saturday and well half an hour before is kind of ridiculous lol but we gave it a shot. Once we were seated, it started getting really busy and the wait was getting longer and longer, so definitely make a reservation in advance. The hostess and wait staff are super friendly and helpful. We had an assortment of nigiris. The toro and unagi were my top favorites.  Definitely coming back ASAP Delicious, traditional Japanese dishes, wonderfully prepared and presented in a cozy but casual yet elegant setting. Excellent and friendly service. We got the  course omakase ($) and enjoyed each course. Stand outs were the house made sesame tofu and the tasty sashimi / nigiri. Make a reservation since the restaurant is small. You won't be disappointed.

name: Cocotte
review_text: I would give this place .  stars. It's a very good place with excellent service and solid French food. We had the duck platter appetizer that was just perfect and what we wanted. We then had the squid. I never order squid but the waiter told us it was special and it really was, an explosion of tastes and something different. HIGHLY recommended even though this place is known for their rotisserie chicken. We also had the rabbit with homemade pasta and I really loved it. Their desserts are excellent, we had the banana creme brulee whcih is not to be missed and the profiteroles (very good but not as amazing as the banana). The wines were good and so was the port. The only dish that was bland was the cauliflower cocotte. Anyone with French roots would be disappointed I was really looking forward to it and it was not up to par. I really like that it is a small, intimate space, it has a lot of character and feels homey which is great because I don't like stuffy French places and sometimes you have to settle for that if you want good, authentic food. Also, great romantic atmosphere. My boyfriend and I really enjoyed ourselves and loved the location, very quaint neighborhood. Parking can be tricky so leave time to find a space. Made a reservation to this restaurant via OpenTable, having this being my first time using OpenTable and visiting this restaurant. Host seated us and spoke very good French and English. Turned out our host was also our waiter, who happened to be very respectful, polite, and very eager for our visit. He was very knowledgeable of the menu, and knew how to address any of our questions appropriately. I first ordered the house espresso and the miss ordered a glass of French wine, both were outrageously delicious. The miss ordered a Rabbit pasta, which I have to say was very very good; it did not have the 'gamey' texture. I had the beef wellington with a complementary seasoned marrow next to the wellington; both were off the charts. I ordered a goat cheese gratin on the side which was a perfect choice to pick on the side. It's somewhat of an open kitchen. The chef cooks/prepares his dishes in an orientation where he is able to see his restaurant and watch his customers's amazing reaction to his food that is just extraordinary. Expect a heavy bill, but don't let the numbers intimidate you! This is one of those places that you have to visit once in your life. I wish I could give  stars to this gem in the wall. This place is called Cocotte, known for their side dishes. Please come here with any type of expectations. I assure you that they will be met, if not exceeded. I plan to come here again next year with my now fiancee, of whom I proposed to later that night in the restaurant after I took the bill. Cocotte, thank you for the exemplary service and authentic French cuisine, we will be back!  stars for the excellent service I received from everybody at this restaurant. I took my boyfriend here on our  year anniversary after reserving just hours in advance, and they ended up putting us in a very cozy corner exclusive for couples. I loved the ambiance of Cococette, as it reminds me of dining out in Europe. . . it's intimate, warm, and cozy. Food and drink were priced very reasonably given the quality of ingredients. I ordered the free range chicken and my bf the squid, and we loved it. Probably some of the best chicken I've ever had!If you're looking to do something romantic, they definitely go above and beyond in ensuring you'll have a memorable evening. Shared a few small plates and a bottle of wine here with a friend for a light dinner. We were accommodated without a reservation on a Thursday evening which was fairly busy. We shared the lobster salad, mussels and duck platter. Everything was well executed and very tasty. The wine list was quite nice as well and we had a nice Spanish wine. The close quarters make it a bit hard to hear and very intimate but somehow it works out. Service is fast and friendly. I give this place  stars, based solely on their rotisserie chicken. To illustrate how much I love this dish: One time , My husband and I made dinner plans and Of course I planned to order the chicken because duh, it's my favorite. I was looking forward to it the whole afternoon. But then when we got there, they were all out!! I was so disappointed and just felt deflated and I just stared quietly at my plate for a couple of minutes. Seriously. Then I ordered my second favorite dish from this place, which is the sea bass. It's really good, but it can't take place of the chicken.  Sigh. Cheese platter and lobster salad. . . perfection! A glass of Oyster Sauv Blanc goes nicely. . . Then Beef Wellington and Coq a Vin paired with the City Cellar Cab. . . heaven! Cocotte takes you to Europe without the airfare! I initially read about this French spot on Yelp then saw it featured on "Check, Please Bay Area," and discovered that this two year old restaurant is much better than the average bistro (and reasonably priced for generous portions) even here in San Francisco. Splurge on a glass of their better champagne, then their Duck Platter, an exquisite housemade charcuterie  of rillette, salami, and smoked duck breast. The lobster and beet salad  (heaven on a plate) contained enough meaty chunks of lobster to generously share with my husband. We both ordered the Beef fillet Wellington (rare) with bone marrow which was sublime and shared carrots with french fried onions and creamed horseradish and Brussels sprouts with anchovies. For dessert, we devoured a lovely tarte tatin more like a baked apple with treacle on a plate of crisscrossed creme anglaise and each had a single shot of espresso in  elegant demitasse cups. The service was exemplary and Yuri, the manager really was lovely and attentive, even giving helpful suggestions on food pairing. Also, the backround reggae music, open kitchen , and slow paced environment really made us feel like we were savoring the experience and not just out for dinner. . . The whole ambiance reminded us of when we spent a summer in Europe really. I was searching for a place that served Beef Wellington.  I hadn't had it for many years & few places (hardly any that I could fine) offered it.  That's how I came upon Cocotte!  In addition, Yelpers seem to like it too. I made reservations for the family.   We walked there as it is very close to where I live.   It's a very small & cute restaurant.   If you like lots of space between tables & like ample size tables while dining  this won't fit your comfort zone!  Tables are very small & not that well spaced apart between you & tables to your left or right.  First, our waiter was excellent!  Very attentive, but not over us every minute.  The wait staff was also great!  We ordered a Endive salad & Mussels to start.  I loved the salad.  I'm not a Mussels fan so can't speak to it.  My son finished it all so he must have loved it!   We ordered my favor  Beef Wellington, the Chicken & Rib Eye.  All the Entrees were excellent, except for the Chicken.  It was good  but it wasn't out of this world.   The Beef Wellington did not disappoint me & my kids really enjoyed the Rib Eye & Wellington.  We traditionally share our meals so we can enjoy everything.  We had the carrots, cauliflower & sprouts as veggie sides.  We enjoyed them all except for the baby carrots.  It just was okay. Cheese cake to finish off the meal. Overall, we really enjoyed this little place.  Great food, great service!  What more can you expect? The food and staff are amazing! Super friendly and very helpful in every way. The drinks were kept full and the food was good. They had things on the menu I had never experienced, particularly with duck. My dad really loved that, and the rest of the family just aren't huge duck people but appreciated it. The cheese tray though was amazing!! The sauces are artistically made with great pride. You can see the chef working so hard!! I had the sea bass which had a Greek influence it felt with the Cuscus (sp?) and spices. Again  the dill sauce was heavenly! My husband loved that and his potatoes  which were amazing. The only negatives were it was loud, parking is hard to come by (but that's true anywhere), and we missed out on dessert. The latter is our own fault though because we had so much fun eating the appetizer and meal that we didn't have room! Would love to go back for more. :) Ate here last night for the first time.  We really enjoyed ourselves.  The Beef Wellington was great, as was the Coq a Vin, and the Rabbit with pasta.  The salads, including the lobster salad were wonderful.  The Banana Crème Brulee was to die for, and the Tart Tatin  was perfect, and the Profiteroles were great also.  The restaurant was small which made it a great atmosphere, and we loved the atmosphere of the neighborhood with the trees and the cable car line.  The service was very good we had no complaints about the speed of the service, and our waiter was very very friendly.  We want to return to try the chicken, which looked and smelled wonderful.  The only complaints were that we had to ask for new wine glasses when we changed wines, and we were not given new silverware with each new course, but other than that LOVED the place, and can't wait to return.  We highly recommend it.  We are big fans of this new find. Had a really really good meal here! The service was fantastic, and the food was good all around. It's been about a month, and unfortunately I don't remember everything we had. I remember the charcuterie platter was really good quality, and the brussels sprouts was fantastic! We had the beef Wellington with bone marrow and I think the rabbit ragu  both were really good. And finally the banana creme brûlée was surprisingly good. Creme brûlée is one of those few things for me where I almost always prefer plain ole traditional. So I figured I wouldn't like this one. . . but it was good! Will definitely be back to try the chicken. I went to Cocotte this past Friday with a group of .  We arrived on time but had to wait at the bar for about  minutes before we were seated.  The restaurant is quite small, so the wait was understandable for a larger table. We ordered a bottle of Spanish red wine to start and later had a California cab.  They were both great, and the restaurant has a great selection of wines, particularly reds. To start, I had the Gruyere Cheese and Thyme Churros (/).  These were served with a horseradish creme fraiche, which I really liked.  The churros themselves tasted similar to mozzarella sticks but were much more subtle and with a much softer, less stringy cheese.  Although I enjoyed the texture of this appetizer, I found the taste to be much too subtle and missing a "punch" that I expected.  My tablemates agreed. For the main dish, I had the squid with forbidden rice, which was just amazing (. /).  I love squid ink, and this dish did not disappoint.  The rice was cooked properly, the squid was soft and flavorful, and the beurre blanc was rich and a little tart.  The dish was wonderful, but definitely on the heavier side.  I was not able to finish this dish, but I really enjoyed it. My friends had some other dishes, some of which I noticed that they loved.  A few of my dining mates shared the duck platter, which they actually devoured.  Another friend had the Beef Filet Wellington, which he really enjoyed.  The dish came with a side of marrow, which he raved about. I really enjoyed my first visit to Cocotte.  Overall, a tasty French restaurant with a good selection of reds. Cocotte really has it all. It is a delightful place to eat because the food is prepared with loving care. The wait staff is caring and helpful and we were surrounded by many others eating quietly and enjoying it all just as we did. Although I imagine the food comes from the same kitchen, Cocotte Sud is just not as successful for us as this charming place. Food: If you are going to Cocotte for the first time then you have to order the Rotisserie Chicken! It is so flavorful and tasty! You can order a / chicken or full chicken. I will say my petite friend and I ordered a / chicken to share and we politely fought over the delicious meat and agreed that next time we'd order a whole chicken (it is just that good!). The chicken comes with sauces on the side which I don't think are necessary since the chicken is already so well seasoned for taste. You get a side (or "cocote") when you order a chicken which turns out to be a pretty good deal. The Yukon Potato Gratin with Goat Cheese is incredible and one that I can never pass up! I also am a sucker for their French Fries and aoli sauce. Atmosphere: The restaurant is very small. There is a bar where you can sit and enjoy a drink while you wait for your table. It is very odd because some nights it is packed (no reservations available and not a chance to get a table) and other nights you can get a table no problem. I highly recommend making reservations here. Location: Cocotte is located on Hyde Street which is the same street the cable car runs on. If you are visiting and staying in downtown or Fisherman's Wharf you can easily take the Hyde Street Cable Car here for dinner (just make sure to leave enough time). It is a pretty great way to commute to dinner and you can get off right in front of the restaurant. As a heads up, finding parking around the restaurant is not easy. Take Out: Cocotte offers "Rotisserie To Go" which is there version of take out and it is awesome! You can call ahead and order a chicken and some sides for a great last minute family dinner. It is reasonably priced for a quality takeout dinner for two given how much food you can order for around $. Heads up that parking is hard to come by in this area and double parking is a big no no because it blocks the Cable Car tracks.  Overall: I give Cocotte a low  for the high quality food that is always well prepared and deliciously flavorful. The food at Cocotte deserves the full five stars, but the service is what gets a two star review. For years my boyfriend has been dying to try Beef Wellington and I'd finally found it as a main stay on Cocotte's menu. I made reservations for an early Thursday evening for my bfs Birthday. We were seated right away and served water by a very nice young man. Then, after moving around the menu, trying to nicely suggest to our waiter, whom we hadn't met yet, that we were ready to order, he finally showed up. After taking our drink order, he arrived after another  minutes with one beautifully poured beer and another that was half foam. My boyfriend nicely asked for a different one, because why would you spend $ on a half a glass of beer? He kindly showed him the glass and the waiter said it was from a bottle, so that's it. That told me that he didn't care, and it was his carelessness in pouring that caused the beer issue. Our food arrived quickly, and it was amazing! The Beef Wellington was everything my boyfriend had hoped for. I'm not sure we saw our waiter again until our table was clear. He asked if we'd like another beer (should've been on the house, considering the other one) but we declined without mentioning why. In all, I felt judged. I felt like our waiter saw myself and my boyfriend as people who scrimped and saved to have a special birthday dinner, and we couldn't know or afford anything on the menu, so why bother. Well sir, that is not the case, and if it were, it shouldn't matter. Treat everyone with the same respect, and give the best service you can, regardless. Customer service is a skill, and one that you choose to only have when a table of two is going to order an entire bottle of wine. Tip of my hat to the chef, but to our waiter, learn how to pour a beer and don't judge a book by it's cover. Fantastic experience. Great service and a really pretty space. We got married at SF city hall on a friday and instead of having a traditional reception we opted for a fancy dinner instead, so we rented out Cocotte for the night and everything was perfect!  All the food was incredible (they let us customize the menu) and the staff were very accommodating.  They didn't give us a time limit and said they would stay open until our guests were done drinking and mingling.  Thank you so much for making our special day so wonderful! Lovely service and amazing rotisserie chicken.  My fiance and I split a whole chicken and we were both full.  Dipping sauces accompanied with chicken was a great touch!  As with most SF restaurants but felt even more so here, seating accommodations were very tight.  Felt like we were on a triple date with the couples sitting on both sides of us.  We will definitely be coming back to this neighborhood treat! If you haven't been, go.  If you have, you know how good it is.  The chicken, ambiance, and service are all worth going. DELICIOUS food! Super nice waiters, and excellent service. Started with the duck platter before moving onto my plate of Coq Au Vin, which was absolutely perfect. For dessert, I shared the banana creme brulee with my boyfriend  I honestly think it was the best creme brulee I've ever had. Had a pm reservations which i got with opentable. com for a birthday party but had to wait an hour :[ because they were just running late, unacceptable. Another great dinner! We sat at the bar again and had the padron peppers with sea salt, Coq au vin, duck confit, and two glasses of wine. Everything was delicious and the service was fantastic. Started with the lobster salad. Really tasty and chucks of lobster but I got a little lobster shell in mine :( Mussels really good. The sauce was great and even better on your bread!Half rotisserie chicken delish especially with the sauces. The green is the best!Potato gratin really creamy and cheesy but not soggyBanana creme brûlée and profiteroles really tastyGreat champagne Very goiod food, all cooked perfectly. I had the beef wellington and i was delciious, nce soft flakey crust and perfectly medium rare. We started with the lobster saald which was quite nice and refreshing as well. nice bottle of wine for the table and my girlfriend got a steak as well. Total was $ a little pricey but worth it. Nice quiet restaurant and cool open kitchen concept. Don't eat often at  $ restaurants, but this one was worth it. Showed up with a reservation and ended up waiting a half hour just to find out they were out of  of their  entrees. We unfortunately left after getting our water because there was nothing my family and I could eat. Delicious meal!! Had the lobster salad to start then the half chicken followed by the banana creme brûlée . Fantastic flavors cool ambiance , quaint small place , handsome employees For the first time I tried French food at this cozy restaurant.  We were celebrating  birthdays and our close friends invited us to one of their favorite places in the city, Cocotte! Our reservation was at : and we checked in,  but our table wasn't ready, so we decided to go across the street for some wine. While we waited we were looking at the wine menu and before you know it, our table was ready :)There were four of us that had to squeeze in a little space, literally our tables were  inches close to the tables next to us. The restaurant was very nice. It was a dressy restaurant,  but was very comfortable. Perfect for a date to remember! For our appetizer we shared the clams and complimentary bread with their olive spread and butter. . . to die for! As we explored their unique and short menu (which makes it much easier to order btw) I decided to order the squid entre. It came with squid ink rice and delicious grilled shrimp,  very good! My friends ordered the rooster,  rabbit pasta and more clams.  It was a nice variety for everyone to try out. Plus we had  bottles of red wine, perfect! The customer service was absolutely the best.  These guys were so polite,  honest and prompt.  Since the restaurant was pretty small and packed, we were still able to get there attention whenever we needed anything.  Definitely give this place a try! There are alot of bars  very close by that are fun to hit up, enjoy! I'm coming back here for the banana creme brulee.  It was like you know what in my mouth. oh, and the food was good too!  I ate a special item on the menu  rabbit with homemade fettuccine. Good service. Good wine. Good ambiance. Good location. What's not to like? Very cute, cozy French restaurant. The service was fantastic and the atmosphere was very nice. The kitchen is open, and although that added a nice touch to the ambiance because the restaurant is so small it made everything very loud. We often had to shout and repeat ourselves to be heard over the noisy kitchen and so many people packed into a small restaurant. I started with the tomato heirloom salad, which was really good. The coq au vin was fantastic. . . Very flavorful and well cooked. Beef Wellington was one of the best I've had, although a tad dry. The banana creme brûlée is a MUST HAVE. The flavors and textures were spot on. The perfect way to end a great meal. We will certainly be back! Watch out for this place!  They will try to upsell you really really badly!  I asked for a $ bottle of wine and our waiter recommended another bottle. Bad on me for not checking out the price but this waiter ended up selling us a $ bottle of wine which we did not realize. During the course of the dinner we ordered another bottle of wine and when the bill came we were shocked. We talked to the waiter who offered to give us a free dessert after he charged us $ on two bottles of wine. We talked to the manager and his response was they don't want piur type in the restaurant and he told us F you . Can't believe that somebody would say that to four people who just spent $ on wine and dinner.  do not go here. They should be putout of business    This is not the way things are done in San Francisco Went here to celebrate a friend's birthday, and I mistakenly made the reservation for the wrong night.  But luckily there were plenty of tables not because it was empty but we were just lucky I guess, because it got full quickly after we were seated.   And the host was nice enough to get us a table right away.  The place is pretty small but it was not cramped, they made it work, it was pretty cozy and intimate actually.  They have nice interior decor and the ambiance is both friendly and very comfortable, I really liked it.  So, the host was very nice, the barkeeper was also nice who was nice enough to recommend the Grimbergen dubbel, which I really liked. It was flavor and almost sweet.  It was really delicious.  The server was also nice, she was patient with me since I'm actually ignorant So, on to the food:Duck platter:duck & sunchoke rillette, duck salami, house smoked duck breast, walnut muffin, red onion pickles, grain mustard.  This is very delicious, I like the rillette the most, it full of flavor yet light and not very rich, which is great in my opinion.  The duck salami is also very good but if I'm forced to choose one, I'll go with rillette.  Good thing it's a platter.  I don't know how they know but the grain mustard is the right condiment.  I took a piece of the walnut muffin and put on rillette, salami, duck breast, the red onion pickles and top if all off with the grain mustard and put them all in my mouth, it's not finesse but it's an explosion of flavors.  Potato gratin with goat cheese:  Very tasty.  Enough said. beef filet wellington:wild mushroom, puff pastry, beef jus.  Never had beef wellington before so I was looking forward to tasting this and it was worth having it here for my first beef wellington.  The beef was cooked perfectly (medium rare) and the pastry was crisp, light and airy, it was great.  It was so good that I finished it in record time, I did not time it but it was pretty fast, my friend was impressed.  Branzini sea bass: Anchovies crust, couscous, sweet' tomato, lemon yogurt & dill  my friend had this but she was forced to share it because I finished my food so fast, I think she felt that I must still be hungry?  So, she gave me a small portion of the dish.  From the amount, I had I can tell it was very good.  I'd have this dish when I return again or maybe I'll have the duck confit.  Oh well, I might have to go back twice. banana creme brulee: Okay, well, if you see the pictures of the after we've inhaled this, you could probably guess it's good, it's not good, it's very good.  Profiterolles: vanilla ice cream, toasted almonds, chocolate sauce  All I can about this is it had ice cream placed inside a crispy, crunchy pastry with chocolate syrup.  The chocolate syrup was just a right amount so it was not drowning in syrup.  I know I said it on all the dishes  it's very good, but that's because it is!Anyway, I am in no way affiliated to this restaurant nor I know anyone who works here, but I was very impressed.  The place is very nice, clean, comfortable, small but layed out perfectly that it did not feel cramped.  The staff are phenomenal, I don't say this a lot because I think staff have to be friendly and nice because it's the nature of their job actually on other establishment they make you feel they're doing you a favor when they serve you, but not here, and I think the staff that were here that night (not sure if there are different staff on a given night) were genuinely nice.  And of course, the main character in this story of this establishment  are the food.  For the dishes we had, they were all delicious.  So, that's why it's a  star review. i was surprised and disappointed by the rotisserie chicken as it had stayed too long in the roaster the day we dined at Cocette (dried out and a little hard).  I am pretty sure that's not normal though because everything else (the 'cocotte') was well executed.  the braised dishes and the duck salumi starter were amazing.  wine is really well chosen and well priced.  it's a nice neighborhood bistro, you know, like to meet friends on a Friday after work, kick off the weekend, nice dinner, nice wine.  Just know it's a noisy bistro atmosphere, so maybe not super romantic date.  AND i think it might be a tough place to bring a large party. i would go back. Undoubtedly the most bizarre experience I have ever had at a restaurant!We selected this place to celebrate the engagement day of my great nephew. The following was our evening:  although informed when booking, the restaurant did not even say congratulations (much less offer anything),  food came we had not ordered. We had great trouble flagging down a waiter to have it removed and given to the right table before it got cold,  several dishes we did order were tepid and had to be rewarmed,  one of us was served the rotisserie chicken  minutes after everyone else was served and half way through their meals no explanation, no apology,   the duck confit entree was so tough it was inedible, and finally,  we were never asked if we wanted something else, told that the problem was we did not have a sharp enough knife, and that we were the first customers to ever complain about the confit. To top it off we were told we ate too much to not charge us. . . . (I promise on my father's grave, we had  bites, one for my husband to initially taste and one for me to confirm his problem!  I still haven't figured out how we could decide it was poorly done with out trying it). I then shared my meal with my husband both of us, of course, left hungry. The waiter  threatened to quit his job if the duck confit was removed from the bill! He is still gainfully employed it wasn't. We gave up, not wanting to have our great nephew's day impacted more by continuing to ask for the item to be removed from the bill. . . . . . . Decent food. Terrible service. Definitely wouldn't come again given the poor experience. Cute small French spot that reminds me of the tiny restaurants you'd walk a few steps down to in SoHo NYC. Solid French dishes but not the best nor the most memorable. But the environment and service was great. Give it some time and I'd probably come back and give it another try. I eat here at least once a month and I've never been disappointed. The menu is simple, the food delicious, the service impeccable and atmosphere relaxed and convivial. I've taken every one from + year old grandmothers to teenagers to Cocotte and all have had a wonderful meal. The menu is great here, you have the get the Rotisserie!! The atmosphere and dining experience is amazing, right off of the cable car line with an elegant and familiar setting that is enhanced with the delicious plate selections and wine. It is apparent that each dish is prepared with care and has a delicate richness. If you like a French cuisine, this is where you will experience traditional elements mixed with an epicurean tongue. They have single dishes prepared individually, like potatoes gratin and other amazing sides to accompany the main course. If you are feeling adventurous there is plenty of options to select, mine being the marrow. I love the farm freshness of this place! There really is something for everyone here, between the rotisserie or seafood, salads and soups selections it is a great spot for a night out. When they have lobster anything on the menu, it is a must have! If there were six stars, I would click it! The restaurant is a bit small, but very charming, and very hospitable. The staff was warm and friendly, and the service was grand. Our server educated us on the menu and suggested great wine pairings for each of us. I ordered the Beef Wellington, which came out rich and flaky and perfectly medium rare. The rotiserie chicken was amazing, too. I know what you're thinking. . . how good can chicken be? This is probably the best rotiserie chicken I've ever had. . . very tender and perfectly seasoned. The sides were excellent, too. This place may is not a high fashion trendy French fusion restaurant. Instead, it is straightforward, honest, traditional food, made with care and served with pride. The next time I come, I intend to order the coq au vin. However, I still think about the wellington, so I guess I'll just have to play it by ear. Wonderful time here. This comfortable little place, wedged into a small space in that very special section of Hyde Street, offers a cozy and relaxing dining experience. Everything we ordered was excellent and served promptly. This place is also a solid  value. No sticker shock here.  Well done! I had an excellent Coq Au Vin here (chicken braised in wine).  It was perfectly braised, tender, and flavorful.  I paired it with some potato gratin, and a glass of their recommended zin.  It was fantastic. My biggest tip here is that the food here is good, simple, and reasonably priced.  But the real deal you get here is with their wines.  I have been here twice, and both times the hosts recommended great wines that were less well known, reasonably priced, but very good.  Do that too when you come here  ask them for wine recommendations, and do exactly that. This is also a cute place for couples' dinners too.  I came here with two other couples, and it was a wonderful evening that was a bang for the buck. I saw Cocette on an episode of Check Please Bay Area.  The food looked pretty good so I decided to check the place out.  Made reservations for dinner on a Wednesday night.  The place was (surprisingly) pretty empty when we got there at :PM.  We were seated immediately.  For an appetizer we ordered the house smoked trout rillette.  It was pretty tasty.  Definitely a nice smokey flavor.  It was served with toast and a small salad with arugula and fennel.  (. /)For mains we ordered a / rotisserie chicken with a side of fries and rabbit and mustard ragu.  The chicken comes with three sauces: gremolata, romesco, and porcini mushroom.  The chicken was good, but just a bit over done so it was not quite as moist as I hoped.  The sauces helped with the dryness and were all pretty tasty.  I enjoyed the fact that there were three very different sauces to mix up the flavors.  The house made french fries were quite tasty with the garlic aioli. (/)The rabbit mustard ragu was quite tasty.  A really nice portion of house made fettucini with mustard seeds and parmigiano.  (. /)The service was friendly enough, but just felt a bit awkward.  Between appetizer and dinner our table was cleared but no one brought back silverware.  Then our main course came and we had no silverware and had to ask. . . No a huge deal by itself, but the waiter also never came back to ask if I wanted a second beer (which I did!).  Total price with tax and tip was $.  I will definitely go back because I feel like the food and value was worth another shot!  If they just picked up their game a bit this place could be awesome. Had a very pleasant evening dining here last week during the dine around town event. The restaurant had a cozy but vibrant ambiance, delicious food, and very friendly staff. We ordered:soup of the day was leek potato soup  very nicely done, classic french twist made it great to start the meal. manilla clams  very well seasoned, brilliant addition of quinoa. wild salmon and squid ink risotto  this was amazing, the salmon was seared to perfection. tagliatelle  also pretty good, but we got tired of it after a few bites because of the parmigiano . banana creme brulee  very creamy, not overly sweet, would be better if its warmapple tart  very nice too. We ended up chatting for a long time with the Sommelier because we tasted a lot of their wines and couldn't find a perfect pairing. He was very patient and eventually shared his surprise finding that his Chardonnay goes well with the creme brulee. What a find! We had a fun night. Will definitely come back and hang out more with the wine guy! Cozy environment on a wonderful European style street. I love the rotisserie chicken take out. Went with the Dine about town set menu. The clam, risotto, and creme brulee were all tasty. The pork belly rillette, pork shank, however, were just average. One word on the salmon risotto. The set menu offers the risotto with seared salmon, however regular menu pairs it with scallop. I understand the cost difference, and why they do it that way. Wish I had it with the scallop though, seems much better pairing than the salmon. New favorite. . . cozy French atmosphere, very friendly French servers, deliciously rich and elegantly crafted food for every course, and great wine! The kir is perfect  not syrupy sweet but tangy with a nice touch of lemon, and a good deal at $. The Chablis ($) was an excellent crisp, citrusy white. From the Dine About Town menu: Starters: Manila clams were excellent, with a delightful addition of quinoa. Pork belly and pistachio rillette was unexpectedly mild but unique and enjoyable, accompanied with delicious pickles veggies. If they ever have pickled veggies, you need to get them! Mains: The salmon was perfectly done with a delicately crispy outside. The squid ink risotto was nice too. The pork shank osso bucco was the most tender pork (not shredded) that we'd ever had. Nice parm polenta with simple but delicious broccoli.  Desserts: Cherry clafoutis was incredibly moist, and the apple tarte tatin was nicely caramelized. Both were not too sweet or big, but rich and scrumptious. Service was very on point, friendly, helpful, and not at all pretentious. Dined evening of June st and the restaurant was quite busy for a Sunday evening which we thought was a good sign of things to come (or maybe it was bc of DAT?). Boy, how wrong were we. . . First, service was really terrible.  After our st pour of water and taking our orders,  the waiter never stopped by once until when we flagged him down to take our plates away and that we are ready for dessert course (all dishes were brought to us by a Hispanic man who works in the open kitchen. . . more on him in a sec).  For savories, we got the mussels which tasted just mediocre, the duck confit which wad decent (was tender, I'll say),  and the coq au vin which was also just ok (also tender).  For dessert,  we got the banana creme brulee which def was the best experience all night.  Oh, I will also give credit to the simple yet tasty tapenade that came with the bread basket. Now onto the Hispanic staff member.  While he was cleaning off the table next to us, he knocked the entirely full jar of tapenade right onto my right leg. Despite it being a small dipping bowl, it was full so all the content was on my jeans and shoe.  Without an apology, the guy looked over at me and went back to bussing the table.  Yes, I understand it's a busy night,  but you can still say sorry and offer to bring a wet towel right?  Nope. . . I had to ask him for one before he was abt to walk away and when he brought it over,  it was as if I was troubling him with a stupid side task.  Since oliver oil doesn't come out easy, I spent time putting baking soda at home on my jeans and shoe with the hope that the stains will come out (I'll be calling you Cocotte if it doesn't).  In the end,  the wife didn't want to leave tip at all but we ended up putting down % anyway just bc I felt generous and assumed that the entire staff including the dishwashing crew have a small cut,  too. Thanks Cocotte for the lovely tapenade. I did like it a lot but you didn't have to spill it on me for effect! A wonderful dinner! juicy rotisserie chicken served with delicious sauce, excellent branzini bass and one of the best paté I ever had! price are great. one of the best deal in the city. will be back soon Wonderful diner we had last Saturday . Place was packed so I recommend make reservation especially on week end. It feel like we went to Paris ! Though the food is fairly solid, Cocotte consistently does not honor their stated business hours. Open till pm? But close at pm? This practice does not lend itself well. If you want to spend your entire dinner turned around trying to make eye contact with the server to grab his attention, and not enjoying your meal or your company, then this is your place.  Took  minutes to even take drink orders. When I asked for a wine recommendation he just quickly directed us to the most expensive glass at $ without any description or nd recommendation. We had the duck platter appetizer. Eh, it was mediocre. The entrees were very average.  Two of us had the beef Wellington and the other had the special which was a steak with blue cheese. Nothing special. The sides were very good. Brussels sprouts in lemon were great and the potatoes au gratin in goat cheese was also very good. The highlight was the banana creme brûlée which was amazing. Everyone seems to agree. Knowing it would take half an hour to get the server's attention again we ordered the creme brûlée and asked for our check at the same time. It only took  more requests for the check before it arrived. The server sensed my agitation as I eyed him down as he moved through the restaurant. He finally arrived and tried to be cute by saying "voila!" as he presented the check. Sorry buddy, not remotely funny, and no I will not ever come back to your restaurant even though I live just a few blocks away. Food was average with a few bright spots. Food alone deserves three stars but the service took away from the experience so much that this was definitely a one star dinner.  Don't come here. Way too many other good restaurants out there in this city to bother with this one. Food is consistently excellent. Service is always great too. This is the first restaurant I bring visitors to when they are in the city. . . And the banana creme brûlée is delicious! Food is a bit too pricey for what you are getting but very delicious. Atmosphere is very corporate. . . Maybe that was just one night, but I came here on a date and it was neither cosy/warm nor lively. . . I would come back for the food but only with my colleagues or on a work dinner. Was having dinner her a few weeks ago and found the experience to be far less than what other yelp reviewers had suggested. We seemed to have multiple waiters all at the same who not only would interrupt us  mins after previous interrupting us or their co worker have interrupted us, and then seemed pissed that we had not made our selections from the menu. That really ruined it for us, and the food was "just ok"; frankly it was a bit too salty for my tastes. Another important note if you're thinking about this restaurant: there is ZERO parking around the area, especially in the evening. I ended up parking a few blocks away on the street, and it took me  mins of driving around to find that spot. There are no parking garages and its a really busy area. Appreciate this is only an issue if you drove in, but still, allow time for it. This place is very nice. Great setting and the foot was delicious, especially the bread!! Highly recommended Cocotte is a wonderfully cozy French restaurant, perfect for dates or small groups. To start off our indulgent meal, a friend and I shared a cheese platter. It consisted of three types of soft and hard cheeses, along with a side of jam, nuts, and an arugula salad with pistachios and balsamic vinegar. I highly recommend tasting the hard cheese with nuts, spreading a piece of bread with brie and jam, and pairing bread with the goat solo or with jam. For my entree, I ordered the coq au vin  the chicken was placed upon a bed of vegetables and potato gratin. SO flavorful and juicy, pairs beautifully with a glass of red wine. My friend ordered the scallops with squid risotto. Had a taste of it and oh my gosh. Definitely ordering this the next time I dine here. This entree had some amazing textures and is great for anyone who loves seafood! We are locals and tried Cocotte for the first time with the Rotisserie take out.  Fabulous whole chicken with its accompanying three delicious sauces.  Two cocottes  peas and carrots and cauliflower gratin.  Superb.  We will definitely make this a regular treat. The chicken and sauces are the best I've had. Went for Valentine's this year,LOVED: The bread. This is important to me. It's what I get to eat when I'm hungriest.  The ambiance. It's simple and warm, but romantic and chic. Not your corner French bistro.  The Valentine's prix fixe menu. Nothing too elaborate, but pretty delicious and with sizes worthy of a man. . . who's not too hungry. I actually couldn't finish the main, though it likely was because I ate so much of that bread. OK: Service. Definitely more positive than negative. Didn't feel like we were being rushed. Also, in their defense, the place was absolutely packed. It must make it harder to be extra nice and attentive.  Personal space. Proximity is part of the warmth and vibe of the place, but it's definitely on the you are also dining with your neighbor side. NOT LOVED: The famed banana creme brulee. Coming from a Caribbean person who loves banana in anything (with soup, next to steak, in omelettes), you have to trust me on this one: it's not for everyone. They had an orgasmic chocolate dessert, so, do yourselves a favor. Overall, wonderful place. For a point of reference in SF: much better on my record than Bistro Central Parc. In town for my birthday weekend and enjoyed this fabulous restaurant with my parents. Cozy, great decor, amazing menu and excellent service. The banana creme brule was out of this world, too! And loved that the chefs and kitchen are open for you to add to the family feeling atmosphere. I felt transported to France with the adorable and sweet French waiters  an amazing dinner and I would highly recommend this restaurant for a date night or any celebration! Great food and service! Seating is a bit tight, especially if you are taller but a nice place to grab dinner! Excellent dinner. Offering French classics as well as specialties, Cocotte has warm atmosphere that made for a great evening. Duck leg confit, half roasted chicken, filet beef wellington, potatoes and goat cheese, and a bordeaux. I will be returning. Fabulous! So glad I found this place!! My boyfriend and I walked in at . pm last night and were able to get a table. So impressed with the food and price! We shared half rotisserie chicken, lobster salad (great!) and THE BEST Brussels sprouts I've ever had! They had lemon in them. . . Too good. Best thing is they do takeout so this could be one of our new weekly dinners, healthy take out with the rotisserie chickens and sides! It is pretty loud in there tho as its a pretty intimate space but don't let that scare you! :) Excellent service with a very intimate atmosphere. I had the Beef Wellington and it was delicious. Cooked to a perfect medium rare as requested with a crispy puff pastry outside. If you ever make a reservation here and they call to ask you to reschedule, then you should either go with the new time or cancel. I made the mistake of wanting to stick to the original time. The table we were given was arguably  the worst in the restaurant. It was a noise attractor. We could hear conversations from everywhere but couldn't hear each other. I would have put up all this if the food was good, but both meals were terrible. I had a seafood stew that was practically forced on to me by the waiter and my partner had the beef steak. Both were so salty and that the only thing I could taste was the salt. Moral of the story: don't piss these guys off by not going with the time they want you to have dinner! Despite of pains finding a parking around the neighborhood this is a gem that is worth it!We really liked the ambience, service and of course a nice selection of wine, appetizers and main entrees. This is a really good spot for a romantic dinner or just hanging out with a few friends. Thank you to everyone, we truly had a great time and will be back soon! Great little gem! We really enjoyed our meal here. The place is tiny but the ambiance is really nice. The creme brulee is really amazing. Pricey but worth it for a nice date night! Wonderful date night! The space is very intimate. Dinner included: duck platter, lobster salad, sea bass, pork belly, side of cauliflower/espelent gratin, and dessert was an apple tartin. For wine we shared a bottle of Medoc. The duck platter was really a trio of duck which included duck sausage, duck rillet, duck belly, a warm walnut loaf, mustard,and pickled onions. This dish was a wonderful start to our meal. The lobster salad was generous in the lobster and burrata,m.  hour pork belly ober lentils, no brainer selection. Their apple tartin was simply Devine, not too sweet perfectly soft apple.  It can be very noisy and be prepared to overhear some of your neighbors conversation. In a nutshell it's great local spot that I hope lasts. small intimate place with european decor.  service was great but the food was a let down.  we ordered the duck platter, mussels, sea bass, beef wellington, fries and red wine.  everything varied from bland, chewy to salty.  AND that included the wine.  maybe we missed the mark on our order or we lack the refined french palate but i dont get all the rave reviews. Such a good find by my friend Jenny!Intimate and cozy atmosphere with romantic (but not too dark) lighting and an open kitchen.  Saw mostly "girls night out" tables here but also great for date night. My beef wellington was great, although my bone marrow that came with it didn't have much more than  tiny spoonfuls of actual marrow in it.  Coq au vin was also excellent, as were our potato gratin and brussels sprouts sides.  We finished the meal off with a refreshing banana creme brulee. All in all a great meal and the perfect fix for a French food craving. I felt like I was in France during our dinner at Cocotte.  The service is excellent and we loved everything we ate.  It was my first experience with bone marrow yum!  I will be back!! I almost dont want to write this review as this place already can be hard to get a table at but I just cant help myself. Awesome little French restaurant in Russian hill. Great cozy atmosphere, good for dates! Wonderful food ( love the duck pate and rabbit flat bread) and wonderful service! I'll keep coming as long as I can get a table! Fantastic food,service and wine list. The roasted chicken is superb. Great place for a romantic date night. We had an excellent meal at Cocotte. The restaurant is warm and inviting; our waitress was all smiles and friendly. It was a fab time. We shared the duck platter to start which was awesome. Duck saucisson sec was tasty as was the smoked duck breast. I've had better rillettes but this variation was still quite good. I had the coq au vin (yum!) but also got a taste of everyone else's mains (roast chicken, pork belly, rib eye steak). All were cooked perfectly. The sides were my favorites though. Cauliflower cheese had that nice chewy golden brown cheese topping. Potato gratin was nice and creamy. Brussels sprouts were good too (but lacked a little oomph). Fries were good albeit slightly soggy but were more than made up for by the excellent aioli. We shared the molten chocolate cake for dessert. This was probably my least favorite dish of the meal. There wasn't anything inherently wrong with it but it didn't have the wow factor of some of the others. I'd definitely come back though! Cocotte has that quaint, European vibe that makes it an ideal date spot. My girlfriends and I were surrounded by lovey dovey couples, but we didn't mind.
