Here are what I think of what we ordered (for the three times we've been there):Awesome dish Sea urchin, chicken liver, beef tartar, steam mussels, sweetbreads, and marrow bones (a bit too greasy, should order when there are more than  people)Good dish  Escargot Dessert  I enjoyed the palmier ice cream and my husband, who likes sour stuff, enjoyed the lemon tartFor the raw dish, they are just simply fresh. How can you go wrong with them? Anyways, I am only giving it a  stars because I have not yet tried any of the main dish because every time I go, it's pretty late. Definitely after dinner time. But so far it seems promising to me and I will definitely try them later. I guess we went on amateur night or something.  I had high hopes for this restaurant considering I had just gone to Bistrot Urchin and was thinking I was going to enjoy this place a lot more.  But that wasn't the case.  Had reservations for a Friday night and surprisingly the restaurant wasn't all that packed at :p, which was surprising because there were no available reservations.  The hostess seemed kind of stiff and cold when we walked in.  Congrats to Corey Lee for his new Michelin stars at Benu, I think they're well deserved.  But I can't help feeling that he's kind of phoning it in  with this restaurant.  Our entrees came out lukewarm, which is a pet peeve.  For this price point and the caliber of the chef, come on. . . bring the food out while it's still hot.   The food itself wasn't anything to write home about, it tasted under seasoned. Our waiter seemed distracted and wasn't at all attentive.  There were a lot of restaurant staff walking about and I couldn't quite tell what they were all doing, especially since they weren't packed at all.  They just seemed to be milling about actually.  With both Absinthe and Chez Maman nearby, I'm not sure this restaurant adds anything interesting nor new to the area. The name sounds like Hercule Poirot's lost lost stepbrother who has been accused of murdering Madame Lafarge with a penknife behind the armoire. Mon dieu, j'accuse Monsieur Benjamin! Mais non, it is master chef Corey Lee's latest culinary venture, a casual brasserie that is anything but casual in execution. In fact, Lee's immaculate culinary skills  so beautifully presented at Benu  can't help but inform this stylish new spot in Hayes Valley. He brought in Jason Berthold of RN to assist, and the results are most worthwhile even if there was a glitch or two along the way. As you would expect from Lee, the space is sleek and modern, not as minimal as Benu but more open and with definitely the same contemporary vibe that's like a porn palace for any salivating foodie (photo: bit. ly/DzQO). Jamie W. took me here for my birthday. Wasn't that nice of him? No Chipotle burrito bowl that night. The menu is still on a piece of folded paper, but it was chock full of appetizing delights, but first, Parisian style cocktails were in order. Jamie went for the $ Pass the Hat, a tantalizing mix of aged rum, Aperol, Fino sherry, Bonal (an apperitif) and lime (photo: bit. ly/tYHpjz). Not a huge kick there but refreshing. I preferred mine, the $ Special Forces, an ideal blend of calvados, sweet vermouth, apple and walnut that was smooth and naughty at the same time (photo: bit. ly/sKtCB). No amuse bouche for us that evening, so we started our meal with a petit plat, the $.  Pommes Gaufrette with Whipped Chicken Liver (photo: bit. ly/qYYJe). They were lightly crisp potatoes prepared in a waffle like fashion and accompanied by a creamy pâté covered in chives. Delicious and most addictive. Those taters honestly would have tasted good with Lipton's French onion dip mix. However, the star of the evening came early for a change, the $ Steamed Mussels with MB Bière and Garlic Sausage (photo: bit. ly/ZppnyH). A healthy portion arrived, and the mussels were fresh and succulent. The beer lent a nice accent to the seaworthy broth as the sautéed garlic sausage was crumbled all about. Dare I say that these may be the best mussels in the city, and I've had plenty in my day. What's rather ironic was that the entrees were not quite as singularly sensational, the flaw in raising the bar a bit too high. Jamie ordered modestly, the $.  French Dip Sandwich, shards of fresh roast beef served in a torpedo roll with horseradish and melted Gruyère (photo: bit. ly/tqip). The sandwich was a modest creation, nothing to write home about except that the au jus had a nice earthy body to it. The $ Pommes Frites that Jamie ordered as a side were surprisingly drab even with the full lubrication of the aioli (photo: bit. ly/tYHMdZ). I ordered the $ Lobster Ragoût, which was a simple bowl of spaghetti with mirepoix,bacon and herbs with chunks of lobster that didn't quite marry well enough with the tomato sauce (photo: bit. ly/sbwTHP). Considering this was Corey Lee, I was a little surprised the dish was only marginally tasty hamstrung as it was with the slight incompatibility of the flavors. Dessert came to the rescue with two that were genuinely stellar. The simplest was the $ bowl of Palmier Ice Cream with Calvados Caramel, three scoops of sheer creamy decadence (photo: bit. ly/sbwVQ). The fancier one was the $.  slice of Gâteau Marjolaine with Hazelnut, Praline and Crème Anglaise, a perfectly layered cake that could have come from a high end patisserie in Montmartre (photo: bit. ly/sEpdx). Not too sweet and oh so flavorful without the fussiness one would expect from a nine layer creation. I gave passing glances to the duck confit, the steak frites and all the other French fare one would expect from a brasserie, and believe me, a return visit is in the cards. Even Jamie said he would forego his burrito bowl one night for an order of the mussels and the ice cream at the bar. I need to take him up on that before he forgets. FOOD   stars. . . Corey Lee artistry applied to French brasseries fare hits far more than it missesAMBIANCE  .  stars. . . nice, sleek space in Hayes ValleySERVICE  .  stars. . . good though our table changed hands mid meal for some reasonTOTAL   stars. . . most definitely a worthwhile new spot thanks to Lee's and Berthold's considerable chops A local "food critic" who praises any restaurant that will give her a free meal claims that Monsieur Benjamin offers something we  don't have a lot of in this town: a traditional French bistro. While the flavours were French Bistro  the San Francisco twist is that the prices would be considered ridiculous in any actual French Bistro. TL:RL review over priced but tasty French inspired food served in a cold atmosphere. The French Spouse and I strongly disagreed about the food here. The FS thought the food was very good while I found most of it one note. I do agree the lobster ragout tasted just like the ragout you get in Marseilles. We started with three "small plates". Camembert Beignets I think most Americans who are used to the beignet found in New Orleans will be surprised by these tiny square pockets of cheese. The FS liked them, I found them to be average. . Potato and Leek Croquettes nicely cooked but not exceptional in terms of flavour. . frites decentWe then had two apps. Sweetbreads a decent portion of two pieces with an acidic sauce that was a good balance for the richness of the sweetbreads but a bit one note. Escargot The preparation was actually quite traditional but was a bit heavy handed. We finished our savory dishes by sharing the lobster ragout which I found to be overly salty. For dessert we had the gateau marjolaine, a very traditional slice of layer cake with thin layers of sponge and cream served with a Crème Anglaise which was unnecessary. It was a very good version of it but not worth the  dollars for the thin slice. Like the prices, the decor is nothing like an actual French bistro. It's in a modern building and takes inspiration more from Bauhaus and edison bulbs than a French bistro. They have sound baffling on the ceiling but the sound is still very bad. The single stall bathrooms are still gendered for no good reason especially since they share a sink. The lighting is also poor with a ton of edison bulbs. All in all, I would rather spend the same amount of money eating at Corey Lee's other restaurant Benu and get real French Bistro food when I visit my in laws every year in the south of France. Delicious Camembert beignets very addictive. Everything else we tried was just ok: wings, lobster pastaGood option before the opera or ballet If I had it all, and food no longer satisfied me, I would still travel back to Monsieur Benjamin; a bistro where the starters are simple yet experimental, and the dishes are clean yet flavorful. Seafood Sausage: scallops, shrimp, and bits of lobster, made into a sausage and enhanced with pine nuts & a smooth Beurre Rose sauce.  Clean & subtle, a magnificent starter. Beef Tongue Dijonnaise: soft beef tongue on top of rye crouton, with herbs & a fine Dijonnaise sauce drizzled over the dish.  One of the best beef tongues I've had yet. Lobster Ragout:  Fine pieces of lobster, herbs, mirepoix & bacon.  Good, but no unique flavors  possibly overshadowed by the duck. Duck Confit and Sausage:  Highlight of the savory part of the meal.  The duck was perfect.  The grape and sauce au poivre fused beautifully with the dish, and prevented the duck from tasting too salty. Gateau Mariolaine: Save your appetites for dessert, and order this cake.  You will not regret it. Palmier Ice Cream:  A creamy, chunky caramel ice cream that finished the meal off beautifully. Thank you for the meal, and thank you for the patient service. Ordered the steak tartare, sweetbreads grenobloise, steamed mussels, and lemon tart. Also got the escargot compliments of the chef. Steak tartare was the best  unique flavors and well cooked. Steamed mussels were also flavorful and very filling. Lemon tart was acidic which I like. Thinking of eating snails makes me gag so I passed on the escargot. There was bread to eat with the escargot sauce, which was not my taste either. Great service and modern venue  I would go back for the steak tartare and to try other dishes. I've heard so much about this place that I felt i needed to go. The first thing I felt were the very uncomfortable chairs we sat on.  The noise level was so loud that we screamed at each other throughout the meal to communicate. I also noticed that only one person on the wait staff was smiling and enjoying herself. Now the food. . . . . this has to be the worst food I have ever eaten in San Francisco. We ordered an eggplant cavier whichtasted more like wallpaper paste than eggplant. The sea bass was dry and completely tasteless. . . . and worse, it was served in a heavy red wine sauce. when I asked for olive oil with my bread they serve the cheapest olive oil imaginable. I don't recommend this place at all. I expected more. The slight twists on the classics are interesting, but nothing was memorable. The dishes were perfectly executed, but the proteins were obscured and ultimately unimpressive. Comments in [brackets] below:Pommes Gaufrette: whipped chicken liver mousse with waffle chip [Pretty to the eye with its covering of minced chives, but it is whipped so light as to lose almost all liver flavor. ]Steak Tartare: egg yolk (molecular), beef fat dust, Pissaladière lavash [Beef fat dust had no flavor and was thus a failed conceit; the yolks were interesting yet felt unnatural; did not like the  flavor of the lavash (cracker); and the minced cornichon overwhelmed everything. ]Escargots Bordelaise: mushroom duxelles, garlic, parsley [Delicious bread crumb coating, but it could be any protein buried under there and it would have tasted exactly the same. ]Marrow Bones "Blue Ribbon": bacon marmalade, country bread [It's bone marrow and it was done properly, but there is no need for the marmalade. While the marmalade is tasty, it is far too strong and overpowering to accompany the marrow. ]Lobster Ragoût: spaghetti, mirepoix, bacon, fines herbes [Very thick with bisque  boiled down lobster shells and cream  which is, again, very tasty, but far too rich to get any pleasure from the lobster. ]Gateau Marjolaine: hazelnut, praline, crème anglaise [Exceptional. Did not use much of the crème anglaise  it's completely unnecessary. ]In conclusion:It kills me to say it, but I expect to be far more impressed by Corey Lee. I'm willing to try again and reach deeper into the menu, but my expectations have been tempered. In the tiniest details of this meal, I feel I have seen the ceiling to Lee's style. The tasting menu at Benu might be the best meal of my life, but it doesn't follow that the dream who can waltz can tango too. .  rounded down. Hailing from The French Laundry and Thomas Keller acclaim, Corey Lee has a reputation that precedes him. It is a reputation that comes with some pretty high expectations. So rightfully so, this was my mindset when we came to dine at Monsieur Benjamin. I have been to TFL, but not Benu, Lee's other  star restaurant in the city. I'm a hard sell on the  star asian fusion scene but I was willing to bite when I heard he was opening a restaurant with his own take on classic French bistro fare. Lee's interpretation isn't much of a deviation at all and you can find the usual classics featured on the menu such as escargots and steak frites but also some interesting items such as the lobster ragout. My wife and I ordered each and they were both solid dishes. My flank steak was perfectly cooked, seasoned, and tender. Her lobster ragout was flavorful with a generous amount of chopped lobster mixed in with the pasta. For starters we shared the bone marrow which included  long bones cut lengthwise to reveal the fatty treasure within. These bones had a good amount of marrow in them which is my main hangup when ordering this appetizer. Often the bones seem almost anorexic or are rendered down to almost nothing. Lastly for dessert, we finished the evening with the palmier ice cream which was simple yet refreshing. A strong effort by chef Lee which I'm certain will quickly become a mainstay in San Francisco's food scene. Delicious!  had so many small plates and dishes and plate changes I can't keep track.  the highlights;shingoku oysters are my new favorite small and so rich. shrimp cocktail  yes, expensive, but very large and meaty. tasty. steak tartare  fresh and very good, the egg yolk blobs add flavor when you get some, but you also taste the beef with out it. mussels plump and a great value for those on a budget and sharingsquab  so tender, something about a special oven.  my fav entreepalmier ice cream  yes, as good as they say. made fresh dailymarjolane cake nice mix of chocolate and the burst of nuttiness.  may not be for everyone, but like eating a box of chocolates. Chef Corey Lee was there on Sunday, most Sundays? I really really liked Monsieur Benjamin. Authentic French bistro food meets new American. Corey Lee's done it again. The ambiance is gorgeous and contemporary  very appropriate for San Francisco. Make a reservation or be prepared to sit at the bar or communal table for walk ins (which is what we did but we were prepared for this). They have a variety of cocktails, wines by the glass, and obviously an extensive wine menu as well. They have some "small plates" as well as first courses & main courses. Since we popped in here casually, we just shared a couple of each  the uni, bone barrow, and chicken mousse were outstanding! Everything was delicious and presented beautifully. The service was top notch  friendly, welcoming, and knowledgeable staff. I look forward to returning here soon! very posh, had me feeling grown eating here. Lovely big glass windows and sophisticated layout of the restaurant and cute custom plates. the beef tartar is new and exciting, instead of an egg mixed in and crostini, it was served work this egg yolk gelee and these thin brown wafer like sheets. Very very delicious. I had the quail and it was tender and the vegetable/sauce pairing was tasty. The lobster pasta was whatever. the service is good, and then wine list is good, but nothing special. this is a good fancy date night spot. Coming back for that tartar tho. Fantastic service and food.  We shared the steak tartare, chicken liver, bone marrow, lobster ragout and palmier ice cream.  Everything was great. And the liver was surprisingly light and smooth.  It was a lot of food for  people so I'd probably nix an app next time around.  True to other reviews, the marrow was pretty skimpy on the marrow so I wouldn't order that again.  We were checking out what others around us were ordering and everything looked good!  No doubt I will be back multiple times.  The service also stood out as genuinely friendly and welcoming. . . Very refreshing. My new favorite restaurant in Hayes. I went in for a late week night dinner around  after working a long day and it was just what I needed. A large and unique menu made with quality ingredients. I wanted to try everything so I ordered a bunch of small plates, a burger, dessert and a cocktail. Steak tartare was delicious as were the waffle like potato chips. The burger was juicy and flavorful and made just right. The ice cream is hands down the best I've had in the city and my favorite part of the meal. Slightly better than Smitten and Bi Rite, seriously. The ambiance, decor and design of the restaurant are fun and unique. Definitely trendy and contemporary. I was most certainly underdressed, bordering on looking homeless, as I had been painting a condo all day, but the staff made me feel right at home and welcome even with a little paint in my hair. The best service I've received in Hayes in a long time. Bottom line: A bit pricey (it's Hayes), the food is good and unique, the design is fun and trendy, they have a full bar, and are open til am daily. What's not to like? Oh and I love the name. Service was great. Food was good, but nothing to write home about. Everything was cooked well, but was really disappointed in the flavoring of all the dishes I ordered. I had the tartare, chicken wings, and the pork ribs. The tartare was really lean and seemed slightly under seasoned. The chicken wings had no special flavor, but cooked perfectly and the dipping sauce was good. The pork ribs fell off the bone perfectly, but the flavor was not really anything amazing. Friends had duck confit, deviled eggs, beignets, and lobster. Deviled eggs and duck confit were the winners of the meal  but everything else was underwhelming. Cocktails were really well thought out, but otherwise an average place with great service that failed to live up to the hype. Love this place! A wonderful menu & fantastic service! p on Wednesday and this place was packed all night! Beautiful restaurant with a large open kitchen and dining area. Floor to ceiling windows facing the streets and the lighting reflecting on the windows made it romantic trendy and contemporary. Steak tartare was really unique and deliciousSeafood sausage was fantasticLobster ragout Steak fritesPalmier ice creamMarjolaine cake Highly recommend all those dishesWill try the mussels next time, they looked so good! Def a new fave! I can't say enough good about this new restaurant!  Having been to France on so many occasions and loving their food culture, it is a delight to see so many classics of the French repertoire. . . and done so extremely well.  I loved the oeufs mayonnaise, the poulet roti, and the blanquette de veau. And Mon Dieu, the crepe gateau with creme fraiche ice cream was outstanding!  I mentioned the roast chicken because I believe in trying the simplest dish first because it is the truest measure of a restaurant's merit. The wines by the glass are well suited to the menu and affordable.  The decor is so beautiful in every detail. . . right down to the little red fox logo on the plates. Everything is a delight.  No review would be complete without a shout out to the staff. The open kitchen is brightly lit and hums with a choreographed efficiency. . . no small feat after only three months. A special mention to Adam, a bartender, and Megan, the hostess. You make the restaurant truly feel like a neighborhood favorite.  Thank you! Highly recommend! Had a fantastic dinner here over the weekend and I already can't wait to go back!We Ordered:x Beau Soliel OystersBone Marrow L'escargotSteak TartareLobster RagoutAll dishes were really delicious and I couldn't fault any one of them. In particular the l'escargot had a memorable, rich flavour. They also came served in their own little iron pot, keeping them piping hot from the kitchen to the table. The lobster pasta was also another of my favourites. Simple and light, yet perfectly executed. Although the dishes are relatively simple, each one is made to perfection and perfectly seasoned without being too overwhelmed with other flavours. The service was flawless. Upon arriving at our table there was some water on the tablecloth, but this was instantly noticed by the hostess and was promptly replaced. The wine choice I was recommend by the waiter was delicious too! Our water was also frequently topped up. This is a super trendy restaurant that I think it is more suited to a younger crowd as it's quite loud. But I love the ambience, service and the food and can't wait to come back and try some of the other menu items!! I had very high expectations for this new place as it looked very nice and always looked packed. The food was nothing special and many items were too salty. The service was also just okay. I was disappointed considering the prices are fairly high. I don't think I will be returning. When your main location is Benu, how do you follow it up with another location in the same city? You do just what they have done with Monsieur Benjamin! You take the experience, quality and style and put it in a newly built out spot where good food is needed at a price point that is acceptable and approachable. The duck confit was brilliant in that is was cooked exactly as I would expect it, and there was enough meat to make it a meal. The experience from start to finish was terrific and I can't wait to go back! Well done folks. Impeccable service, amiable staff, unassuming, beautiful array of wonderfully executed dishes,wine list is broad without being confusing and over the top. Clean, smart and receptive staff! Internal architecture/ambiance is unpretentious, urban, fresh while still being very warm & alluring. Truly my new favorite restaurant!  Pictures with comments in gallery! Bon apetit! Agree with David L. Mediocre food, over salted, ridiculously expensive prices. Won't be back. The food is perfection but unfortunately had some pretty cruddy service. I'll try the bar next time because the food is worth revisiting. I loved the design. . . loved and even though the food wasnt super fabulous, it was good. Yes, the server was weak and she seemed out of place in terms of her dress, demeanor and even name however she did the job fine. I was just happy to be in a new place in hayes valley that doesnt sell kabab and I felt as though I was in ny which is fun.  Jardinere etc have held the symphony scene for too long hence I like a new clean fresh fun option to those nights. For my friend's recent birthday, we all chose to celebrate here at this Parisian bistro inspired spot, wearing bow ties and all dressed up for our reservation. To accompany our Cep Pinot Noir from the Sonoma Coast, we decided to share the following dishes: Frog Legs en Aigre Doux Escargots Bordelaise Marrow Bones "Blue Ribbon" with Bacon Marmalade Lobster Ragoût Seafood Sausage Quail à la ChasseurIt was my second time trying frog legs, and they were quite decent, not far from chicken flavor. Their quail was spectacular, and watching the waiter pour the sauce was a spectacle in itself. I enjoyed the lobster ragoût in part because it included bacon!Normally, I'm not a mushroom fan (part of the escargot dish), but somehow, they made that work here, too. Seafood sausage just flat out works. The only dish seemingly lacking  not in terms of flavor but in quantity  was the marrow bones. Their portions appeared very minuscule, though the bacon marmalade applied tasted fantastic. I also liked the Monsieur Benjamin cat iconography applied to the plates. Was a wee bit costly, but appropriately so! I hear this restaurant was formerly part of a parking structure  this is definitely a cultural improvement that can stick around. I had very high expectations for this place considering my husband and I celebrated our anniversary at Benu in .  My family and I came here on Sunday, September th with a  PM reservation to celebrate my birthday.  This restaurant did not live up to Chef Corey Lee's reputation.  Oeufs Mayonnaise Pimenton, Chervil  pretty good, but at $.  for  pieces it was not as impressive as the price. Pommes Gaufrette & Whipped Chicken Liver  my kids loved their "potato chip" but the texture of the chicken liver needed something much harder to contrast its softness. Bone Marrow   pieces of marrow rather than , but I don't feel like the bacon marmalade complemented the marrow atop the burnt toast.  I've had better. Our main courses were the Arctic Char, Lobster Ragout, Steak Fites and Braised Lamb Shank.  All the dishes were executed well but lacked flavor and creativity. If I'm in Hayes Valley again, I will stick with Chez Maman or Absynthe.  If I'm craving a french bistro I will go back to L'ardoise. We sat outside for dinner on a nice night, which was pleasant (but beware the outside curfew is :pm).  The GM, Tomas, is so friendly and informative.  We loved the escargot and mussels and fries.  Lobster ragout was not my favorite, but the artic char main was tasty.  Cocktails were delicious.  I would return for the cocktails and appetizers and friendly service. After much excitement about this restaurant, my husband and I decided to venture in on Friday night without reservations and try our luck.  The place was packed but we were offered seats at the bar for cocktails, and after our drink they were able to find a table for us.  The ambiance is unique for San Francisco  chic but not formal.  I have to say, Monsieur Benjamin did not disappoint.  We started with oysters and the potato and leek croquettes, then went a little more daring with the seafood sausage and sweetbreads.  The flavors were unique and spot on.  I keep thinking about the seafood sausage in particular.  For entrees, my husband had the arctic char and I did the mussels, which were probably the best mussels I can remember having and they're a dish I will frequently try.  The garlic sausage and flavorful broth were to die for.  Be sure to get them with fries to soak up the broth.  I was stuffed but found a way to finish them!  My husband was equally happy with his char.  Finally we finished by sharing the palmier ice cream, which was light and perfect and a fun way to get the flavors of a palmier.  Our server was on the ball and able to answer our onslaught of questions about the menu, as well as make some good wine recommendations to go with our meal.  All in all, I'm thrilled Monsieur Benjamin has come to town.  We've been waiting ages for a quality French option and I think we've finally found it! My new go to restaurant in the neighborhood, when I'm feeling spendy, and it's cold and foggy outside, after watching a performance at SF Symphony a few blocks away. SUMMARY: Over rated, over priced restaurant. Don't go. We went there with high expectation. We put our name in the waiting list and waited for  minutes. We were taken to a communal table. I don't mind a communal table but they were packing customers. There wasn't comfortable space between us, sitting across the table, and the next couple. I felt like I were in casual pub in Tokyo. The couple was friendly but spoke rather loud. My ear hurt. We had hard time conversing with each other. The service wasn't very attentive. Our table surface was sticky. Service was slow. Description of wine by our waitress wasn't even accurate; she described a wine that is usually described medium bodied, full body. Foods are interesting but the taste lacked balance. Bone marrow was a bit too salty while lobster ragu was a bit spicy. We liked bread and butter. We liked wine and wine was actually priced right. Other dishes were overpriced. We weren't very hungry and we shared  small plates and  main dish,  glass of wine,  bottle of sparkling water, cost over $ after tax and tip. By the way, the portion was rather an American size than French. Maybe this is a plus. By the time we arrived, only  table was left  our reserved one  and we only had a little over an hour before curtain time. We asked the wait staff to fire everything at once rather than serve each dish in a separate course.   Like raw oysters, I prefer my raw sea urchin naturally seasoned by the sea, but they were unexpectedly served dressed in a lemony vinaigrette. Not bad at all, but not  at all expected. The sea bass with mussels and the duck confit were perfectly executed.  Our favorite side dish was the grilled little gems salad.  I was disappointed that the pomme frites came in a clump, glued together with little seasoning to bring out the flavor. Our waitress brought a dish of high quality sea salt to our table which allowed us to season them to our own taste. The servers and roving staff were very attentive. The front and back house worked expertly together to serve our meal to us and deliver the check within the all too brief time allowed. We will return again but, next time, with more time to spare. Another overrated, overpriced place in Hayes Valley.  My fiancé and I could not wait to go since it opened in our neighborhood not that long ago. We were left completely underwhelmed. . . . to say the least.  We split an order of mussels which were pretty good but I prefer the mussels are Chez Maman up the street.  We also split an order of Frittes which we thought would come out with the mussels but didn't at least that is what we asked of our waiter. They arrived first and it was at least  minutes before any other food came out.  My fiancé wanted to try the chicken wings gross, ugh I could barely eat one.   They were overcooked and had basically green mayo dip served with them.  Then arrived the mussels after almost an hour and then the roasted chicken quite a bit after that.  The roasted chicken was ok.  It's $ and doesn't come with anything except a side of oil & fat (supposed to be gravy I guess??) We ordered a side of roasted beets to go with the chicken. . . meh.  The whole meal was $ for  cocktail each, fries, shared mussels, shared chicken with crappy side and delivered to us over  minutes.  We arrived at :pm and didn't leave until almost :pm.  The place was somewhat busy but definitely not packed and no wait.  Besides paying so much for ok food, there was an adorable older couple sitting next to us.  They were from out of town and just went to the theater.  They had to be in their mid 's early 's.  What completely topped off the less than desirable experience for us was when the woman politely asked the waiter if he could call them a cab back to their hotel (A very nice thing that most restaurants will do in major cities) and he said "um we don't do that. You should be able to stand outside on Gough and hail a cab".  I was so pissed.  What happened to the exceptional service and going above and beyond ?  The couple obviously has not adapted to the Uber or Lift generation, they didn't even have cell phones or they were so old school they don't need take them out in public places (Another rant for another occasion).  I just kept imagining this waiter saying what he said to my grandmother and I didn't like it.  I absolutely do not mind paying for amazing food and service.  This place has neither.  I will continue to go to my favorite neighborhood places like Chez Maman, Ottoro or even Hayes & Kebab. The Most OverRated New Restaurant in SFBAD service. Mediocre food at high prices. Don't go. Well one thing is for sure, Monsieur Benjamin is no Benu not even a mini me Benu.  Oh my, disappointing! of us went and we ordered  appetizers.  The only one really, really good was the deviled eggs, ($.  for  halves).  We got  orders of those, I had  /.  YUM.  We also got the Poached shrimp ( for $. ) and unlike Michael Bauer's assessment they were not the best shrimp any of us have ever eaten.  However they were good.  The fried chicken wings ($. ) were a bit odd.  Deep fried but not really battered. They were crispy but they looked like deformed tiny chicken wings.  I think it was how they were cut.  I bet they got  pieces out of  chicken wing, yes that small.  I bit into  and it was very pink inside, so forget that one.  They did come with a tasty green sauce.  Next came Pate de Campagne ($. ).  No flavor. Thank God for the great whole grain mustard. We all love beef tongue so we ordered the beef tongue diionnaise ($. ).  Well it is not the slightly chewy kind we have in Japanese restaurants but the kind my Mother made us growing up in the pressure cooker, so tender.  Which could be good, but again, it lacked flavor.  We all agreed, thumbs down. I just love mussels ($. ) but after the ones I ate here I may take a hiatus from them.  It sounded so good!  Butter, garlic, and sausage.  Well the best thing about it was the charred bread it came with.  First of all there was so little of the broth which is usually a favorite part.  So boo to that.  Next the sausage, though plentiful, had no flavor and worse no fat.  LOL  And then the saddest part, the mussels themselves were way too strong tasting, Some were not, but too many were.  And they were a bit dry because the broth was way at the bottom unattainable and hardly any.  So there I had a big bowl of mussels with lots of sausage and it so sucked.  LOL  Woe was me.  Next came the entrees.  Well again, woe was me.  I had decided long before coming here that I was going to get the duck confit.  But being weak and easily swayed, when our friend ordered the lobster ragout, it sounded so good.  I asked the waitress if there were big chunks of lobster in it.  And she said "oh yes,  it was so good and oh so much lobster. "  One of the best dishes there she claimed and made it sound like it beat the duck confit hands down though that was good too. So my husband who was going to order the French dip sandwich and I the duck confit, immediately switched and went with the lobster ragout with bacon (was hiding) and mirepoix (chopped celery, onions and carrots) ($. ).  First bite I could taste lobster flavor but not in a pleasurable way, second bite all I could taste was too salty weird pebbles of something, not reminiscent of lobster at all.  For $ I would think you would get fresh chunks of just cooked lobster.  In my opinion this tasted like it was made with canned lobster rejected little bits, all pebble size and the liquid from the can was poured in the tomato sauce for that so salty canned lobster flavor.  And yes there looked like a lot of these pebble sized so called "lobster" nodules.  My husband was aghast, he never got any lobster flavor.  Our friend was laughing at the so untrue description the waitress had given me.  It reminded me of cheap canned crab I once bought that was not edible.  I literally had  bites and left the rest.  I sent it home with my friend.  Thank God we had ordered the french fries.  I ate some of those and they were great. The only original one in our party ordered the pork rib ($. ).  He was expecting pork, as in pork ribs.  And instead he got a ham bone.  LOL  Yes, it was ham.  He gave us all a piece in disbelief.  Maybe the fact that it had choucroute, (sauerkraut), was the tip off, but we all missed it.  I do not think it was bad, but it was no pork rib.  LOL  For dessert we had the lemon tart ($. ) which actually did not disappoint,  I think it actually had real and just squeezed lemon juice in it, shock!  I loved it.  We also had the Crepe facon gateau ($. ) which was great too. So in conclusion, our entire table agreed, the only good dishes were the deviled eggs, french fries and the desserts.  Service was fine, timing was good.  Chairs a bit uncomfortable. Great food, this place can definitely give Absinthe some competition. We were lucky to be seated right away (Monday night, late), but the place was still bustling. Good service, good menu recommendations . . .  stars only because I wish there were more vegetarian options. Went here after work on a Sunday. I was very appreciative of them being open until am. Our server was great and made all the right suggestions. He had the attentiveness and timing down perfectly. But he left /rds of the way through our meal, which was kind of a bummer since liked him and we were left with a handful of awkward wait staff that couldn't read us. The food was amazing. House picklesSweet breadsOysters Escargot Eggplant caviar Steak tartareQuail Gateau marjolaineEvery dish was delicious. Very French but contemporary at the same time. The portion sizes are perfect. I love that we ordered several plates so we could taste many dishes and not be  overly stuffed. The wine selection is very nice. Their muscadet by the glass was very very dry  (so yum and just how we like our white wine). "Clinically refreshing" I wasn't sold on the cocktails. The decor and ambiance feels like you're in a French cafe. Love the red tiles in the bathroom. I loved benu and I love this place. I will be back soon. My new favorite french bistro. Loved the seafood sausage!! Tried two main courses so far, the quail and the duck confit, and both were excellent. Will definitely come back to try more dishes. Oh. . . One more thing, they open late (until am), awesome! And I said to myself: oh putain. Let's be honest, French restaurants in San Francisco usually range from mediocre to average. Monsieur Benjamin is way ahead of the pack. Nice, refined and friendly yet not annoying wait staff. It's quite impressive for a place that's only been open for a few months. The food is truly excellent, everything we had true French food and if there was a twist, it was modern and not stupid. Special mention for the pork ribs (which are not really a usual French cut) came out really well (maybe because they cook it for  hours?). While the wine selection is a bit short (and very French), they make up for it with a great beer and cocktail list. Keep some room for dessert because it's worth it, especially the Gateau Marjolaine and their novel Palmier Ice Cream. Now if only they could and did serve foie gras. . . There is really not much to say because everything is spot on. Their French GM, Thomas is extremely nice and helpful and keeps everything in check, like a true professional. Now a tiny bit of advice: pommes sarladaises with the confit, more garlic in the escargots and maybe some sort of stew for winter time and you'll earn a th star. Good job guys! Delicious meal.  Absolute must tries include the camembert beignets and palmier ice cream. Service was excellent without overwhelming.  Staff was friendly and attentive. Only issue was parking, but that's to be expected on a night when there is a performance at the Opera House. I love French food and bistro style restaurants but this place has a few kinks to work out before it can be great.  The space is gorgeous, lots of light, open kitchen, windows and even outside seating.  I wish it was a bit better in absorbing noise, it was a bit loud. The service was not very attentive, the food came out too fast and not spaced out since we were sharing all our dishes.  It took the waitress a while to come take our order and she was always running around, we had to ask for new plates and silverware in between dishes. The food: Frog legs: deep fried, dry and no flavor, presented like french fries.  I prefer the classic preparation with butter, garlic where they melt in your mouth. This poof frog gave up its life for nothing. Beef Tongue: It was tender but hard to tell what you're eating, the sauce was nice, but could use more flavor, very flat. Sweet Breads: one of our favorites, tender, great sauce, beautiful presentation. Burger: great classic, we loved it, the medium rare prep was perfect.  Beets: another miss, they were served hot and that created a very strange flavor.  We did give our waiter feedback and the flog legs and beets were taken off the bill, so that was nice, but I would have rather had great dishes. The desserts didn't seem inspired so we skipped and went to Spruce for the beignets. With large menus it's often hard to create great dishes all around, but we did aim for the classics and I hope this place does well, always love French food. A new resto in Hayes Valley! A restaurant opened by Corey Lee?! Sign me up! Parisian style bistro without the excess butter, well there's butter of course but I said "excess" so I didn't feel like I needed to be rolled out of the restaurant. The restaurant has an open kitchen, awesome menu, great ambiance, friendly service, what else do you need? I spend alot of time in Hayes Valley and never even noticed they were building this on what used to be a parking lot. Thank you Chef Lee. We've tried alot of their items and we were not disappointed. I don't even know what to recommend because they were all so good! Also save room for dessert! . We had no reservation and expected to wait .  While they encourage you to have a drink, there really is no place to,wait out of the way of servers . Still we enjoyed excellently prepared manhattans, and were happily surprised that the manager kept his eye on us and sat us when someone failed to,show for a reservation at  a very nice table. And we loved the classic French bistro food.  Steak tartare , chicken  liver, seafood ragout. We did not have courage to try the bone arrow, thought it might be just too rich with other choices, but definitely will next time. We are in the civic center area  often for various performances and this exceptional restaurant is an exciting, excellent  addition to many other good choices.  I just hope it won't always be impossible to get a reservation! A wonderful modern French bistro. Decor is minimal yet cozy and inviting. I opted to try the range of small dishes on my first visit. My friend loved his arctic char and butter lettuce salad. Potato croquettes were perfectly round orbs  crispy on the outside, soft and buttery inside. Camembert beignets were a little bit of a disappointment; the pillows of dough were hollow and overly dusted with the sweet cinnamon powder. Had hoped for more of the cheese flavor. Steak tartare was plentiful; as others have mentioned, portions were larger than expected. The yolks were cleverly solidified only to the point of not oozing all over the plate. They still mixed easily with the rest of the ingredients. Slightly too acidic though. Bone marrow was fantastic and well complemented by its accompanying jam. Three canals to scoop through was decadent! Bread was a bit over toasted though. Wish I had read up on the escargots  was very sad they weren't soaked in garlic butter. I thought the green puree was pesto, rather it was some cucumber combo. I couldn't even finish all  (and that was a first!). I'll be back. Was too full to try palmier ice cream but it looks and sounds fantastic. My friends probably left JFK right before dinner since their arrival time to SFO was pm on a Fri night.  I had a feeling they may be hungry, so I took a chance and made a reservation here at pm. I was so excited to find a new place that serves food past midnight and literally a min Uber ride away; perfect. I had to warn them that this restaurant has only been open for a month and that I have not yet dined here. When our Uber ride dropped us off, I have to say I was immediately excited. From the outside, you can see the entire restaurant; cool glass windows throughout.  It looked completely modern & voguish; different from any other restaurant in Hayes Valley or for that matter, any where in the city.  We were greeted by the host; I was happy I made reservations because it was packed. So we started off with cocktails. They chose their signature drink which everyone seems to Yelp about, (I did have a sip; can't remember the name of it, but it was very good), but I continued to drink red wine.  I must admit that my review is based purely on the fantastic location and ambiance of this place.  I am not as experienced with French cuisine as I am with sushi  or wine bars.  And since I just had a whole lb lobster at Morton's, I wasn't about to eat. But the dishes looked delicious from other tables; and my friends agreed they enjoyed their food.  I believe they started off with the croquettes and shrimp cocktail; as their entrees, one had the steak frites and my other friend had the duck. We pretty much shut down the place, because we continued to drink and reminisced on my last visit to NYC this past April.  The type of music playing was jazz, but it seemed to change a bit when the restaurant started to clear out. Overall, the service was very friendly and attentive. I look forward to coming back so that I can personally taste the food while enjoying the vibrant ambiance. Exquisite! This is the only word that is befitting of this modern, French bistro.  And to be quite honest, there really isn't anything like it around. The food here is not only beautifully executed and presented, but also really delicious! Our chicken liver was light, fluffy, and just gorgeous. The steak tartare was the best I've ever had, with beautiful, hand cut cubes of beef and dollops of sous vide egg yolk. The seafood ragout was another standout rich and flavorful. And not to be outdone, our dessert was amazing!  I didn't expect the crunchy morsels of meringue in the filling of the crepe, but I relished in the surprise. I knew to expect good food at this restaurant, because after all, the people of Benu, the French Laundry, Per Se, and RN are at the helm, but actually I was a bit surprised at the level of goodness. I was thoroughly impressed!  Cannot wait for another visit! Good portions for apps and great to share. The food is not bad, but I think the service could be better. The servers were not very attentive. Sigh. . . . I did so want to like you, M. Benjamin.  Your space is sleek and sexy, your wait staff attentive and friendly, and your menu ever so French.  But, unfortunately, your food was just. . . . not quite right. The good:. Palmier Ice Cream. Sea Urchin. The meh:. Sweetbreads  sauce was far too sour. . Lobster Ragout  I've had better. Specifically, at Bix. . Camembert Beignets. . . had just an aftertaste of camembert. Potato and Leek Croquettes  forgettable. . Escargot. Call me a purist but I like em drenched in butter and garlic. The huh?. Steak tartare.  Came with a bunch of somewhat cooked egg yolks that had a gummy texture, and leaned a little too heavily on the cornichons. . . The wine list. I was expecting a baller wine list. . . theirs was very thin and not very french (I mean, except that it was thin). Honestly, Mr. Benjamins reminded me of RN when it opened  awesome space, good concept, and meh food.  But, I am hoping they can pull off the same food turnaround, because I really do want them to win. Super over rated and even more disappointing that it was a Corey Lee restaurant.  This makes me rethink trying Benu. First the service was SLOW.  For a restaurant that had more workers than customers ( ish customers at pm and easily  workers ), it took  minutes for our server to even come to us and say hello.  This was great indication of what we were to get the rest of our time there. Secondly, the food was SALTY.  Like this morning I am still insanely dehydrated from the over use of seasoning on the food we ordered (beignet, escargot, beef dip and fries).   I would say pretty much inedible.  This is really unfortunate given that they are open late, it would have really been nice to be able to make this spot a regular option for late night dining.  However, I would never recommend this place to any of my friends unless they are looking to gain  pounds of water weight the next morning by being salted to death the night before!Next time I am looking for a great late night dining experience I will just go to nopa!  That place never disappoints. Very nice ambiance and space but the food is inconsistent. Love the bone marrow, camembert beignets and the sweet breads but disappointed by the deviled eggs and the sea urchin (it wasnt as fresh as I'm used to). The bar is also slow despite having   bartenders behind it. We ordered  drinks and didnt get our drinks until  out of the  dishes were done. Great location and space.  I was really excited to finally dine here.  Reservations weren't too hard but the space was packed for a Tuesday night.  The staff was all very nice.  The menu is vast  a lot of choices.  The  of us shared more small plates: CroquettesBeignetsTerrinePateBone marrow w/ bacon chutneyLobster raguAll in all I thought everything was good but I would like to go back and try more.  It already has great potential. Prime dinner time slots are often booked up on Opentable but I was able to snag a (what must've been a last min cancellation) :pm reservation last night.  I'd walked past Monsieur Benjamin quite a few times as I'm often in Hayes Valley and was excited to try it out. The restaurant itself is beautiful  bustling but not too crowded and the kitchen/bar looks impeccable.  Waitstaff was very friendly and attentive. We ordered the Rappahannock River oysters and the Shigoku oysters, steak tartare, escargots bordelaise, blanquette de veau, quail â la chasseur (would've probably ordered dessert too if we weren't full).  While both oysters were fresh, we both prefered the shigoku oysters.  Overall, the food was quite good  full disclosure: it was my first time trying escargot bordelaise so I can't actually speak to the quality of the snails but my boyfriend who is no stranger to escargot said they were pretty good.  The blanquette de veau was good but didn't necessarily blow my mind.  The steak tartare was pretty darn good and would definitely recommend.  Portions aren't "huge" which I appreciated but are generous enough that if you being with hors d'oeurves/petit plats and get a main course you should be just fine. Restaurant professional and my truthful experience of one of my co worker and myselfs dinner experience was poor and I might come back in  months or so when they get their stuff together. . . . . maybe. We walk in and the host guy remembers me from other places I've been to eat around the city, so that was cool. And then my friend Robin recognizes a server she used to work with. And I see a line cook I knew from presidio social club. It's cool to see how us industry peeps come across everyone we've met at some point or another. Anyways we sat down and I ordered a glass of wine and my friend wanted to taste two different wines. The waitress brings my glass and then it takes her  min to get my friends first taster. She didn't like it and asked for the other.  The waitress then takes another  minutes just for that! So she has been sitting there with no drink for  minutes. Meanwhile, the other tables around us were given their drinks in a timely manner. Finallyy she got her glass. Moving on. . . we ordered so much food! Being chefs/cooks ourselves, we are always curious and want to try as much as we can. I really hate the fact that we paid $ for two pieces of sweetbreads about the size of a half dollar. Really?? Who are you trying to fool? Not us, cause that didn't work. Let's move on again, escargot tasted like straight grassy parsley. Not great. The chicken liver mousse was disappointing. . . if people order mousse, they obviously like the Taste of that particular organ so why try to lighten it up so much and put it in a canister and whip it?? It tasted like nothing. It was like airy, fluffy butter.  No real liver flavor. And all this time out waitress has not come over once to check on us but mind you she has checked in to all the tables around us several times. Has to ask a food runner for bread. And my friend finished her drink and since we couldn't find the damn waitress she asked the bus boy if she could order a drink (obviously that wasn't gonna happen but we were getting desperate). He had to go pull her out from around the corner and we got another drink. There's so much more food we had but it would make this review even longer and it not worth it since nothing was amazing, just good. After we were done with our  courses, yes TEN!!, the waitress finally comes to is to ask about dessert. We order and eat it and get the bill. Paid and left the most crappiest tip I have ever left in my life with a nice hand written note at the bottom of it. I honestly believe that's what she deserved because I have been every where in the city and that lady just sucked. And kind of put a downer on our experience.  U have friends at Benu who recommended this place to me and I let them know afterwards of our experience and he was even shocked.  whatever. After wards we were still hungry due to the tiny portions so we walked to jardinière, since my friend had worked there for a long time, and got greeted with excellent service and dessert and cocktails. . . . . should have just went there from the beginning. I suppose that my expectations were pretty high given Corey Lee's reputation. We tried  dishes plus dessert.   The menu was ok.   Not great, just ok.  There seems to be a creeping trend in SF restaurants where there's a lack of 'oomph' on the menu.  What is 'oomph'?   Its that element a great dish has where its outstandingly good.    In other words, 'You have to go to (Nopa/Foreign Cinema) and try their (pork chop, burger, fried chicken etc)'.   The lobster ragout was the closest dish that captures this and yet wasn't quite there.  On a separate note, the service here was impeccable. I had a very lovely meal here. First of all my Ace cocktail was DELICIOUS. Started with potato leek croquettes and some kind of beignet which due to the powdered cheese topping tasted like amazing fancy Doritos. I had steak tartare and frites for my main, very pretty to look at, tasted fine. Fries were perfect!  Our server was totally on point, she was around but didn't hover, we had a time issue and she was sensitive to it and took care of everything. Overall, it's a fun, loud, tasty new place to enjoy great drinks and good food.  Ps. The little fox on the plates and the matches is super cute. Chef Corey Lee did an awesome job creating the concept of this restaurant. It's no Benu, but it is a good solid French bistro. What a hipster joint though. Who am I kidding, I am a hipster! Oh well. . . Anyways all our appetizers and small dishes were amazing. The mains are small depending on what you get. I got the Duck Confit and it was not fulfilling and probably not the best choice of mains. The GF got the Lobster Ragout and that was pretty good. Must come again to try other mains! Until then,  stars. Slick place, close to theaters and symphony, open late. Service is OK, although could be more efficient considering how many members of staff are strolling around in various uniforms. My food experience though was mediocre and I couldn't detect anything french about it. Pate de Champagne was dense, salty and practically tasteless. I liked grilled chicken better but it was on a salty side and rather dry. Steak frites was few pieces of cheap hanger steak with soggy fries ($ feels like real bad value here), again too salty for my liking. Probably not the best things to order in this place but I am in no hurry to go back. This place is a gem. Are you understanding? I mean, they are one of the few restaurants in SF that is not a diner (gross!), open until am and serves amazing food. Um, if you are planning on finally eating and taking a day off from your green juice diet then this is the place. IT'S f* MAY HAYY JOR! Like it's better than any other French Bistro in the city. You just order Quail á la Chasseur, eat it on an empty stomach, and you feel like a trillion bucks. Go try it yourself!P. S. Thanks Erol A. for introducing me to Monsieur Benjamin. I felt refocused enough after that horrendous Friday CF class. We need to go back here soon! THE ONE THING YOU SHOULD KNOW. . yes yes, the decor is amazing. . FOCUS. . Go family style & Go heavy on the appetizers.  Here's why. . The portion of the mains were not large, very much so on the small side.  The appetizers (most) however, where on the large side. It's very simple. . . to make it even easier, we all enjoyed the apps more than the mains we ordered. If you need another reason, its also significantly easier on the wallet. ORDER THESE (imho):HIP HIP HOORAY for. . () BONE MARROW  (holy smokes, HUGE portions!) and the "jam" it comes with REALLY tops it off, was first time I enjoyed it this way!() lobster ragu (main)() MUSSELS  another holy SMOKES huge mussels and broth is outstanding!() deviled eggs() palmier ice cream  ignore those who say this is too sweet. seriously. SKIP THESE: duck confit (main) lamb (main)  if you are feeling like a nice piece of meat, by all means. just didn't feel "special" at all to me for the price.  escargot (if you're a "i can take it or leave it" about escargot in general, id say pass on this one. . its not your typical buttery deliciousness type. . ) I was disappointed that they don't use the proper wineglasses, especially with a nice (not many, however) French list  but Burgundy out of a small generic wine glass was appalling. . . . otherwise the service was friendly and efficient. The roasted chicken and duck terrine were very good, however the $ quail was not as memorable. Loud place  better for friends than romance. If you want a French meal that isn't too heavy, with a NYC vibe where the tables are close but not intrusive, and where the staff is beyond friendly and has good recommendations, then go here.

name: Verbena
review_text: Stumbled upon this gem after dinner and had excellent cocktails. I believe I had "Thirteen Blooms". Exceptional ambiance and service as well! I've eaten in a lot of places with terrible service but none that I bothered writing a review about. This placed was so bad that I really feel the need to write this review. Extremely rude host, we walked in for brunch waited for almost  minutes in an empty restaurant as the host was on the phone. . . No one else bothered seating us, when the host finally kept the phone down he offered the seat us at the bar, before he could answer why we couldn't sit on one of the  open tables he decided to take another call. . . horrible service. We walked out obviously. . . . never going back to this place again. My whole family had SUCH a fantastic culinary experience last night at Verbena It was truly divine, every single dish and every drop of drink, we talked about it all day today and will surely continue to do so for years to come.  The staff was knowledgeable and early very experienced.  After a million delicious dishes we were then blown away by the ginger cake dessert and the house made vermouths to finish the meal.  We're all now obsessed with the seed bread that started our meal and want to know where we can get that on the regular. . .  Cheers to a fantastic menu, divine preparations and solid service!  THANK YOU! novel tastes, edgy Great service, innovative food. All around a night to remember . Food was superb!To start grilled bread with spreadable Salumi. Next we had a delicious beef tartar with fried tofu skin (pure genius) and oysters that adds salt spikes. Pork chop was perfectly cooked and delicious! Very good meal and great bartender.  Met some friends initially at the bar and the bartender was helpful and informative.  I went the wine route and really appreciated their well thought out wines by the glass. Once seated, we started with bread with spreadable salami, which may have been the highlight of the evening.  Perfectly toasted bread with what can only be described as spreadable salami.  We then had the shrimp scampi, which was good but not remarkable.  I had Duck Wings as a main course and although messy I really enjoyed them.  Overall an excellent meal on the line between  and  stars but not memorable enough to get the full .  Still highly recommended. Have been here  times now. Verbena has nice offerings and likes to modify their dishes according to what's in season. Prices are standard SF new American (not cheap but somewhat affordable depending if you dine family style or choose your own entrees).  Breads are $ , Small Plates $ , and Entrees $ . Service is excellent. Great for brunch/lunch, dinner, or just even drinks! The space is romantic/darkly lit and great for a small group or date night. I was taken there for my birthday.  The first thing I noticed was the low lighting.   I couldn't read the menu. I couldn't see how the dishes were prepared.  They should, at the very least, have a candle on the table.  I enjoyed the Little Gem salad and the Rabini.  The lamb meatballs had no flavor whatsoever.  The scampi was served whole so it was left uneaten.  Maybe the kitchen could slit the shell so it's easier to eat?  Would I go back or recommend it?  I don't think so. I'm always excited when, as a vegetarian, I can eat at the hip, new restaurant and not have to settle for a $ plate of mediocre risotto. Yay for the creative veggie options at Verbena! Service was great, it seems like they work as a team which is nice. They explained the menu well. Cocktail and wine choices were delicious, the only part that fell short was the desert menu. Nothing sounded appetizing. . . . and I'm a huge fan of deserts. I don't recall all the options but there was something involving beets and goat cheese. We will be back for sure. If you're two women dining together, expect to be offered the worst table (next to the kitchen and bathrooms) in an otherwise empty restaurant. Service is intrusive and overbearing. On a positive note, the space is beautiful, acoustics are great and vegetable dishes are excellent and inventive (but price point is too high). Meat and seafood dishes are poor and need work.  You can have a good meal here if you're dining with a husband/boyfriend, stick to vegetables and don't mind the constantly in your face wait staff.   Otherwise, Polk Street offers friendlier options with better food. De blah blah blah, and meh meh mehIs all I want to say to youDe blah blah blah, and meh meh mehTheir innocence will pull me throughDe blah blah blah, and meh meh mehIs all I want to say to youDe blah blah blah, and meh meh mehThey're meaningless and all that's trueVerbena blah blah blah, and meh meh mehI'm talking about the menu. It's a typical SF blah blah blah menu. Everything is blah blah blah here. Food and waitress, blah blah blah and meh meh mehIt was Rex's for a long time, and became Marbella for no reason but it sucked so badly because there was a character bartender. It seems like the bad luck had began with Marbella, over priced under delivered. Food went down and picking wrong staff. Nice decor for sure but lack of flavor and unprofessional poor customer service. You may have a good time at Chopstick House only a block away. Because the Chopstick House is a little hit or a lot miss, like Verbena, Chinese version. But a lot cheaper and better service, if you don't mind roaches. I recommend, don't go for both. De blah blah blah, and meh meh mehIs all I want to say to you, period. Before I came here I told my wife "I don't get excited about food anymore, because I feel like I've had it all". I was wrong. I came here and was blown away. Chef Sean is the Bay Area's most creative chef. Brunch review only!I've been to Verbena for brunch before, and was sorely disappointed that my second visit was a miserable affair. I'm basing this review simply on the fact that:a. they have almost no gluten free/dairy free options on the menub. they screwed up my simple salad (the only thing I could eat) and had to remake it when they made it incorrectly with bread crumbs. c. they insist on serving everything family style, which for brunch is not really my thing. when we stated we weren't doing family style, they still insisted on presenting everything in the middle of the table. Very awkward for a brunch of . Otherwise, my companions loved their french toast and said everything else was delicious. I'd give them another chance to do better, but only after they update their menu. As my co worker who frequent here warned me that it's a hit or missed depending what chef is cooking up that day, I arrived with no expectation.  We had reservation but decided to sit at the bar for a fun fare.  The mixologist was charming and talk us up in to sitting there for fun, and mixed up some connotations for us that was not on the menu per our request, after we ordered some that was on the menu too.  The drinks was just a okay for us considering all the raves. We proceed to ordered the beets salad that was delicous, he recommended us to get some bread so  (half)slices of the artisan sourdough ($) to dip was a nice way to clean the plate and soak up the alcoholnot sure about $.  for a half inch slice of sour dough though. The Fried pepper with eggplant was also good. We also had the duckwings but that reminded of the chicken feet at dimsum somehow so it was just okay for me.  The pork rib was tender but other than being tender it was just so so flavoring.  We also ordered dessert, it was a deconstructed chocolate cake. . . well, one word "interesting".  There were hop on the cake, we both didn't really care for the bitterness of the hop for dessert.  Perhaps because we sat at the bar and foods feel more like bar bites than an actual dining experience. So for a okay food and okay drink, nice bar tender and friendly staff, good service I am not sure if I will be running back soon given there are so many more places to try. Horrible never got main course after  hours. When we asked where our food was, The waitress scurried away and didn't come back for another  minutes, telling us that our food was on its way. We could tell that meant another  to  minutes so I politely asked for the check. The manager returned and told us our food would be a few more minutes, at which point we alerted him to the fact that it had been two hours since we ordered our food. Cocktail menu was a bit over designed, you really had to read each recipe to understand what you were getting. I love artisan  cocktails but these were just a bit to bizarre wine pours were very skimpy. Best brunch I've had to date in a new restaurant in Russian Hill. Unique dishes carefully prepared, warm service, and great wine/drink choices. Started with sprouted seed bread, a piece of warm nutty bread, dark and hearty, served with goat cheese. For the main dish, I had the corn pancakes with persimmon, fluffy and decadent. My friend went a little healthier with the little gem salad, cabbage and avocado, and claims it's the best she's had (I'm not big on lettuce, but this was quite good). They also have a fantastic wine selection, I chose the Hirsch Gruner, a respected producer in Austria, and it did not disappoint. The Bloody Mary was a solid interpretation of the classic. Can't comment on the decor, since we sat on one of the three sidewalk tables. My partner and I came in for dinner on Halloween.  I was surprised to find Verena as one of the best restaurants that I have been to in SF in a long time.  Everything that we ordered was perfect.  The menu is vegetable heavy but not exclusively vegetarian.  The food was very creative and satisfying.  The service was great as well. Been there twice now.  The second time was an accident because I forgot we already went and are not fans.  We just didn't leave because we had friends joining us and our second experience  was the same as the first.  Overall, the food isn't great and because of that the price value is really off because of the portion size.  I've now had about  different dishes from here and frankly, nothing was that great.  There are so many great restaurants in that neighborhood not to mention the city that it isn't worth going back. Verbena is probably the most beautiful looking food per dollar you'll find in SF. Artistry, beautiful layering, great use of negative space. Amazing vegetarian selection  very rich and hearty to please a very meaty person like myself. Magical sauces you'll remember every detail of. After several visits to Verbena, I'm still waiting to be impressed.  there has been a few odd staff incidents. . . It's such a pretty room, I'm hoping the food and service come up to meet the ambiance of the space. Brunch review only!Came with three friends for a brunch reservation at a on a Saturday. They opened right at a so we were the first ones sitting. But the place definitely filled up fast. FOOD: Everything the brunch menu is amazing. Sprouted bread  this is their specialty; made in house; you have to get it. It is surprisingly delicious. For the dishes we got grilled country bread with pork belly, poached eggs over braised beef, duck confit with rice grits, and french toast. Everything was outstanding  jam packed flavor, beautiful presentation, nice balance of meat and veggies. And a side of their potatoes, which were crispy on the outside, fluffy on the inside. ENVIRONMENT: Not terribly large, but doesn't feel cramped. They get a lot of natural light, which I like. There's a private dining room upstairs. There's a handful of tables outside if that's your thing. But it definitely seems like reservations are the way to go. SERVICE: Way friendly and energetic. Answered all our questions. Gave great recommendations. So attentive with the coffee and water refills :) This is a beautiful quaint by energetic restaurant with terrific service and some of the most unbelievable eclectic food I have had in a long time.  We arrived ahead of our party and there was none of that "we have to wait until everyone is here crap," we were seated immediately. Our server, Rebecca, was absolutely amazing. Rebecca has one of those warm smiles that will melt cold butter on pumpernickel bread yet she has a great sense of humor and was very knowledgeable about the food.  Speaking of food, oh my God; I fancy myself to be quite a cook and often after eating "Baby" looks at me and says "I liked it but I bet you can cook that. " After eating at Verbena we both agreed, I had a better chance of staying upright while leaning on a slender reed than making any dish that we had a Verbena. I would highly suggest sharing plates and you just have to have the: () eggplant; () duck wings; () air dried beef; () grilled chicken; and the fish stew. Notwithstanding the the horrific parking experience I absolutely loved this experience. My fave new restaurant I went to recently. I love the seed bread with goat cheese and caramelized onions. Whatever they do with that is magicAnyone who knows me knows I'm not  a huge fan of salads but surprisingly, their vegetable centric dishes are my fave here, including the summer tomato salad. The guinea hen sausage platter, grilled squid, and peaches  and blackberries pop corn icecream were crowd pleaders too. I came back for brunch and was totally sold on the pork belly fried egg sandwich. Them poached eggs with grits were ok, but the French toast was a pass for me completely tasteless and left a weird aftertaste. Overall, a great space to check out, esp for dinner. A friend recommended we eat at Verbena a few days ago and I was skeptical after checking out the menu. The ingredients in many of the dishes seemed a little like the worst of "Chopped": make a desert that includes kale and mustard or an entrée with durian and Brussel sprouts. Fortunately Verbena's dishes weren't quite that out there but needless to say I arrived pretty skeptical.  But oddly enough, everything worked, to the point where you wouldn't even notice the components that made up the dishes if you weren't paying attention everything was that good! Even the deserts, which are often most vulnerable to odd ingredients, were delicious.  We will go back, and soon! had a fabulous birthday dinner in Verbena. All the dishes are amazing and beautifully done. Will definitely come back. Wow, Wow, Wow!   This is my very first Yelp review ever.  The food was so amazing at this restaurant that I felt compelled to sign up on Yelp and give a  star rating! I've now been here twice. The last time I came was with my parents on their latest visit to San Francisco. All I'll say about the food is that it is flawless. We ordered five or so dishes and were pleased by the fresh vegetables and unique sauce and texture combinations. What Verbena excels at is the service. Our waitress overheard that we were from D. C. , and passed along the message to their service manager, who also hailed from our nation's capitol. The service manager then brought us his favorite dish and chatted with us about home. My parents were delighted! Pricey, and the menu is limited. BUT if quality is what you're after, this place has it in spades. I've been following Chef Sean Baker since he worked at Millennium  and later when he opened Gather at Berkeley. He is perhaps my favorite chef in the Bay Area. I like the way he cooks high quality, creative and flavorful food for both omnivores and vegans. I tried Verbena for brunch and didn't disappoint at all. It was in fact delicious. The frittata and the red corn pancakes were particularly outstanding. The Rose I had with my meal was also quite good. I've browsed the menu for dinner and it looks tempting and seems to cater well to omnivores and vegans. I will definitely try it in my next trip to the Bay Area. However, a new concept dish, like the Vegan Charcuterie,  seems to be missing in Verbena. Chef Baker should seriously consider reviving it in Verbena now that it has been removed from Gather's menu. I think it would give the WOW factor that seems to be missing in Verbena and that was definitely present in Gather until chef Baker left. The day that the vegan charcuterie or something similarly creative appears in Verbena's menu, I will definitely give this restaurant the  stars it deserves. I'll say first of all: beautiful space and design, excellent service, nice wine and drink selection. Other than that, our food was consistently disappointing. Our main entree was the corn cream in carrot juice that could have come of out a truck stop. No creativity with the cheapest ingredients one could possibly ask form (sweet corn and beans!) with zero flavor (except for the cheap sweetness of the corn). We also ordered the shelling bean plate which neither of us could finish. That duck egg was not a good decision and the flavor of the sauce was essentially vinegar. We also ordered the tofu pasta dish, which was very good actually, but for $, we should have gotten three times more than what was on the plate. (Really?)For what what it costs coupled with the Gather reputation, I would expect more creativity, quality and even quantity. They are clearing cutting corners on the food to save on costs. Not just in quantity, but in quality and content. I should note that we said something to them about our experience and they we were very nice, understanding and accommodating and took off one of our meals from the bill (which was not our intention). Verbena if you are reading this, know that our  intention was  to make you better and to  help you create something with more quality and creativity in your menu. I know your space is expensive, but it's obvious you are cutting corners on your food costs to save money. Hope to check back in a few months and see some changes and return! Great date spot but a bit pricey for what you get. My date ordered a bottle of wine and they didn't have it so they gave us a discount on another bottle which was nice! We ordered the josey baker bread, one veggie inspired item (apples and cucumbers), two meat inspired ones(pork and chicken), and a desert. We shared all of our plates. It was just about perfect dinner with maybe one more plate for the hungry eaters. Cost was around $ with tip. fyi: the table was really small and the plates come out in big fancy serving dishes so it was a bit hard to get situated with food and drinks on one tiny table. I would suggest immediately dividing up all the serving into your individual plates so there is room before the next plate comes out. expensive, but really delicious food and drinks with a bright, lovely environment perfect for a lazy sunday meal (brunch, to be exact). i went for the Tymes Cure cocktail, X.  it tasted so refreshing and yummy i almost forgot that there was vodka in it.  i love how verbena legitimizes a stiff cocktail on a sunday morning outside the usual concept of bloody marys and mimosas.  for entree i ordered the french toasts.  i was pretty much sold once i saw "hazelnut creme fraiche," since i love hazelnut anything.  and the toasts did not disappoint.  the fellow diner ordered the one of the last two orders of duck confit with shishito peppers and a fried egg.  and man, was that delicious.  may be the best savory brunch food item i have ever tasted.  the bill was a bit high, but the quality of food and service lived up to it. Swipe right. I want to meet you. I want to date you. I want to commit to you. Red corn pancakes topped with strawberries are that good. Such a rich, indelible flavor that was arguable one of the best pancakes ever enjoyed. But there is competition. Just as incredible was the scrambled eggs, chicken skin, tomatoes, cheddar puree and avocado on grilled bread. All at the once. In each bite. Absolutely incredible. Yet even more. We started with bread and lemon marmalade. We scooped. We spread. We marveled at how good something could taste. If Tinder were for dining out you'd be swiping this five star brunch right all day long.  stars for the food, drinks, and atmosphere (big, high ceilings) but the service was what knocked it down for us. First, the food  we went with  people and everything is meant to be shared, so we got to try a lot of dishes.  Standouts were the: shishito and padron peppers with okra, chicken thighs marinated in koji buttermilk, and for dessert, strawberry with tomato cake and fig & chocolate.  The only thing I would say we did not like was the huckleberry sundae, it was just too tart.  Everything else was good.  We did not try the salmon much (weirdly) to the server's dismay (see below). Drinks were good too, the only one we did not like was the aviatrix.  It kind of sums up what we did not like about the restaurant in general, it just seemed like they were trying really hard.  The food and drinks tasted good, and if they just stuck to that instead of making it really crazy/stand out as far as presentation, it would all probably taste even better.  The bar is nice as well, if you just want a place to have a drink. Our main issue was with the service.  It was to the point of annoyance.  For example, as mentioned above, the waiter tried REALLY hard to sell us the salmon. . . as in, he offered it at least three times, all the way through our meal.  He also kept coming back to ask if anyone needed anything  while we appreciated the attention, it was to the point where he was interrupting conversations.  I know service is a balance, and lack of attention isn't good either, but it would be helpful to read the patrons body language a bit better. We were very excited to try out this restaurant and came for dinner. The place looks nice and intimate. And the service was very lovely. The only thing negative was the food.
