My husband had the chicken, it was undercooked. I had the air dried beef; i found many pips. Then we ordered the fig & chocolate dessert (with peanut butter). It was way too salty! It's unlikely we would come back After walking  miles around the city, and desperate for a delicious cocktail and some appetizers, we stumbled upon Verbena in Russian Hill. Nestled amongst many other restaurants and cute shops, this was a great find. The cocktail list was of the savory nature, so my husband thoroughly enjoyed a old fashion. The bar tenders take the care and precision of making cocktails like a high end speakeasy. The bar is complete with hard to find liquors and a thoughtful wine menu. The JK Carriere Rose was the best Rose I have had, highly recommended. Since, we only had appetizers, we don't have a ton to go on, but the breads were delicious, and the shishito and padron peppers in an Indian curry with cow peas were scrumptious. Just watch out for those hot peppers every once in awhile! I love small plates when they're tasty and appropriately priced.  At Verbana, most of their entrees are small plates that sell at entree prices.  Nothing we had was better than average.  I live in the neighborhood and was hoping for better, but we won't be back. wow. the food here is just amazing. we tried a few items originally but after a few bites, we went ahead and tried everything on the menu  the food was just that good. i have absolutely no complains on the food. amazing and delicious. classy, clean decorum, good atomsphere. be warned though, even with a reservation we had to wait an extra  minutes. . not sure if it was just the day we went that had this issue. . ? but the place is small so it really depends on other patrons leaving in order for you to get seated. but notice that even with the wait, im giving this place stars because the food is really just that good. I dunno if others have found the customer service here to be as terrible as I have, but both times I've tried to give this place a shot they've done something to completely make me not want to ever go there. Latest example: I went there today with my girlfriend's parents who are in town. We get there at : and the front door is closed/locked, but there are clearly people in there. One guy comes to the door, opens it a peak, and I ask if they're open. He says, "sorry but we open at :. " At this point it's  minutes to : and there are clearly people in there. I sit there dumbfounded and say, "isn't that like five minutes from now?" He says "yes" and then closes the door in our faces. We proceeded to cross the street and go to La Folie Lounge, which was delicious. Screw you Verbena. Bring back Rex Cafe. I've been on a new restaurant binge lately, from Urchin to Aveline to Alta and I think Verbena so far has been my favorite because the food is really unique and executed perfectly. Verbena is a beautiful, modern restaurant perfect for a date  upon opening the heavy doors I was shocked at how empty the restaurant was on a week night. Opentable reservations were easy, and similar spots like  are always packed. Verbena serves various dishes which are meant to be shared, they recommend two plates per person although some items are bigger than others. * FIREBRAND BREAD ($)   STARS:Served with Verbena butter. Firebrand is a bakery in Oakland, Verbena serves  pieces with their own Verbena butter. I wouldn't say the bread is especially unique, but I love carbs in most forms, and I loved how fresh these thick cut slices were, and how it was slightly sour and served with a very soft whipped butter topped with large flecks of salt. I would encourage you to get it if you're looking to fill your stomach because the recommended two plates per person was not enough for me. * TOMATO AND FENNEL ($)   STARS:Seaweed cashew tonnato, lobster mushroom & saffron vinaigrette, rice cracker. I'm not sure what I was expecting, but I typically hate anything with saffron (tastes like betadine to me), but this had a really light and unusual tasting dressing, heavy on the seaweed flavor. I didn't taste the lobster and I almost broke a tooth eating the rice cracker, but it was a very interesting take on a tomato salad. If you like seaweed and tomato I would recommend it, the tomatoes were incredibly fresh, but $ seemed hefty for a glorified tomato salad. * SHISHITO AND PADRON PEPPERS WITH OKRA ($)  .  STARS:fresh cow peas, fermented lime mayonnaise, curry leaf. This kind of reminded me of Spanish tapas, it was creamy but very flavorful. Like every other dish it was a combination of ingredients I've hever had before and I wanted to lick the plate clean. I wish the portion size was bigger. . . * SHELLING BEANS ($)  .  STARS:sunchoke peel dashi, duck egg, chanterelle. Beautiful dish of a large, slow poached duck egg topped with flower petals, and served on a bed of large beans. It wasn't salty enough for me, and it would have been infinitely better with meat, but the duck egg was cooked to perfection. * GRILLED SQUID ($?)  .  STARS:Served with squid ink compressed watermelon (didn't really taste the squid ink). This was nice and refreshing but kind of pricey for the portion size. The squid was on the fishier side and I think needed to be grilled longer to get the edges burnt. * FIG AND CHOCOLATE ($)   STARS:Peanut butter cookie milk jam, fig leaf chocolate ice cream. Milk jam apparently is a caramelized milk, then mixed with crumbled cookies. It is served with their homemade fig leaf chocolate ice cream, which is made by infusing the flavor of the fig leaves during the ice cream making process, then straining them before freezing. The chocolate ice cream was really smooth, rich and decadent and paired well with the thin buttery PB cookie, and milk jam is just a genius idea that topped it all off. Really good but I wanted more!Overall great date night place, really unusual but interesting dishes. Their menu is seasonal and changes often  would definitely return to try other things! Absolutely amazing!  We went here for brunch after we discovered that Sean Baker, the chef at Gather, is now at Verbena.  We had the squash and potato, mushroom and corn frittata and red corn pancakes.  Everything was superb!  The flavors in the squash and potato were what I would expect from food prepared by Sean Baker  incredibly flavorful, creative and innovative.  The mushroom corn frittate was very tasty.  The red corn pancakes were the best pancakes I think I have ever had.  Five stars!! Another solid meal at Verbena. Must haves:sprouted breadShishito pepper and padron pepper with chickpeaAvoid:Watermelon and squid with senise pepper, tomato vinegar, garum, mint  the squid was a bit fishy and the grapes and watermelon a bit too sweet and too strong,  overpowering the squidOK:Air dried beef with eggplant tartare smoked zinfandel grapes, cress, grilled bread  nothing to brag about. so so. the grapes are too sweetI feel like that the chef should bring back more vegetables from the garden, which are the best on the menu. I know how quickly I write off starkly negative Yelp reviews when I'm looking at a popular new place, so I'm a little leery of writing this. . . but my goal is simply to be honest and balanced. Ambience: .  stars  while becoming over done around town, the Edisonian lights, muted wood and earth tones work well here with the lofty ceilings and intimate table seating.  Food: .  stars  neither myself (vegetarian) nor my wife (omnivorous) gets what the hype is about.  our seeded bread was indeed tasty, but the tomato and fennel tripped up by a strange, almost repulsive sauce.  could be us but the ingredients were not complimentary.  i found myself wishing the succulent heirloom tomatoes came sans appetizer with only a pinch of salt and pepper.  We found the this year's shelling beans to be interesting and comforting but not "transcendent" or however the waiter described it.  My wife had the salmon and thought it good not great.  As a vegetarian, I had my entree self selected, the corn creamed in carrot juice, and really found the small sampling of side vegetables to be entertaining for but a second and then wondered what had happened to my $ and when was my entree coming.  Service:  stars  generally attentive, our napkins were folded two out of the three times we left our seats.  the staff were frequently present but didn't intervene at all the opportunities (e. g. cocktails drained, time to represent a menu or inquire about another desired drink) which is not too much to ask for this level of dining or this small a place. Overall, I'd head up the street to  instead in a heartbeat. . I'm not quite sure how this place only has  stars. We had  dishes, and I was shocked at how flavorful every single one of them was. Especially the salmon. Stop reading this and order the salmon already. The service was impeccable. I had told our waiter that I had a food allergy, and even the food runner was aware of this, confirming that each dish did not contain the allergen. This might be my new favorite spot in SF. I'll be back soon. Hue L. , our NYF, and I had our "monthly" dinner here last night.  PM reservations on a Friday night. We were a little late because parking is a b*tch in this neighborhood.  Although, technically, we were late mostly because we left late.  We actually found parking a couple blocks away within   minutes.  Just lucky, I guess. The place was packed when we walked in, but we were seated after a couple of minutes.  There were two vents under the seat where our NYF was sitting.  She was wearing a dress, so the hostess offered to turn down the air, so the vents wouldn't blow up her dress.  That was very considerate.  Our NYF mentioned later that one vent was blowing cold air and the other vent was blowing hot air, so it was an odd feeling on her legs during the meal. Our waitress recommended we have about   plates per person, so   dishes.  It seemed excessive, but she should know best, right?DRINKS:  Our NYF and I both ordered the Via del Rio  watermelon mezcal, cilantro, citrus, pineapple.  The watermelon drew me in.  It was tasty, but I couldn't really taste the watermelon.  It definitely had more of the citrus / pineapple taste going for it.  Hue L. ordered the Ruby Sour  bourbon, lemon, bitters, port  which he didn't say much about, so I can't give you much of an input on that. FOOD:  We decided to go with  dishes to share.  Tomato and fennel (seaweed cashew tonnato, lobster mushroom & saffronvinaigrette, rice cracker).  Basically a tomato salad.  I'm not the biggest fan of tomatoes, so it wasn't my favorite, but it was very flavorful and I liked the lobster mushroom.  This year's shelling beans cooked in last year's shelling bean miso (sunchoke peel dashi, sunflower hearts, soft cooked duck egg, chanterelle, summer savory).  We pretty much ordered this just because we liked what it was called.  This year's beans and last year's beans?  That's a lot of years worth of beans!  I liked the duck egg.  Oh!  And it came with sunflower petals on top.  You can eat sunflower petals!  I'm going to eat my flowers from now on when I'm hungry! ;) Smoked duck wings (strawberry early girl tomato hot sauce, last year's cucumbers, rau ram).  I loved the duck wings.  Saucy and flavorful.  Not too difficult to eat, although it's definitely finger food.  They bring moist towels to wipe your hands with when you're done eating.  Also, last year's cucumbers!  I wonder if they taste better than this year's cucumbers? Meatballs and clams in fermented green tomato broth (overgrown mareko fana peppers, new oil).  Only one meatball and clam per person, so it's definitely a small plate.  Good, but not my favorite.   Air dried beef and eggplant tartare on grilled bread (bone marrow vinaigrette, arugula). I liked this one!  I liked the toast that was covered in bone marrow vinaigrette.  I did not taste the eggplant at all, but I liked the beef.   Chicken thighs marinated in koji buttermilk (rice grits, pickled eggplant, shishito pepper, thai basil, sea spinach).  This was one of the bigger servings.  Two pieces of chicken which we cut into six pieces, so we each had two pieces.  It was very moist and flavorful.  The grits were pretty tasty as well, and I'm not a fan of grits. DESSERT:  We were totally and completely full.  We probably could've done with  plates, versus .  But we HAD to have dessert! Poached gravenstein apples, ginger custard, huckleberry, almond.  I actually liked the poached apples.  And the custard was good, even though I don't like ginger.  I liked the crunch of the almond and the sourness of the berries.  Yum!PRICE: $pp including tax/tip/drinks Loved this place.  The service was outstanding and the food was even better.  Stars for Service  I had made a mistake with my opentable rsvp and booked for the wrong night.  These guys are true professionals.  In a booked restaurant on a busy Friday evening, they managed to find a place for my party of .  Bravo fellas. . . . bravo!Food  flavors were interesting and unique in a lovely way.  I have found that with so many new places popping up all over SF, sometimes, the creative food can be too out there for me.  That was not the case at Verbena. .  stars  Chilled frog skin melon and eggplant soup  a nice start to the meal.  It was a bit sweeter than ideal for me but I still enjoyed it stars  Pink pearl & gravenstein apple with cucumber  nice and refeshing. A charming balance of sweet, tart, and nutty.  stars  Smoked duck wings  now this one was my absolute favorite.  Top notch and wonderfully unique flavors.  stars  Meatballs and clams in fermented green tomato broth  this was nice but I did feel the price was a bit steep for how much food was presented.  stars  Fort Bragg king salmon  this one, though likable, in my opinion it paled against the other items. Overall, really enjoyed it.  So happy they took over the space and can't wait to return. Met my meat and potatoes husband here for dinner.  He arrived first and was grumpy about the menu, it is not very extensive and is a little challenging.  But we ordered all vegetable dishes and loved everything, both of us!  The cocktails were good, the service very nice and the setting homey yet rustic, modern and  attractive.  We'll be back! Warm atmosphere, very friendly service. Had some wine and appetizers at the bar. They were super nice. The menu has a lot of unusual choices. The food is meant for sharing at the table. We tried many thing and the quality is excellent. Portions are small, bit good. The bread with seeds is an option to order and it is great. Meatballs & clams, chicken, green beans, hen etc is some of the items that were good. It isn't cheap, but what is in SF. The service was exceptional. Rachel really knew the menu.  The chocolate and fig dessert is excellent. The menu changes and isn't very extensive. The four of us went ahead and ordered the entire menu minus   dishes that didnt sound appealing to the majority. Everything we had was pretty good, as we progressed into the night the dishes definitely got more impressive. I enjoyed the fried chicken, they warn you that it might seem a little undercooked/red (considerate since once of the girls was preggers) the way they prepare it but it was DELISH and seemed fine!Typical dark/romantic vibe that you often see in SF ( for example). . overall no complaints.  Only  star missing for the fact that you had to order bread. . and I think it was pretty basic for $.  Also some of the starters were good, but not  star quality. . .  is still solid/repeatable though! :) I live around the block and was very excited to try out this restaurant.  I was blown away by the service and expressed as much  our server, Rachel, was by far the most attentive and knowledgeable waitress I've encountered in a very long time and it made the experience that much more delightful.  I joked early on that my gf is a super taster (which is true) and Rachel immediately understood and pointed out specific dishes that wouldn't overwhelm her taste buds.  Which was precious.  The great service extended to the rest of the staff as well, refills were prompt and everyone wore a smile. As far as the food goes, the menu is ever changing and loaded with fresh combinations of ingredients.  I thought the duck wings and meatballs were particularly tasty. The atmosphere is another plus  it's refined yet unpretentious with a lot of wood and exposed brick behind the bar. I really enjoyed Verbena for a friend's birthday brunch. I was a bit dresses but didn't feel overdressed with it's classy, upscale ambiance. I ordered a mimosa and it was so tasty. I think the minty leaf makes such a difference in making the drink so refreshing. All three brunch dishes were fabulous ordered the French toast which tasted very different from most French toasts I've had in the past it's actually the best I've had (I may change my mind after my brunch at Nopa next week). The egg dishes were a great compliment to the savory French toast. Can't get enough of Verbena! I've never been there for dinner, but it is one of my favorite places for brunch in San Francisco. All the dishes are well executed and have incredible flavor. We shared the French toast, with figs, hazelnut crème fraiche and mint; and the guinea hen boudin blanc, accompanied by perfectly fried eggs and potatoes.  Their menu changes often, so there is always something new to try. The red corn pancakes have been on the menu the last couple times we've been and they are pretty fantastic as well. Aching to try their dinner menu, will be back! Came for brunch , we eat at the bar and the bartender was very helpful and made some great suggestions. Even the drinks we tasty. This is a very cute place, They even have outside seating. Since we were a party of , we were able to try several dishes.  The portion size is small so great for sharing, kind of like tapas style.  Overall, everything was solid.  Very unique flavors and ingredients put together to create great concoctions. Not your typical menu items, all very innovative dishes.  They also change up their menu regularly so a great place to re visit again.  Definitely a place you should try. Came here for weekend brunch.  The space is cute and service is attentive.  I thought brunch was fine, but nothing spectacular.  There are some interesting combinations of ingredients on the menu.  I had the biscuits and sausage, which I found fairly underwhelming.  It was salty, a bit too heavy, and the gravy was not that flavorful.  The mimosas were good.  Overall, I might try it again, but I think there was just a bit too much of a "look and see what I can combine together to make a dish!" going on as opposed to thoughtfulness of what makes a dish really work. Second time there. First meal was delicious but squid and watermelon combo last night was out of this world. Just try it. The Octavia cocktail was good too. The Slovenian wine sounds interesting but just skip it. This could easily be the best farm to table restaurant in the city. It's a must try. Excellent cooking here, with emphasis on vegetables. Beautiful space. Great cocktails. Wonderful service. We had the sardines, the beans, meatballs, and the salmon. Everything was great but the meatballs were my favorite. It comes with clams on a bed of fermented green tomato sauce. Delicious. I'd love to come back and just have that dish at the bar. The food is definitely pricey for what you get at Verbena. I found myself asking why I paid so much money for vegetables at the end of the meal. At the same, my friend and I raved about how we ate the most delicious peas and carrots the entire meal. It is also a welcome change of ambiance and type of food on the divey north end of Polk St. We weren't rushed through out meal there and the wait staff was friendly and not overbearing. I made it back to Verbena last Fri night to grab dinner before a movie. We had an early reservation at :pm and the place was pretty quiet when we arrived. Again, I couldn't help but notice the airy and well designed interior and got to enjoy it more this time with a table inside. For eats we ordered the Firebrand bread ($), tavera beans & plum ($), meatballs ($), Chicken thighs in buttermilk ($) and rose ($/glass). Our server was super friendly, attentive and confirmed that we made some decent choices. After training for a / marathon, my husband was famished and tore into the bread  it really was quite good with shaved salt and butter made in house. Worth the additional $ in my opinion. I saw the seeded bread at the table next door and it looked pretty darn delicious too. Anyways, on to the other plates! The beans & plums were fresh and well presented. It felt good to balance out the meat dishes with veggies. Nice, but not a standout dish. Speaking of standouts  we were blown away by the meatballs. They were tender and flavorsome with hint of spiciness. We learned that they're made of chicken, bacon and pork belly. How can that not be amazing?! To wrap up, the chicken was delicious, crispy with a creamy texture. I really like how it was presented with two thighs and two sides of grains  perfect for sharing. We didn't love the grains, something about the flavor (maybe the hazelnut miso?) was a bit overwhelming. Once we were on our way out, the place was popping with people sipping drinks at the bar and practically every table was bustling. Definitely recommended for a date night or catch up with girlfriends. I'll be back to try more dishes soon! Came here last night and was pleasantly surprised as the previous place at this location was a flop.  Ordered the Seed Bread, Tomato and fennel, Squash and corolla potato with pumpkin seed milk, Meatballs, and Fort Bragg king salmon  more than enough food for  people.  The food was good  simple flavors, and nothing too over the top.  All in all, very filling our eyes were bigger than our stomachs.  The waitstaff were VERY accommodating and served us even after the kitchen was technically closed (:pm).  Our server also let us try a couple different wines before we settled on one.  The decor inside is great  slightly more upscale but (like the food) still simple and not over the top.  All in   stars for great service and ambiance.  The food is very good, though slightly underwhelming for the price given the abundance of great dining choices in SF.  I would % come here again good date spot or place to grab a drink a few food plates. I think I could give this restaurant a five star, but I reserve opinion  until I  have dinner there.   Today for first time, we visited Verbena for brunch.  Even though we arrived  late, after pm, we were welcome!   The food was superb, and so was the service.  I never had a better frittata.  It was presented  in such artistic and way too!  Every bite was a delicious delight!  My husband had the pork belly and egg sandwich.  Unique and delicious!  I don't know where they get their bread, but is is superb!  We are looking forward to a dinner at Verbena, next week.   We don't want to wait too long, this place is great!  Well done Verbena! this highly anticipated new dining place was a bust. . sorry to say. Verbena looks great yet simply does not deliver great tasting cuisine. The salmon and chicken dishes were undercooked. Sure, the place is beautiful and well appointed with mod wood and a slick bar. Yet again, the food is not indicative of Verbena's appearance. Too many other places in SF that seriously rival Verbena. Cheers,Sam I enjoyed the dining experience at Verbena, as everything is professionally prepared and the service staff is great, but the food simply wasn't that appealing to me.  Perhaps it's a matter of personal taste, but I don't understand what everyone is raving about  the flavors here are kind of weird and weren't the type to "grow on me".  The duck wings were the only thing that were very good.  Watermelon and squid was alright, while the meatballs were very odd tasting.  The chicken thighs were decent but again, contained odd flavors that I wasn't a huge fan of. Great food, cocktails, and service!  All I ate were vegetables, and it was super tasty, and I was stuffed.  My carrots tasted like. . . BBQ ribs?  They were really "meaty".  And the bread made completely out of seeds  I've never tasted anything like that before.  Everything was fantastic.  Our server, Becky, was so super nice, and very accommodating.  I told her I was vegan, and she didn't even flinch, and knew exactly what to order and what to modify (if necessary).  She even brought me a cherry sorbet for dessert, and told us about the farm where their veggies come from.  Delightful!  I will be back, a lot. I cannot say enough about this place.  So, I have always been the one to make fun of vegetarians, but I could totally live the life if my food was as inventive and tasty as this place.  There are meats on the menu, but their true talent is with vegetables.  Service was attentive to detail and very good.  Chef Baker stopped by the table twice to answer questions and even brought us a dish to try.  What a wonderful experience for our group from such a talented individual.  I can also say it is the first time I have had cucumber and tomato for dessert.  We ate every bite. Came here not sure what to expect, and left feeling lucky that we had "discovered" this little gem. The food was beautifully presented, combinations of ingredients masterfully blended, and each dish was a creative artform. We shared each dish, everyone a winner, and must say the Meatballs Mole was especially creative, and could become addictive. The Popcorn ice cream dessert was WONDERFUL. We will return. Norma S This restaurant is named as one of best brunch places in SF. We came here on a Saturday for brunch with high expectations, but I was not impressed by food, but impressed by the interiors: earthy, exquisite, and yet low profile. We ordered pastrami, pancake, and scramble eggs. I've eaten at Verbena several times now for dinner and for brunch. Each experience has been delicious and satisfying. The staff is excellent and takes care of every detail. The decor and ambiance both earthy and elegant, by favorite combination. The food is unique, creative, and most of all delicious. Sean Baker creates divine dishes out of simple ingredients. . . his genius shows on the plate. He is a master with vegetables but there is so much to like on the menu including fish, meat and poultry. My favorite right now is the green beans with cherries. . . but that will change with the seasons. Just go. I've eaten at scores  of restaurants in San Francisco over many years and this was one of a very few times I ever sent food back and certainly the first time I ever got in a polite disagreement with the staff about whether  chicken was cooked sufficiently for the diner's taste .   What was served was both cold  and very red (bloody) at the bone.  I know what juicy looks like and I know what undercooked looks like. We were told by the server that  this red flesh was either the marinade or the brine; yet the outer flesh was not red in the least.  The most incredible moment was some  ten minutes into this topic with staff when my friend's meal was  already eaten and when the manager (?) finally came and took the uncooked chicken back to the kitchen.  She finally returned to tell us that the chef had confirmed it was properly cooked.   The evening felt a little like a skit from SNL.  The salad was OK. Awesome, innovative food.  It kind of reminds me of a less rich and heavy version of TBD. The design is kind of subdued and minimalist.  It can have different vibes depending on who's in there. . . Sometimes  really quiet and feel like a fancy upscale place, and then sometimes more bustling and lively and more casual feeling. Either way, always some delicious, interesting dishes you can't find elsewhere. The service was great and the decor pretty, but our waiter guaranteed us the best meal of our lives and this was far from it. Everything was very fresh and flavorful, but the combination on flavors felt sometimes like a stretch. Oh and the duck wings were waay too salty. This place was really great, we came here on a whim when another place we planned on eating at was too long of a wait for some in our group.  The bartender was extremely nice and gave one of the people in our group a new glass of wine when they did not like the original glass they ordered.  Our waiter and manager were very helpful in dealing with a food allergy in our group and offered to make items off menu as to make sure there would be no problems. Additionally, our waiter was hilarious and made the whole meal more entertaining.  Just about everything we had was amazing, they pickle and ferment a lot of items and put some combinations and flavours together that none of us had really tried before.  This is a restaurant for sharing and most of the plates are on the smaller side.  We were all very satisfied by the end of the meal.  It is not the cheapest restaurant in town but the ambiance, food, and service were all fantastic. Came here for brunch on Father's Day, and it was INCREDIBLE. The service was amazing, and it was just a wonderful experience all around. The red corn pancakes, porcini and pastrami with friend eggs, and the poached eggs over kale and pancetta were all to die for.  The Verbena mimosa is also delicious. I can't wait to come back. Food here was surprisingly good despite the menu (didn't really contain my favorite foods).  Came here with a group of  girls and we left spending about $ a person WITH drinks. We went family style on everything and it was a great value and food was definitely an improvement over marabella.  Would return. Impeccable service, great vibe (somewhere between laid back and nice date spot), fantastic food. I generally don't like to repeat restaurants, but I came here twice in one month, once for brunch and another for dinner, and loved both meals. THE COST: About $ for  drinks,  starter,  share dishes, &  dessert. A very filling meal for two. MUST HAVES: Green beans & cherries, Meatballs in Mole, Chicken thighs!COCKTAILS: yelp. com/biz_photos/verb…* Emerald Remedy # (gin, pimm's chartreuse, celery, lemon. $)   starsI told my server I like something well balanced with tart flavors. He went straight to this one, which hadn't jumped out at me when I looked at the menu at all, but I trusted his recommendation and this was perfect for me. * Octavia BLVD (bourbon, gran classico, amaro, orange. $)   starsNormally I find these old fashioned type drinks too strong, but we were both surprised that this had a fairly strong citrus presents that balanced the boozy taste really well. DINNER: yelp. com/biz_photos/verb…* Firebrand artisan bread (verbena butter. $)  .  starspic: yelp. com/biz_photos/verb…This would be great as free bread, a soft sourdough that serves to soak up the sauces really well, but since were were paying I expect something much more amazing. * Seared squash (penelope peas, vadouvan squash flower sauce, last year's Manzano peppers. $)  .  starspic: yelp. com/biz_photos/verb…A rather visually stunning dish, but I found the squash to be undercooked and too hard. The peas were really fresh and the sweetness and slight crunch went well. My friend didn't think the squash was undercooked and enjoyed this. * Green Beans & cherries (charmoula, black walnut yogurt, black olive honey. $)  .  starspic: yelp. com/biz_photos/verb…Doesn't look very impressive, but this was really, really good. All the different types of peas had slightly different tastes, and all were fresh and crunchy. The olive honey was surprisingly amazing  a denser texture than regular honey, with a hint of savory. That mixed with the black walnut yogurt and the crunchy green beans was great. * Meatballs braised in black mole (hominy cooked in whey, kale. $)   starspic: yelp. com/biz_photos/verb…cross section: yelp. com/biz_photos/verb…I've never liked mole but I ordered this (somewhat hesitantly) because everyone raves about it  and they're right! I honestly had no ideas that meatballs, just as a concept, could be this amazing. The texture was soft, and the flavor was crazy intense and delicious. I loved the hominy (they use this well  it also came in a brunch dish with duck) and the texture of the soft chewy bits mixing with the cheese and thick mole sauce. I can't truly describe what made this so good since I don't completely understand it myself  just try it!* Chicken thighs marinated in koji buttermilk (sonoma grains cooked dirty, red corn & red padron sauce. $)   starspic: yelp. com/biz_photos/verb…cross section: yelp. com/biz_photos/verb…Another amazing dish! Plus this was huge, very filling for two. The thighs were perfectly juicy and tender, and WOW the crisp on the skin and its slightly charred flavor was like heaven. The texture of the soft grains was really nice and all the flavors fitted together seamlessly. DESSERT: yelp. com/biz_photos/verb…* Squash Cake (chocolate ice cream, squash blossom anglaise. $)   starspic: yelp. com/biz_photos/verb…A very intense chocolate flavor in the ice cream (which melted WAY too fast  should've been kept colder and maybe put together and brought out more quickly). The squash cake was definitely unique, its texture a little dry though I like that these were edge pieces that had a little bit of that hardness on one edge. The little drops of anglaise were a nice flavor complement as well. The worst service I've ever encountered in a restaurant a this price point. Check in host didn't know how to use computer. Told me I had no reservation. Turns out, he didn't know how to set the computer to "today" and was really saying I didn't reserve another day. Server was strange, fidgety, not knowledgeable, distracted. Felt like he was on crack. When he poured my wine, it splashed all over the place, on the table, dribbled down the outside of the glass, he didn't even seem to notice, or if he did, made no effort to wipe it up. Wine list was horrible. Not a single decent option on the menu. Food was mixed. A few dishes were good, others were boring. Food was the high point of the experience but all the other stuff distracted from it. I'd say, overall, the people running this restaurant don't know how to run a restaurant. Very solid brunch option. The menu is clever and the execution of everything was beautiful and delicious. I will be back. Went there for brunch. SoWe came with a quiet baby that slept the whole time. The head guy gave us the evil eye. Fine, not everyone likes babies. The wines, $ $ for a wine glass. I know the winery and the guy who makes itand he charges $ for a bottle and $ wholesale. So drinks are overpriced. The food, my wife had pastrami and porcini fried eggs. Which was a piece of meat, with eggs and fried potatoes. I had, fried egg and pork belly sandwich which came with fried potatoesand our friend had a frittata. The food was ok but nothing much above you making some meat, egg and a potato at home. So  people $ and the drinks were too expensive so we left quickly. So ok, but wouldn't go back. I'd simply buy crab and make crab Benedict at homealong with  bottles of expensive wine. So three starsIf you can't cook and have just sold your first startup. Well then this place is for you and  bottoms up! Can I extoll the ways that my dining experience was stellar last night? Okay, here are a few: Impeccable, attentive, and patient service. This is *rare* in SF. Rare. Usually, my feeling is that servers here have are disinterested in the customer's dining experience. My experience at Verbena was the opposite of this, i. e. , attentive, impeccable, and patient. I could have frustrated a person with ordinary patience by repeating   times that my fiancee and I were gluten sensitive.  He handled it with kindness and skill. Also, he checked on us throughout the meal and ensured that our dining needs were being met. Also, the hostess helped me right away. This is rare in SF restaurants, and something for which I am grateful. Usually, I wait   minutes for a hostess to come to the front of the house and talk to me about my reservation. As a former New Yorker, I find this to be annoying. The food! Delicious! We all relished every bite. The chef changed his creations to be GF so that we could enjoy them. Thank you! Decor  A great mixture of grounded dark, heavy furniture and spacious verticality. Teal green tiles in the bathroom are a rich touch. Letting us sit. We closed down the restaurant. The staff didn't interrupt our long sobremesa. This is much appreciated, because one of our party was in town from Spain. Good service, great ambiance, good food for about   a plate, family style  menu changes. Outdoor seating is nice. Must orders:. Meatballs in smokey delicious sauce. Carrots and Pea deliciousness (if choosing, I prefer the carrots/pea dish over the charred carrots). Mushrooms (also smokey deliciousness)Drinks are good and creative at around $Also enjoyed the sprouted seed bread. Delicious vegetable forward restaurant, that also serves tasty meat dishes. Ingredients are locally sourced from nearby farms, or gathered wild. Some of the dishes may sound like strange combinations (such as beets with strawberries, or molasses charred carrots), but are surprisingly delicious.  Be adventurous.  The duck wings and mole meatballs are also a delight.  There are an inventive selection of cocktails on menu as well.  Can be a bit tricky to get reservations, but worth it if you plan a week or two ahead.  Also, they have a new private upstairs dining room for large groups (up to ). i've had Verbena bookmarked since it's opening late last year. today i finally got my chance to check them out for brunch and my expectations were more than met. i'd been to Gather in Oakland so i knew the food would be good but didn't want to get my hopes up. in my opinion, the brunch at Verbena is better than the brunch served at Gather. i got the pastrami and porcini with fried potatoes, fried eggs and a horseradish sauce. the portion was generous and it was SO DAMN GOOD! the flavors just worked well together. my friend ordered the french toast with strawberries and rhubarb, which was also really great. i cannot wait to go back to check out their dinner. Wonderful flavors and great ambiance. Especially loved the meatballs in mole. OMG! I have been anxious to try brunch here for a long time.  It was worth the wait.  Holy cow! Nothing short of amazing.  Our waiter, a very cool guy from Australia was superb, made nothing but great recommendations that were right on point.  He was awesome!  Despite all the mediocrity that occupied this space perviously, Verbena is far from mediocre, its STELLAR!  I will be back! It was perfect to celebrate my birthday with my husband alone. Decor and silverwares were rustic and contemporary. It was a hip and yuppie San Franciscan scene with excellent service and quiet ambiance. And the best part was food; we had sprouted seed bread, duck wings, cucumber salad, mushroom & bean, meatballs and their bite sized cheesecake with edible flower pedals and fruits. . . all delicious, wholesome and thoughtfully put together. They seem to make their own variety of pickled vegetables which were served with various dishes. We didn't order the special, Kimchi tartar with squid which I wish I had. The menu changes every week with chef's favorites so be open minded. Review of bar only. Wine list organized by winery  who orders wine that way?  Especially when the wineries are rather obscure.  Totally pretentious.  WAY overpriced.  $ for a bottle of average wine? (we couldn't find a light red for anything less. )  Oh, and the waiter tried to upsell me to a $ bottle. . . Having loved dinner at Verbena, I was excited to try their brunch. I wasn't disappointed! I went with a group, so we were able to try nearly every dish. I was pleased to find a diverse cocktail and wine/beer list, just as at dinner. Although the menu was now brunch worthy with several egg dishes, it still represented what this restaurant does best  let quality, seasonal produce shine. Service was still prompt & friendly, the decor welcoming and comfortable, the noise level was moderate allowing  of us to converse with ease. Of the dishes we had, here's what stood out: the little gem with snap pea and green almond salad, the pork belly with fried eggs and english peas, the french toast with kumquat & strawberry with hazlenut creme fraiche, the cauliflower and cheddar fritatta with crispy potatoes, and the buttermilk biscuit with saugage and an herb bechamel sauce (see photos). So basically, skip the carrot pancake and order everything else! Delicious and inventive food that has a refreshing focus on vegetables. You really don't find many non vegetarian restaurants who elevate vegetables like Verbena does. Every course was creative and delicious. The atmosphere is simple, lit by the ubiquitous Edison bulbs that grade most SF restaurants these days. The one thing that took away from our experience was the service. Not awful, but definitely rough around the edges. Some plates were delivered to the wrong table, and others took very long to arrive. Make a reservation and try a plate from each section :) Would give .  stars if I could.  Came in for brunch on a busy Saturday morning and got seated pretty quickly.  Hostess, waitstaff, and bartender were all very sweet and friendly, but the service was so slow.  We waited a good while to put our drink/food order in.  Once we did, the food came out pretty quick but we still hadn't received our beverages  pet peeve. We split the chocolate granola and cheddar frittata.  The presentation was fun and flavors were good, nothing really wowed me though.  Definitely glad to have made the stop in but won't be running back.  Hoping they expand their menu, or at least the portion sizes, in the near future! A group of three enjoyed a refreshing brunch here this past weekend. The indoor atmosphere was calm and soothing, with several trees in the sunlit room. I ordered the Fried Egg and Beef Sandwich, with jalapeño aioli. Not too spicy, but was still immensely flavorful, just right. My friends ordered the Poached Eggs with Braised Duck Legs, and Grilled Boar Ham and Fried Egg, respectively. Seems eggs are part of everybody's orders. We also all shared a side of bacon, which was crispy and delicious. Even thick!Must say, they put great effort into their tasty cocktails to make them unique. Tried both their Bloody Mary and their Mimosa, and each were inventively above par. Looks like they even serve a bev called "The Gilded Lily"  too perfect! Lovely place for brunch/lunch: Warm staff with good recommendations Nice relaxing interior space Generous portions Excellent fluffy frittata Not too sweet carrot pancakes, nice nasturtium butterDefinitely would be back.  Relaxed, top notch ingredients, simple, but with an elegant finish. Enjoyed a wonderful date night with Hubby and ate about % of the menu which was DELICIOUS! The ambiance is nice and mixology drinks were a nice touch to kick off the evening! We'll be back! I really hope this restaurant stays as I know this particular location has turned so many times. Everything was totally amazing. Their seed bread is made in house as is the goat cheese. All the dishes were savory and cooked to perfection. Their dirty rice should be served as a side because it's that freaking good! There's chopped up liver in the rice and OMG I wanted MORE! Also had the asparagus and button mushrooms and they were both so good. Their dessert with the peas was daring. . . . not sure what I thought about it but it didn't stop me from eating it.  Overall this place is definitely worth giving a go. Their cocktail menu is just as amazing. Do I remember all the drinks I had? Nope because I was pretty toasty by the end. All I remember was a burnt sprig of rosemary. . . Bartenders are adorable and attentive. Everyone there obviously appreciates good food. Give it a go! This place is excellent all around. I ate: bread w/ cheese (i forget the name) but the bread had seeds and it was served with a soft a mid cheese and I believe pickled onions. carrots: served with a couple of different sauces, delicious. squid with asparagus and ink: served chilled. delicious mole pork meatballs: I love me some mole! mole mole mole !All paired with excellent selection of wines.  Only downside is that there are more options by the bottle. .  starsreally beautiful restaurant, exceptional service, stellar food.  price point could be better. standouts:beetslamb sausagekoji chickenchocolate dessert with nettle ice creamwith all the new california small plate type restaurants popping up (Alta CA, Stones Throw, etc), it's easy to be underwhelmed by the similarities.  this one definitely stands out, a must try. Wow we were really impressed with Verbena!  I think Michael Bauer needs to come back  he'll nudge his review up to three stars.  The worst part, hands down, is trying to find parking.  After driving around for  minutes, we headed home and called Uber.  The restaurant was great about it  we'd kept them updated and they saved our table, which was waiting for us when we arrived  minutes late. Other than parking, almost everything was fantastic. The ambiance is delightful  rustic chic with gorgeous wood.  We were seated upstairs with a terrific view of the restaurant below.  The carrots are beautifully presented and amazing!  The meatballs in mole were out of this world.  We also loved the seeded bread (an upsell by our server, totally worth it) and the duck wings were much meatier than we'd expected.  We tried the molasses cake with carrot sorbet for dessert  beautiful and delicious.  Two minor downsides: small beer and (relatively) small wine by the glass lists.  Would love to see more; also, the coffee service was a bit off  our dessert arrived first, then about  minutes later the coffee and about another  minutes later, cream and sugar.  Overall, though, one of our best dinners out in SF in recent memory and we've already made reservations to return. At last I got to eat here and try their culinary repertoire! And what a range of flavors to sing in.  Out of the five dishes that we ordered four were excellent. Strawberry, beets in rhubarb was rich and full flavor, plus arugula was a nice touch. Same goes for squids. Excellent pairing with light vegetable aioli bed, with a bit of bite to close out the full range of flavors. Ginger bread crumbled too easy, but the flavors were astonishing with a colorful citrus sorbet and strong kick  of ginger. Swordfish was well worth the wait with a very pleasant sauce that complements the spices of the fish. Presentation was key and I would highly recommend you try this rotating menu of well though out cuisine. I can't wait to go back and try more of these culinary delights! Um, Yeah, I mean, ok,, Its good. Is it mind blowing? No.  Is its better than most?  Maybe. . . ?  Maybe+?I think the fact that Verbena has been open for how many months now? ? ?And still only has  reviews on Yelp ( with mine) kind of says it all. Its not so amazing that you go home, open Yelp, and write a killer review. But then again, you don't feel the need to do the opposite either, which is run home and write a really bad review. For those reasons, Yes, I will reiterate.  Stars. I will say the cocktail I got with jalapeno was quite good. The wine list?  It felt like i had to spend $ bucks to get anything decent and we all know that is silly. The food?The Carrots and Meatballs were yummy. The Quail was really good. The mushrooms and the Trotter thing were just ok. Service was attentive.  Maybe a tad overly attentive, but I'll take it over rude or non existent. Will I go back?  Sure.  When?  When somebody else invites me. Not rushing back on my own. Went back a second time and glad to say still as impressed as the first time. Food fresh and creative and absolutely delicious.  Excellent service also.  Look forward to our rd time in a few weeks. Had a great date night here, very welcome addition to Polk St. Only "miss" was the squid dish. Loved everything else. Edible Art.  It was date night, and I couldn't have asked for a better vibe or a better meal.  The decor is sexy, the staff were super attentive and friendly, and the food and cocktails were delicious.  Seed bread, carrots, beets, gem lettuce, brassicas.  All excellent.  Great vegetarian meal. We had a late brunch, and opted for the bar.  Everything we ordered was delicious, and I don't do brunch, typically.  I like lunch. Anyhoots, we had biscuits & gravy, broccoli frittata and trotter terrine and drinks, duh. Perfect portions for the three of us, and the bartender was training new employees he was patient, funny and kind to the newbies, which I loved. This is a very well run, comfortable place. Inventive dishes in small portions. #sanfrancisco #restaurantreviewIt's difficult to share these plates with more than another person. The portions are, for the most part, quite small. If you're in a sizable group, you'll definitely need to order multiples. The meatballs in mole sauce and the duck wings were great. Nice selection of vegetarian dishes. Try the carrots! They're smokey and taste like sausage, in a good way. Cool, modern vibe. Great service. Full bar and good cocktails. Service was friendly and attentive, drinks were unique and tasty, food was flavorful and multi dimensional! Amazing selection and quality! Highly recommend for a new ish restaurant in town!

name: Beso Bistronomia
category: Tapas/Small Plates in San Francisco, CA
review_text: Great all around dining experience. I recommend it! This place is so amazing, the Fideau Negre is to die for. Great staff and really cute ambiance. I will definitely come back Wow, just wow! An awesome tapas bar, in the Castro? I stopped in with two friends and we just ordered off the happy hour menu and we all left very satisfied. Excellent service, attentive without being cloying. And to top off our meal with the churros? Delightful! I'll be coming back for more! So here's some good news. . . I *did* get my Bulgari gift bag back :)  That's great that they kept it.  Not sure it warrants another star actually, no  but maybe a sign that at least they're somewhat trustworthy? Awesome tapas! Loved the porchetta, squid ink wild rice, steak (with delicious brussel sprouts) and tons of other goodies. Also, hands down the best churros i have ever had! Besos tapas are fresh with complexity in flavor while the service is friendly and energetic. One of our absolute favorites in the Castro. As a sidenote, highly recommend the carrots. (Yelp needs to get on top of half stars  this is not a four star or three star review/restaurant. . . it's somewhere in between). Overall, it was a good experience. Our waiter was friendly, helpful and attentive, without being annoying. He was very accommodating with the wine  it's almost all Spanish wines, which I'm not terribly familiar with, so he brought over a few bottles of wines available by the glass and let me take a taste of each. The space is cool  I liked the decor, it feels homey but modern. The food was a bit up and down: Valdeon Blue Cheese: fair portion of cheese, but came with lousy bread, and not enough bread. Get better bread.  The kale, squash and apple salad: very good. It was a little over dressed for my taste, but the flavor was terrific, the portion was large, everything tasted fresh.  Mushroom Toast thing: fantastic, those mushrooms were SO good.  Brussel Sprout Special: terrible. I mean literally inedible. Overcooked, soft, mushy, soupy, salty, acidic, gross. Do not order.  Pork Belly  holy cow, fantastic. Melt in your mouth texture, delicious flavor. Definitely order this!  Garlic Shrimp: meh. This was fine. Portion was tiny,  very small shrimp. Not enough garlic flavor.  Chocolate Desert Thing with Salted Caramel: Super delicious! I'd go back. I think they're doing a good job and will likely improve the longer they are over. Except for the Brussle Sprouts. I don't know what they were thinking even serving those. YUCK. I found all the plates to be overly oily / greasy. The presentation is nice, except for the fried potatoes that would look at home next to an order of buffalo wings in a sports bar. Wines were good. Restaurant is really noisey, I guess because of concrete floors and ceiling. Over all I think there are many many more better restaurants in SF for the price. Try Contigo for tapas. OK taste, tiny portions crazy expensive. I would not go again.  Had to share a table to boot.  Spent over $ for four and still went and got something to eat at Eureka across the street directly after. What a warm and inviting restaurant.  I was really impressed by the good as well. The service was good, everyone was friendly.  The food was really good too.  I really loves the pan con tomate (which is one of my fav tapas. . . so simple but tasty), the patatas bravas and the garlic shrimp.  For our main course we had the paella which was delicious. Definitely coming back to try some of their other menu items. Amazing ambiance, as many Castro restaurants tend to have. Food that leaves a lot to be desired, as many Castro restaurants tend to serve. We ordered:  paella: good variety of shellfish (I only tried the shrimp, which were plump & fresh. ) Over salted rice, though I did enjoy the spice combination. Texture was very firm & chewy, similar to a grain like farro. Would not order again.  gambas al ajillo: too few shrimp in a portion (six. ) I'm only complaining because I thought they were very good. Liked the light wine & garlic broth. hanger steak: did not try, as it was prepared medium rare. Zero enthusiasm from his side of the table for this dish. Manchego trigal: cow's milk, hard, not too sharp. Loved the accompanying quince paste (or was that guava?) If they had a sampler of three cheeses, we would've loved that. I'd come back to try their non meat items like toast points with a mushroom medley or their fried potatoes with garlic aioli. Quite underwhelmed with what I tried, but I enjoy Spanish tapas, & I feel there is more to be discovered on Beso's menu. We had a good visit. No reservation but the hostess was helpful in finding a bar spot that worked for the  of us. We only ordered the Happy Hour items (it was snack time) but those were great and the service and attention was bravo. The fried potatoes are to be commended. SO good, I'm thinking about them now! (why do so many places serve tasteless potatoes?) I look forward to going back and trying some of the real menu items. SUPER addition to the Castro! I have eaten here twice now. Great tapas. Everything I have had here has been outstanding.  The pancetta is amazing.  The ensalada de pulpo was to die for.  It is not a cheap place even if it is tapas but for the price you get plenty of food. horrible acoustics and equally bad service with just average paella made for a rather poor dining experience. stunning buildout and furnishings and our califrito desert were beso's only saving grace. perhaps i'll lower my expectations and return to see if i was wrong. . . nice restaurant  a converted garage! go for the paella and pulpo a la plancha. YUM. The octopus and mushrooms with egg yolk were some of the best I've ever had. Would just suggest pacing out your ordering if you're not in a rush or they are almost too efficient. Love the churros for dessert too. It's not cheap but the flavors were explosive. Two words. PORK BELLY. Okay, I'll add two more. GOOD TAPAS. I think that really says everything I need to say. Great date/double date spot. Wouldn't recommend a larger group than . Nice wine/beer menu & excellent food. You should definitely try the toast point w/ chorizo & quail egg! I have to say, they nailed it with this place. I have been there a few times now and am still delighted by how all the staff make you feel like family.  Of course, the food is delicious, and the tapas style menu is perfect for those of us who want to taste a bit of everything, but don't need a pound of it. Great addition to the neighborhood! Love this new comer, just great!Walked in early for some food, greeted and seated, interesting menu, and the wines!We had a great time, the food was perfect, the wines we tried were excellent, and our server was friendly, well trained and helpful. Wonderful food and wine, come check it out. Enjoy! Must get the pork belly. The softest, tastiest, melt in your mouth piece of pork you'll ever have. Period. All around fantastic food. We had the Spanish cheese (Garrotxa), bread with crushed tomatoes and garlic (pan con tomate), chicken skewers, wild mushrooms with egg yoke, potatas bravas, and garlic shrimp. Not one bad dish. The service was top notch as well with a cool inviting atmosphere. Best tapas rest I've been to in the city. Let's face it, the Castro isn't exactly known for having the best food in the city, but Beso is definitely setting out to change that!Overall the meal was great  everything from the service, to the ambiance, to the food.  The staff is very welcoming (even got hugs on the way out from the owner) and the waiter was knowledgeable on the food/wine and made some great recommendations. In fact, everything sounded so good on the menu that we went a little crazy ordering before the waiter told us to pull back. I really appreciated him actually telling us we were ordering too much food vs. trying to just upsell us to make more money. FOOD:Montado de Atun (/)  two small pieces of toast topped with spanish cured tuna, pickled shallots, roasted tomato and an aioli . . . very fresh, tangy and deliciousEnsalada de Zanahorias (/)  roasted baby carrots, yogurt sauce, cilantro, marcona almonds, vinaigrette . . . amazing flavor, carrots are from their farm in Napa and the quality of the ingredients definitely stood outPanceta (/)  this is a giant portion of braised pork belly, we found the garlic in either the mashed potatoes underneath or the aioli to be a little overpowering, but the pork itself was delicious.  It was almost too much pork belly, I would think they should cut the portion down and make it more of a $  dish and not $.  Paella (/)  this was the star of the night!  heaping portion of seafood (clams, mussels, monkfish, shrimp, squid), perfectly prepared.  It's $ and perfect for  people, but could easily be shared with a party of  if you were ordering a bunch of other small plates to go along with it.  Definitely some of the plumpest, juiciest, sweetest mussels I've ever eaten. Chocolate Brownie + Horchata Ice Cream  I rarely order dessert out, but this sounded too good to pass up.  We weren't disappointed! The brownie comes out in a cast iron pan, piping hot from the oven, topped with homemade ice cream that was the perfect compliment to the rich chocolate brownie.  The brownie had some crispy, toffee like topping on it that added a great crunchy textural component too. WINE:The by the glass options are limited but we had one glass of white and one glass of red.  Nothing really that exciting, so I would say the wines left something to be desired. All in all a fantastic experience in a great neighborhood space.  We will surely be back to try the handful of other dishes we wanted to order. Beso is one of those places that make me regret I no longer live a block away. Quick summary: amazingly delicious food, beyond expectations service, and creative/inventive space. FOOD (for ):Olives  for $, couldn't ask for more. We definitely enjoyed the variety. Setas  wild mushroom a la carbonara!  Ok I made that up, but when you mix the raw yolk topped with pecorino with the shrooms underneath, you'll think of exactly the pasta dish. And how lovely it is!  The earthiness was balanced by the citrus nicely. Paella  generous portions and very flavorful!  The seafood was cooked to perfection (shrimp was succulent, mussels were plump, squid was tender, and fish was flaky) and the rice, oh my. Each kernel seemed to have been injected with flavor and cooked al dente. And the crispy bottom (socarrat?), wow!  Dessert was a chocolate bomb!  Forgot the name but it was the brownie with chocolate ice cream. The crispy sugary bits were a nice texture contrast and the hot brownie/ice cream gave the temperature contrast. Yum!SERVICE:Everyone was great, super attentive, and really just wanted us to have an awesome time. I ended up having a mini wine tasting because () I didn't know half the grapes, and () I wasn't sure what would go with our dinner.  Talk about service!SPACE:What can I say, I can't believe that space used to be a garage!  They did great with the brick wall, wooden beams, lighting, etc. I'm impressed. Happy they're here and can't wait to be back!  Thanks guys! Incredible food, awesome atmosphere, and the partnership for fresh vegetables is a welcomed treat. Francisco was warm and inviting. Will definitely be back!! Pleasantly impressed by Beso. In my ventures into the various Spanish/latin themed restaurants in SF, Beso has been my favorite thus far. I enjoyed the atmosphere with red brick walls, an open kitchen and great lighting. The design allows for an airier feel and date ambiance that I liked. If I lived closer I'd be back often and probably be the creeper in the corner drinking his wine, eating his cheese and reading a book. They carry Idiazabal cheese here! It's so rare for me to find a place that offers it on menu and allows me the opportunity to polish my cheese snobbery. The squid dish was well cooked and delicious and just briny/vinegary enough without being overpowering. The star of the evening; however, was the paella. More often than not I'm disappointed by different renditions of paella but Beso's was fantastic. They got that crispy, slightly charred (Soccarat) bottom layer cooked perfectly and it was topped with generous helpings of seafood. Those mussels were enormous and delicious! All in all, great food and a strong wine selection to accompany great company. First Tip: Make a reservation!This place is pretty small and getting very popular so a wait started forming soon after we arrived for our :pm reservation. Trust me, it'll be worth the extra step of making a reservation! I went with a party of  that all love to eat so of course we ordered a ton of items. The waiter had to stop us while we were ordering and tell us that we were "bordering on way too much food". My favorite dishes for the dinner portion:Setas (mushrooms) a very tangy twist on mushrooms. Must try if you like mushrooms. Pancheta (Pork Belly) So flavorful and crispy! Pimientos de Padrón (peppers) These are so classic, a must try! They are tiny little peppers that aren't too spicy but still are kicking with flavor. Patatas Bravas (potatoes) I'm not the biggest fan of potatoes because they tend to be so dry but these had a great aioli sauce which really added to the flavor. Plus they were so crispy, it really helped with the texture of the dish. Paella Probably one of the best paellas I've ever had. The seafood was so fresh and they had that delicious "crisp" from the rice. Second Tip: The Paella takes  minutes to make so order this as soon as you sit down. Trust me, you're going to want it. We probably ordered it  minutes earlier than all the other dishes and it still came out last. Third Tip: Order Dessert. . . . ALL of them, if possible! We ordered  desserts. The churros, the chocolate brownie, and the orange cake. They were all amazing! The orange cake with the blue cheese was very original and had so many complex layers of flavor. I was very impressed even though I really dislike blue cheese. The brownie was probably my favorite as it was crispy but still gooey in the middle. One of the best parts about this place is that they are fast. The first dish probably came out  minutes after we ordered. Also, the service is fantastic and all the waiters that served us were really friendly and helpful. I love tapas, but I usually think most tapas places are overrated or overpriced. Beso was a pleasant surprise. My date and I were able to walk in and were seated right away at the bar overlooking the kitchen area. I love the open kitchen and rustic charm of the restaurant. The ambiance was great and not too loud  perfect for cozy date nights. Our waiter recommended   tapas per person, so we ordered a few dishes to share. * Jamon Serano charcuterie platter* Chorizo con tinto* Patatas bravas* Txipirones  Seared squid* PancetaThe portions were a good size and we were full by the end of the meal. My favorites were definitely the Txipirones and panceta. The squid was grilled perfectly, with a nice char and tender, chewy bite. The panceta was AMAZING  super tender, with a lovely crispy skin and I loved the apple and vinaigrette. I'd come back just for this dish alone. Overall, great service and good food. Would definitely come back. Beso didn't disappoint.  I am a big fan of Bisou, its sister restaurant, in part because of the delicious cuisine and boisterous environment and also in part because of the gregarious host/owner.  Beso has that same energy when you walk in, he has translated that element into this inventive tapas restaurant quite well while forging a new identity in both cuisine and decor.  Dim amber light settles in against the electic but elegant array of red brick, marble, and brown wood creating a warmth and soft tone.  This is in contrast to the buzz of activity as waiters rush past you with sizzling caliente plates and fresh frias plates.  We enjoyed pretty much everything we tried:   Aged Manchego Trigal (cow's milk, hard, tangy, intense, sharp, citrus)  quite good Montado de setas (toast with wild mixed mushrooms, grated tomatoes, goat milk cheese, pinenuts)  surprisingly served cold but quite flavorful nonetheless Ensalada de zanahorias (roasted baby carrots, labne yogurt, marcona almond, cilantro, avocado, citrus vinaigrette)  a standout because of the savory carrots Chorizo con Tinto (Seared fresh chorizo, sunchoke purée, baby bell pepper, red wine reduction)  succulent sausage with perfect accompaniments Patatas Bravas (Fried Yukon potato, spicy tomato sauce, smoked paprika, confit)  a staple tapas dish and done well, reminded us of the flavors of BarcelonaReally well done, not a single complaint.  Service was exceptional and food came out seemingly instantly, without a drop in quality which is impressive considering how busy they were.  Highly recommended. Some of the tapas we had tonight were a twist on originals, nice surprise! Service was fast and friendly, the kitchen was jammin', and we were outta there in  minutes! Dimly lit, wooden tables, an open kitchen all give this place a warm, family dining room vibe. We started with the aged Manchego trigal. Que queso! Creamy, not too sharp, accompanied with grapes, bread, and lil' chunks of guava jelly. Yes, yes please. Patatas bravas: they did them justice. For a second I was transported to Barcelona. Fried potatoes mounted on a bed of salsa brava, topped off with dollops of garlic aioli. Rico. Ensalada de zanahoria: this carrot salad ba lew my mind. Cilantro, Marcona almonds, labne yogurt, avocado, roasted exotic baby carrots, and citrus vinaigrette. Gwow, mama. Gwow. Lovely Spanish restaurant near the heart of the Castro. We went on a Sunday evening and had OpenTabled a pm dinner reservation, and good thing because the place was packed! Server said it's been like that since they opened six weeks ago. From the rustic sign out front and open entryway, to the different kinds of tables and booths and wine collection that makes up one wall in the back, I felt a lot of care went into creating an exciting space, while being approachable and intimate. There was a robust enough tapas and other Spanish dish menu, though not the typically overwhelming selection of tapas that you sometimes see. We passed on the seafood paella for two, and instead opted for sharing five dishes between the two of us. The chorizo iberico was delicious if you like cured meat with a ton of flavorI have to have patatas bravas any time it's on a menu. While this was doused in red and white sauce, it was still crispy and I could have ordered another oneThe cauliflower dish was good  can't really mess up roasted cauliflower but also nothing spectacular. Pulpo a la plancha was fantastic. It's hard to cook octopus well, and it came out perfectly tender and not overdone at allCarne a la plancha was medium rare as suggested, and also quite flavorful and a great meaty end to the meal. We should have just gone for a bottle of wine, but ended up with two glasses each. They have a wine list that is % Spanish, which I don't know well, but the server was great with recommendations and letting us try the glasses. I wish I remembered what they were but both on the lighter end and quite good. All in $ per person My husband and I went to Spain this past May, and ever since our trip we've been struggling to find a Spanish restaurant that comes close to the delicious tapas we experienced while in Spain. To be fair, nothing truly comes close to some of the culinary experiences we had in Barcelona, Seville, and Madrid; however, this place is the best Spanish food we have come by in San Francisco. FOOD:My husband and I ordered the following:Pan con tomate (delicious; great tomato topping, texture of the bread was spot on   stars)Jamon Serano (ok; amongst the other dishes, this didn't stand out  .  stars)Marinated Spanish Olives (as expected, nothing special   stars)Carne a la Plancha (just "ok"   stars)Patatas Bravas (piping hot, crisp outside, soft and creamy in the middle   stars)Pulpo a la Plancha (perfectly cooked octopus; loved the smokey flavor   stars)We were hoping to try the Panceta (pork belly dish); however, they had run out.  We'll definitely be back again to try this dish.  Sounds phenomenal. Of the above dishes, we'll re order the patatas bravas and pulpo; however, for the remaining dishes we'll try out other things on the menu. EXPERIENCE:The ambiance of this restaurant is very nice; love the exposed brick and pendant lamps.  The bar is also very nice.  Sound level was average; it was very easy to hold a conversation between the two of us.  Our service was also very good; the waitress was very attentive, and she was also very generous on our refill of wine (which by the way was amazing  I had the white blend and my husband had the Albarino; I preferred my wine, but both were stellar). This place is awesome.  It was Friday night, there was three of us, and we didn't have reservations.  They said it would take  minutes so we ordered wine and waited by the door until our table was ready.  After some confusion about our table, we finally got sat (right around   mins after we got there).  Our server was really nice and we ordered a bunch of appetizers and one large plate.  We were worried if we ordered the right amount for three people but he said they would bring out the dishes as they were ready so if we were hungry we could order more (I like that he didn't upsell us).  Here's what we ordered  WE LOVED EVERYTHING!$ Pimientos de Padrón: Fried pimientos with Maldon salt$ Montado de setas: Toast point, wild mixed mushrooms, grated tomatoes, goat milk cheese, pine nuts$ Pinchos de Pollo:Seared chicken skewers, pickled shallots, salsa verde$ Gambas al Ajillo: White shrimp, garlic, guindilla sherry vinegar, fresh lemon$: Carne a la plancha: Hanger Steak, hazelnut romanesco sauce, heirloom tomatoes, purple beans, basilWe literally ate every bite so we ordered dessert, imagining that it would be as good.  And it was.  I don't see the menu online but it was the brownie with caramel ice cream and the citrus bread.  Both were amazing. FOOD, SERVICE, AMBIENCE: Everything was SPECTACULAR.  Absolutely worth the  minute wait.  (Even better if we had made a reservation haha!)Can't wait to go back.  :) So close to four stars. There is a dearth of good tapas in SF and Beso is good and they'll get better. First, parking will suck. It's in the heart of the Castro and you can expect your parking experience to last longer than your dinner. Given all the construction that's been going on in the area for the last year it's even tougher. So, assuming you get in, the ambiance is bit suboptimal. It almost seems like a cellar. . . very little light, very few windows. Ceiling seems a tad low. And the floors. . . polished concrete with a pattern that can only be described as 'large blood vessels'. Hard surfaces and parallel walls (when will restaurants learn?) means the room is louder than it should be. OK. On to the food. This is the good part because the food was very good. We're both big lovers of patatas bravas and these were good. Crisp and a great sauce. the pan con tomate. . . good but a bit too much tomate which made them a bit runny. The lomo Iberico was very good but the portion was small and the bread needs a rethink. Too ordinary and a bit dry. The Pimientos de Padrón were perfect. The right amount of charring and the right salting. The Gambas al Ajillo were excellent. So, the food could use a touch of tuning but on the whole it was really good. Wine was fine. We opted for a couple of glasses of a recent Monastrell. The service was very good. Beso has only been open for seven weeks. I imagine in a few months this will be an easy four star place. My boyfriend and I ate here late on a Sunday. It Can be crowded and hard to get service, but only because the food really is that great. We started with a cheese plate. It was accompanied well with membrillo and fruit and the cheese was great. Perfect way to start. Advice to owner: A cheese sampling plate would be an excellent addition!We had the cumin carrot salad and it was fantastic. tangy vinegar  and yogurt combine well with the avocado and earthy smokey carrot. We also had the frisee salad with gem lettuce. Good but the carrot really took it away. For warm plates we had the garlic shrimp and cauliflower. Both excellent. The hosts are accomadating if you want more bread to soak up the juices. For dessert, we ordered something that sounded like custard filled churros, but wasn't. Be advised, the dessert that says it's churros is more like a flan or creme brulee. The couple next to us ordered a chocolate brownie with ice cream for dessert and that seems to be the way to go. Overall, we loved this place and will definitely be back for the paella, carrots, more cheese, and other dessert. If I have a food mecca, it would be Barcelona. I have never had a single bad meal there ever. So of course anytime I see a place doing tapas or really any Spanish or Catalonian inspired food I have to try it. And I try to lower my expectations. TL:RL review Good food, portions too small for the price. Opening a restuarant in the Castro is a pretty good deal. There isn't an expectation of amazing food although there is one of decor. Most places in the Castro are good, not great and that goes for Beso. Other than an overuse of Aioli in many of the dishes, the food here is mostly as good as an the average Barcelona bar except for a much higher price. $ dollars for six pieces of octopus being the worst value. The octopus was tender but could have had more char on it. The toasts were all good but so tiny. I expected  not  toast points for the price of $. Their potatoes Bravas was spot on with a good romesco sauce. Of course in Spain the portion would have been twice as large for the price of $. The food is by far more authentic and a better value that a rip off like Coqueta but still palls in comparison to the average Barcelona eatery. The service was absentee but that might be due to it being empty and early when we got there. The host said that we had a choice only of the bar and the communal table but five minutes later offered two tops to other walk in diners. We choose the bar and then got to share it with servers folding napkins and having conversations in Spanish that I guess they assumed we couldn't understand (never a good assumption in San Francisco FYI). The decor is the usual hipster restaurant style, wood everywhere, steel and concrete floor. Does not make for a quiet space.  It's wheelchair accessible, very poor light for reading or signing. Some of the two tops and the communal table are at bar height and not wheelchair accessible. Parking is horrible unless you know the side streets in the Castro. Plan at least $  per person. It's a good addition to the Castro and I'll probably be back when I am in the Castro and hungry. Tried out Beso for the first time yesterday.  Since it's relatively new, it's really busy.  We walked in shortly after pm and were seated at the bar.  Right now, it's best to RSVP if you want to dine during primetime dinner hours.  The decor and ambiance is appropriate for the neighborhood with wood and exposed brick.  The cuisine is Spanish, so there's lots of flavor with minimum spice.  We had the following: Young Mahon, Chorizo Iberico, Cojonudo, Pinchos de pollo, Chorizo con Tinto, Hanger Steak, and Panceta.  Now, that probably seems like a lot of dishes right?  Well, it's not because they serve really small portions here.  Even at  dishes, we didn't leave full.  The entree sizes are really more like appetizers, so don't show up really hungry or you'll have an astronomical bill.  With the  dishes and  glasses of wine, my bill was $ before tax and tip.  That's pricey for the amount of food consumed.  I'd recommend this place and I'll go back, but I definitely won't make the mistake of showing up hungry. We had nothing short of a fabulous time at Beso! Our very large group visited for a birthday celebration.  First of all, our server was absolutely fabulous.  He was patient with our large group arriving at different times, made sure our wine glasses were perpetually full, and ensured that our nosh was served promptly.  Since our table was so large, we relied one person to order our tapas plates. . . . we pretty much ordered the entire menu!  Every dish was presented in a lovely fashion and I didn't have anything that I didn't care for.  Highlights were:  Aged Manchego Trigal: I absolutely adored the cheese on this platePinchos de Pollo: chicken skewersPatatas Bravas:  potatoes!  Txipirones: fried calamari with chickpeas Paella: obviously I live about a block away from Beso so I've been watching construction with eager eyes. When they opened, my roommates and I wanted to drop in for dinner. I absolutely hate that any decent restaurant in SF seems to require a reservation, preferably way in advance, but we were able to get three seats at the bar really great because we got to watch dishes being made and plated. I was most impressed with the pan con tomate. Such a simple dish, but the olive oil they used with the tomato was excellent. This was definitely my favorite. I also ordered the rosemary manchego, which was lovely, and jamon serrano, which was a bit on the stiff side.  I had a Rioja red, which was nice but not the most amazing thing I've ever had to drink. My roommates had the paella I personally prefer a less seafoody paella so I only tasted the rice, which was flavorful but a little on the wet side for me. (I ate tons of and learned to make paella while living with a family in Madrid. )We shared two deserts the brownie with salted caramel ice cream (so rich and delicious) and the absolute best creme brûlée I've ever had. The ambiance was nice and the entrance in particular draws people in like a fly trap. The owner was there, and while friendly and clearly passionate, he kind of killed the magic for me he kept messing with the lights, interfering with the staff, etc. He should just let his place be the wonderful creation he's shaped without getting his hands in it during prime time.
