Cioppino was the best dish of the evening and for the price (), a health big bowl two can easily share.  Seafood was fresh ( tasted of the sea) and tender. Capesante was fantastic but for the price,  small scallops didn't warrant the cost. (). My mate swilled some Vida Rosa (which had a smoky mezcal) and Gargenga Soave, a red from Italy. Both were tasty. And for dessert:  budino, a warm apricot bread pudding with vanilla gelato, one of the best I've had. Minus one star for the uneven service. Sometimes overly attentive (getting to close to the customer is awkward) and sometimes the timing is off  getting your drink order after your food arrives. Dishes like these are best shared with loved ones.  Bundle up this winter with a visit to this fine eatery in its new home. You Have Got To Be Kidding Me.  I have paid a high price for many different dining experiences in SF, but this was the worst value. Poor service blended with small portions masked by uber rich cream sauces made for a underwhelming experience. The menu is full of dishes priced as entrees that are mere snacks with boring and expected over rich flavors. Boo. $ paid for two people to leave bored and hungry is not worth it. Find somewhere else to spend your money on better planned menus. Sterile. Flat. Expensive. Restaurant opened with little fanfare. . . . . coming into the Castro swimmingly. Once in the door. . . the ambiance and restaurant lacked character. Drinks were not as refreshing as thought. Now the kicker. . . . food. . . It didn't. Appetizers was a huge miss. . try it and you won't be able to picked up with one hand. . . bread did not hold ingredients. Should I give them time to perfect? No. . . they had no business opening if they were not ready for people paying their hard earned money into their business and the immediate neighborhood. Think twice before sauntering into Pesce. We got caught in their net. . . not a good catch. Had a Saturday brunch here with my hubby. Food was a delight. Server Gary was friendly and professional and kept our coffee full. A pleasant find. We will return here the next time in SF. PS have the Kale Ceaser. Had brunch and got the same vibe as dinner a few weeks ago. Pleasant staff and service. Food is creative and pretty good. Nice variety. Was a fan of  many years ago, and this is a nice replacement. Prices are bit high for small portions, but still acceptable I went to Pesce a little while ago when it was on Polk Street when my parents were visiting the city.  The food was delicious. . risotto . . yum, and the fresh seafood was amazing.  Our waiter was so nice, friendly and timely.  My parents and I were celebrating, but it also felt special while we were dining there.  I don't know if they could tell we were celebrating or not (we were there for a couple hours lingering with drinks) but they brought us a complimentary dessert, which was awesome! I haven't tried Pesce in their new Market Street location, but I hope they are as good as they were on Polk Street! Delicious quality brunch, just the reasonable sized amount that doesn't leave me feeling bloated.  Nice environment and good service!  That's equality as important!  Quality food and good service. So far I've only been here for brunch.  I am a brunch lover. Overrated.  Our party of four went to town at Pesce having heard good things about it and I was underwhelmed. We ate the granchio, polpo, fritto misto, cavoletti, bigoli, torta cioccolato, and budino.  Of all those, I only truly recommend the polpo because it had to be the best octopus I've ever had. . . and I am not a big fan of octopus.  Everything else was honestly mediocre.  Not sure if we'll be back. I had previous checked out Pesce in its former location in Russian Hill many years ago.  I had remembered it was quite good back then . . . I think that still holds true today. As is recommended, we ordered a bunch of small share plates and for the most part, they were stellar.  Some of the highlights: Granchio (dungeness crab tower with avocado)  beautiful arrangement and even better tasting.  One of the best dishes Risotto di seppia (squid ink risotto)  creamy and rich; another hit.  Pumpkin ravioli with brown butter sage and saba  just a touch of sweetness that added a nice balance to this savory pasta dish Capocollo Pizzette (spicy tomato, capocollo, calabrese chile)  this pizza, on the other hand, was amazing.  Simple but with surprising heat.  So good we ordered an extra one. Others dishes were just ok: Pere e gorgonzola Pizzette (d'anjou pear, onion preserve, pomegranate seeds)  interesting toppings but unlike the capocollo, this one was just ok.  Tonno (herb crusted tuna, tomato puttanesca, soffritto)  the fish was just ok but the sauce made up for it. For cocktails, the Focolare (bourbon, Benedictine, walnut liqueur, mezcal rinse) was a great drink although the Estasi (chamomile infused grappa, elderflower, cocchi, lemon, grapefruit) was surprisingly even better. Desserts were somewhat disappointing. The Budino (warm cinnamon apricot bread pudding with vanilla gelato) was better than the Limoncello cake with marscapone but neither really shined. Nice spacious location with a semi private room in back for small parties.  Friendly, prompt service and reasonable prices. Gosh, I really liked this space when it was  probably because years ago, some close friends threw a birthday party for me in their private back room. That kind of thing happens to me like once every twenty years, so I don't expect the next one until I'm eating the Early Bird Special at some suburban shopping mall chain restaurant. Anyway, I still dream about that herb roasted Fulton Valley chicken sitting on a bed of garlic mashed potatoes and piled high with Blue Lake green beans and a stack of fried onion rings (photo: bit. ly/epZiO). Delicious. I read some good things about Pesce, so Jamie W. and I sauntered over to the Castro for a birthday eve dinner here. The first thing that struck me was how loud it was. REALLY LOUD! I know it's the Castro, and they kept the bar scene hopping. But still. . . Even though we made a reservation, we were squeezed into the crowded banquette seating area where the couple next to us felt a need to hog the seating for themselves. In fact, the one who was sitting halfway into my space wouldn't even acknowledge that I was trying to get in. EXCUSE ME. MAYBE YOU CAN DO THAT AT HOME WHERE YOU ACTUALLY OWN THE SOFA. I tried to push him to his space with my jacket but to little avail. The server was no help even as other tables started to open up. Oh well, I suppose I can eat with just my left arm. Service was on the slow side as the bread finally arrived. Room temperature and rather chewy (photo: bit. ly/dEcw). The menu had a pretty standard cross section of Italian food with of course, a focus on seafood. Thus the name, Einstein (photo: bit. ly/awmUq). By this time, another nearby couple was doing the two on the couch thing. WTF. YOU WANNA TAKE YOUR SHOES OFF AND PICK YOUR TOES NOW, TOO? We decided to start with the mini pizzas or Pizzettes as they are apt to call them in Castroland. The first was the $ Puttanesca with spicy tomatoes, capers, olives and white anchovy on a puffy, browned crust (photo: bit. ly/akBCdM). It was decent enough though a bit saltier than it had to be. Better was the $ Scarola e Salsiccia which had clumps of caggiano sausage along with escarole, lemon zest and panna (photo: bit. ly/p). This had actually substance, and the lemon gave it a more refreshing taste than you would expect. Entrees were next, and Jamie got all predictable and ordered the $ Pappardelle with Braised Duck in a Porcini Tomato Sauce (photo: bit. ly/cBuSO). It was pretty good but strictly by the numbers in execution. Once again, overseasoning hindered the intended rustic flavor. It was my birthday. . . OK, birthday eve (did I mention that already?). . . so I decided I deserved the $ Aragosta, which was just a plain bowl of spaghetti mixed in saffron, brandy and tomato and topped with a roasted half lobster (photo: bit. ly/iEQWF). I didn't have any complaints about the succulent lobster, but it overshadowed the pasta which was in a pool of watery sauce with only a hint of the brandy mentioned in the description. By now, the couple next to us had left unable to disengage their mutual embrace. DON'T LET THE DOOR HIT YOU ON THE WAY OUT, BOYS! And the other couple was canoodling causing a look of sheepish indigestion on the neighboring diner. HEY, YOU CAN GET AN HOURLY RATE AT BECK'S REAL CHEAP, SWEETHEART. Why am I yelling? The place has emptied out. Please bring back . FOOD  .  stars. . . some of it is good, much of it is meh and often on the same plateAMBIANCE   stars. . . WHAT?!!SERVICE   stars. . . fairly indifferent given the canoodling that was going onTOTAL   stars. . . that chicken with the onion ring tower sounds pretty good now Pretty solid for the Castro. I do prefer the quieter vibe of the old location but really, this place is vibrant and what really impressed me is that every person you come in contact with was super polite and friendly. The waiter, each busser, food runner, etc. Crab tower: /Octopus: . /Sardines: /Whole Branzino: /Service: /What I remember about the old Pesce is that there were tons of hits but a few missed here and there. Last night was along the same lines. Only one miss that was the sardines. The accompaniments on the plate was wilted and underwhelming. But, everything else was really nice and the whole Branzino was cooked perfectly!Energetic  and a bit noisy but we can hang with that  people were having fun and enjoying their dinner and we really enjoyed it as well. Good job, please keep it up! Disclaimer: I don't have the most sophisticated palette, so maybe the quality of food at this place was beyond my appreciation. Went here for a mini celebration and figured the prices weren't ridiculous ($  ish a plate for a nice place with a beautiful, fancy atmosphere) so we tried it out. SERVICE was nice. It was crowded for a Sunday night, and we walked in without a reservation. The host was also the waiter and bartender so we were waiting up front for a few minutes, but then seated immediately at the bar because the dining room was full. The waiter seemed rushed but was still polite. I wouldn't exactly call it attentive service, though. DRINKS: We started with $ cocktails. A Farewell to Arms, I can't remember what was in it but it was fairly sweet and delicious. He had the Americano, which sounded sweet on the menu but ended up being crazy bitter. We didn't finish the drink, it was just made badly. Thought about sending it back but he didn't want to. After ordering, the waiter brought some bread on a plate with a pat of butter. The food came relatively quickly after that. SCALLOPS: I had the $ scallops, which came with three seared scallops, some mushrooms and a delicious sauce. It was a yummy dish, and it didn't seem expensive, but the fact that the dish was so SMALL threw me off. It looked like an appetizer. I was hungry when I finished and continued eating bread. PAPPARDELLE: He had the duck pappardelle, which was also a tiny dish. Delicious as well, but perhaps my palette couldn't distinguish how that tiny bowl was worth  bucks. The food was not bad, and the prices (for the quality) was not bad, but I really couldn't get over the QUANTITY (or lack thereof). We spent nearly $ on dinner and left hungry. It wasn't a good experience; maybe we will come again when we are feeling more frivolous or loose with our wallets, but the value didn't hit it home that night. Atmosphere was nice. I'm lucky I sat in the back room! I could still hear a lot ofNoise coming from the front!Service was good but a little too good at times. I felt rushed!Also, food that comes out to the table under  minutes ofOrdering, makes me believe it was sitting in the fridge. Ordered the kale salad that had some kale in it mixed withIceberg. If it says kale salad on the menu, shouldn't it be kale?Steak was good, but each bite had a lot of olive oil in it. Tiramisu was not good. Cocktails were very good!I would return for cocktails & maybe an appetizer (happy hour)I don't mind paying higher prices for dinner but I don'tBelieve the food at Pesce justifies the price. Too many other restaurants that are great without the highPrice. Overall excellent. Food, service and decor was such a huge improvement over anything that has been in this space. Only criticism is the chubby host. There were two of us, it was early and not yet busy and he sat us at a table just outside the kitchen. We requested a booth and he said that the booths were reserved for  even though the table we were being seated at was a four top. The booths went empty until just as we were leaving when he sat two separate parties of TWO. Pesce needs a new host or they'll be doomed as others in this space have been. First impressions! very rare I give a  star to places but my two experiences were so wonderful there. . I love the remodel and the upscaling they have done to the place. The staff it actually amazing in every way. they had dimmed the lights and to my friends it was too low and they turned them back up . I have not been to too many places that will do that for u . This place is maily SEAFood so do not go if u do not like, they have some dishes not that way like lamb and beef but majority is seafood and amazing seafood at that . Jessica was our server noth nights and she rememeber everything about me and one of my other freidns that came both nights, to me that is impressive. The food is mainly smaller portions ment to be shared but they also have about  dishes that r just a big plate style . which one night i did that way and had the lamb ( excellant) in every way shape and form. . . and then last night the small plates and shared with friend from Turkey. The only thing i would say is that with the high ceilings and wood floors it gets very loud in there to where u may not be able to hear people at the other end of table if u have a big group . sorta like HOME used to be before the carpeting and still how Chow is. I do hope that if u r in the area you give it a try for its great to have another new addition to the hood that is upscale and great food. . . . . . Fantastic!  Lovely, warm interior with a friendly and attentive staff.  I came early and was waiting for my friend, but they sat me anyway.  Other places would have made me wait or told me they were booked (even if half full).  They won me over with their friendliness.  Now the food. . . awesome!  They had fresh clams that were incredible.  Fresh, with just a lovely hint of the ocean.  Their slightly baked squash salad with fresh mozzarella and a sprinkling of cinnamon was incredible.  Wide noodles with braised duck in a tomato and mushroom sauce, amazing.  The noodles were like butter!  The menu changes depending on what is fresh and in season.  Nice wine and cocktail list.  Very relaxed and friendly atmosphere, with a great staff.  A bit pricey, but worth it.  We will make this a regular place. The introduction of Pesce to the neighborhood was quite refreshing as that area of Market Street leaves much to be desired in terms of dining options. Pesce (owned by the same group as Starbelly) has opened a great Seafood oriented restaurant that offers a wide variety of dishes from the Northern Italian regions.  The menu offers mostly smaller plates, but unlike most other Tapas style places, you actually feel like you're getting a good value.  The options range from exclusively Italian items (seafood pastas, mozzarella etc) to more local items like flat breads and scalloped potatoes.  They do also have a shorter list of larger entrees. The restaurant itself is freshly designed, think Restoration Hardware meets Italian Seafood!  The bar is quite nicely designed and the space feel like something you might expect in NYC. Overall having already eaten several dinners at Pesce, I highly recommend it for its consistently good food, friendly service and pleasant atmosphere.  Hopefully the neighborhood can take a few notes from these guys! Awesome brunch. Not crowded which will change very soon. Food was inventive and well priced. Good music Good bar. Coffee was so so but that didn't ruin it. Definitely check this brunch out. Good food in the hood is welcomed. Yay Superb food, drinks and service.  Well crafted menu.  Everything was just so tasty.  We sat in the cozy back dinning room.  Our waiter was professional, friendly and very knowledgeable he helped guide us thru an awesome meal. As we were leaving I did notice the noise level in the main dinning room was very, VERY loud.  I'll be sure to book the back room again. What a pleasure to have in the neighborhood.  Great food and service.  Portions are small so it can add up to order many plates, but it was quite delicious and our server Jessica was sensational. I love this place. We have been long time fans going to the location on Polk about once a week for years. We were sad to see them move from our neighborhood but happy to see the amazing new space and extended pizza menu! My faves will always be the scallops and the tuna pasta. The best best ever! Also the staff is so nice. I don't usually drive across town for a mellow week day dinner  but for the food and staff this place is worth it! Wish I had gotten in a review for the former Russian Hill Pesce ( Polk St), but I was quite relieved to know this place only moved, and did not shut down because their seafood is so delicious!At this newer location about two month ago, my date and I ate such items as sardines, baby octopus salad, diver scallop crudo, pan seared scallops and lobster pasta. Everything was tasty. I particularly liked the sardines, and the octopus  it was soft and seared, not chewy at all. Our waiter was quite knowledgeable about the menu, as well as the wine selection  his help guided us to select the Moscotto. Did have to get reservations, but it was well worth it. Delicious gourmet meal each time. Friendly service, tasty cocktails, comfortable atmosphere. Has it been perfect each time? Of course not  that would be boring, and what's more seriously unrealistic. Sometimes its great, sometimes its not. But each time, its been a fully present experience that doesn't pretend to be anything its not. And for that (and the gravity challenging deliciousness of their crab tower), I truly appreciate them. Old school Italian seafood without traditional Italian American east coast exuberance,"mezza mezza" atmosphere and service. Great improvement from Jakes, however miss warmth of , especially @ the bar.

name: TBD Restaurant
review_text: What a cute little restaurant right by the Orpheum.  We came here for a quick bite, was able to get reservations pretty last minute and the food was unique and tasteful.  We had the baker's bread because it sounded interesting. . . it was sort of like mushrooms on top of bread with some kind of sauce.  Their honey glazed brussel sprounts was good and the presentation of the tuna tar tar was perfect.  I'd definitely recommend anyone catching a show by the orpheum to come here. They also have a good yet simple selection of wine! Really nice comfortable decor. Silverware in drawers in the table a very neat concept. Brussels sprouts appetizer was delicious as was the sturgeon entree and the tuna tartare appetizer. Friendly service. Constantly updating menu: if what you see on the menu for the day strikes your fancy, highly recommend giving them a shot. Try mixing and matching from the prix fixe menu by asking the great servers politely. The menu at this place makes no sense and was super disjointed.  The tasting plates we ordered actually had good flavors but do they have to make them all with baby vegetables?  We had the Josey bread which was okay but you couldn't taste the chanterelles, the leeks which looked like  baby pieces of scallion, and brussel sprouts which were about the diameter of dimes. The kitchen then gave us a complimentary appetizer of tuna tartare with head cheese. It;s a nice gesture, but we didn't order it specifically because the combination sounds bad. Who wants a slice of fatty pork head with warm tuna that doesn't taste like tuna?Then here is where it really goes downhill. The entrees all came out and were gigantic. It's like two people designed the menu where the appetizers have to use minuscule vegetables and the second person felt bad and overcompensated  with gigantic entrees. Sure, normally one wouldn't complain about gigantic entrees but the roast chicken was an entire half chicken. My opinion is that the waiter should have let us know how big it is instead of letting us over order like that. What kind of person would actually want a half chicken at dinner? Also it was too salty.  It came with a side of bread salad that I had trouble cutting with a knife. My friend got the pork ribs and wouldn't finish them because he said they were also very salty. They were braised ribs that had a grayish sauce on them.  You know they are not good when someone can't finish ribs! Another dish was the fish over sunchokes which my friend didn't like and to me it looked unappetizing.  It was a dry looking fish sitting on top of an unidentified brown mush. The steak looked nice but my other friends said it had no real flavor. This review might sound harsh but these things are easy to change. As is, this place is a waste of time. I'll conceived menu with poor execution. Love this place! Awesome kitchen, and we prefer to sit at the bar to watch how they cook on this massive interesting grill. Come open minded to try new things. Not a full bar though. Great place.  Good food, love the style of the restaurant.  Friendly staff.  Get lots of small plates, and eat like a king! Great meal. Bright inside love that now I'm older. Nice arrangements of flavors. As long as the food stays consistent I would continue to go. Great service as well. Check menu on line it's consistently changing. good food at a fair price. upstairs seating might be a little awk but since there were only  of us, it was fine. ordered the prix fix which came with:daikon radish salad  GREATveal in mushroom cream sauce  goodpumpkin profiteroles  good Wow, great food and service!  My daughter and fiance invited us to a SF dinner. . . we went to TBD.  Since this type of fine dining was new to us our future son in law ordered family style.  Oh hooray, we get to taste the multiples!!  The appetizers and main courses were outstanding, deserts amazing!  We can't even pick one item out that was the best. . . it was all good!  Our waiters/servers were so nice.  They were there for every need.  Swooped in to grab the used plates and moments later were bringing new plated foods. The manager was exceptional, went out of her way to our request, I had asked for a certain type of beverage that they didn't have available. . . she went out and found it!  How cool is that?   It was so much fun watching the chefs prepare the food on the open fire and exciting to watch the very handsome head chef take a little taste of everything before it was plated.  So much care and detail to every dish for every patron. The ambiance was warm and inviting. . . rustic with class!  Loved, Loved, Loved it and can't wait to go back! Loved this place!  Stopped into AQ (it's sister restaurant) and the prefix menu was just  bit too pricey (it's listed on Yelp as '$' but I think it should be '$' especially if that prefix didn't include wine which I don't believe it did, but I digress) so we went over to TBD.  We were seated at a group table upstairs which was very nice and intimate, another group was there but it was not a problem.  We started with some great wine and proceeded to order a bunch of dishes for the  of us.  I believe in total we order  or  things,  entree and the rest were small/medium plates.  To me, this place would've been  stars but the portions were a bit too small.  The entree we got was lamb very good but too small for an entree.  For other plates, the highlights were the mussels, octopus ceviche, and rockfish.  The pepper with squid ink was underwhelming for sure. Overall, I loved the ambiance and we had great service, the food was fun and interesting and delicious, but I wasn't stuffed.  I would absolutely go back! Each dish was amazing. We started with warm Josey Baker bread with corn, cotijo and espelette, followed by a beet salad with grapes and walnuts just touched by a subtle fresh horseradish.  Then the heartier plates arrived: arepa (duck) with tomatillo, apples and manchego, roasted sunchokes in a red brick mole and grilled leg of lamb with carrot and mint (both part of the three dish prix fixe menu), honey glazed brussel sprouts, octopus ceviche with lime and avocado served over a very light bed of hashed brown potatoes, and finally a shared desert included in the prix fixe selection the lightest, fluffiest doughnuts resembling beignets and more than enough for the three of us.   All the dishes were amazing and made with loving attention to detail, encapsulating all the flavor a recipe could possibly have!  Read the entire review with photos at:  unhealedwound. com (October , ) Nice place, though the server kept interrupting us as we tried to talk business. Anyway, the appetizers were very inventive, though not all hit the mark.  The rice cakes were really just that nothing special, but the potato salad was excellent. The leaks were good as well. My trout dinner was okay, though a bit mushy and watery for my taste. This place was just a fun timeI walked In with  of my good friends, and we were determined to have a good time. I was a little difficult with ordering the wine and appetizers, but both the server and manager matched our energy. They even sent us a small gift from the kitchen which was extremely nice of them, so thanks. We crushed  bottles of wine, the server nailed my needy requests, and we had a big meal. All in all this place has some great food, great service, and a fun environment. I'm down to go again. The silverware is in your tables drawer! Did not know this restaurant existed! It's been open for almost a year and we finally checked it out last night for dinner. Everything started out great. They don't have a full bar but they have a couple of wine based cocktails which are pretty good. To start, we ordered the eggplant, brussel sprouts, and the octopus ceviche. These were all really good. Special shout of to the sprouts and the octopus which was perfectly cooked. We then had the venison tartare which none of us cared for. They mix raw and cooked venison and the textures were too different and we were done after a couple of bites. Then we got the porcetta, which was mostly fat, and the burger, which also tasted way too fatty. Basically, we should've stopped at the appetizers because the rest of the meal left much to be desired. If I come here again, I'll have  orders of the octopus and call it a day. PS: Great service! I really enjoyed this restaurant. I read about it online and I was very excited to try it with my friend. When we arrived we got our seats very quickly. First the lights in the restaurant was pretty bright but after  min later they dimmed which made our experience more enjoyable. They have their services (fork,knife. . etc) available on your table. Each side has their own drawers with one set of service. Such a good idea and I think it saved time too. Food was great! It was a good amount. Price was good for the service we received. I will go back there for sure. Loved this place when it opened.  Went there as much as any place in the City as a no fuzz honest interesting food at fair prices.  Cocktails made from Sherries and like were fun and service was friendly.  Chef Mark even sent us a extra dish when we shared some good wine with him.  But last time. . . they ran out of the lamb chop main course when we had a PM Reso.  They gave us some sausages instead which was a joke.  We didn't complain but that was way unprofessional.  Bauer might be right on his update this past TH.  Bummer because we really had great fun there before. I was very impressed with the ambience and the food. We had the prix fixe. The soup was great, with the right touch of the pumpkin seeds. The short ribs were plentiful and so tender atop a great grit and tomato based sauce. The peaches with farrow and cream were a great ending to this meal; light and delicious. The service was just ok. I tipped % and generally tip closer to  %. % is equal to a  on   scale. A little more attentiveness would have gone a long way. Overall, it was a great pre show experience. Great plates to order and share family style. Super easy parking on the street right in front. Had a reservation  seated right when we walked in. Great service. Will be back. I know yelp probably won't post my review because it's the first one but I had to register so I could comment on this restaurant. For a Friday night and hardly anyone there, that should have been our first clue to go somewhere else but my husband wanted to try it. First  Menu is very limited.  Unless you're going with the prix fixe menu (which hubby got and wasn't wowed with).  There was only three entrees to choose from (already made steak and roasted chicken for dinner at home this week).  So the only I got was the beet salad.   They bought my beet salad out thinking it was a side dish my husband and I were sharing.  I said that's my entree and our waitress said "oh, sorry" and just walked away.  I don't know what they did to the beets salad (mashed/mushed), but it really wasn't a salad.  Just mashed beets with spicy walnuts which the walnuts didn't even go with beets (I love walnuts and didn't even eat them).   It took another  minutes for my husband to get his prix fixe entree and that wasn't even impressive.   Long story short. . . I'm glad we only spent what we did at this restaurant.  There are to many restaurants out there so we will not be going back to this place and we sure won't recommend it. Let's start with the good: Everything except the food!  We were seated at the bar and the bartender that served us was very friendly, helpful, and charming. . She served me two excellent beers.  The ambiance in the place is neat, its got a classed up 'roughin it outdoors' kind of feel to it.   For example, in the bathroom, the toilet paper holders are made out of branchesWe weren't too hungry, so my girlfriend and I split the prix fix meal and it was plenty of food.  The amuse bouche was beet with arugula and ricotta cheese, pretty uninteresting.  The first course, yellowtail crudo, tasted meh. Next, the grilled halibut served on a bed of greens, was remarkably underseasoned, and the veggies tasted like how I used to steam them in college.  The main course, the dry aged NY steak, was undercooked (I enjoy rare, but this was bordering on purple, and chewy and dangerously close to cold in the middle).  It did come with a badass steak knife.  The meal ended on a decent note; although the dessert on the prix fixe ran out, the soft serve and smore dessert they substituted was perfectly fine. Underwhelming. . . Went to TBD because I planned at the last second on a Saturday and there were still seats available. Staff: Awesome. Decor: Awesome camp y vibeAtmosphere: About half empty on a Saturday dinnerDrinks menu: Nice selection of beers and wines by the glass (like legit selections for a beer lover, not just a couple of CA IPAs)Food: It's mandatory Prix fixe for $, which I liked. They also have a separate "bar menu" which you can order alongside your dinner. Food was excellent all around, but they serve family style, and gave us way less food than could fill us up, even with extras, drinks and dessert. st course: Shrimp ceviche  Super yummy, though  small shrimp total for our group of . nd: Mole carrots. Excellent mole, soft sweet carrots. Very tasty. Add ons: Avocado seaweed bread (so good) and padrones peppers (like small shishito, OK). rd: Pork Posole  amazingly delicious juicy pork with some incredible jus. They need to bring bread or a starch with this, so much jus and not enough stuff!th: Dessert was bowls of panna cotta with fruit / mint sauce.  stars. Extra dessert: Deconstructed s'mores. Mm. So overall, fun place for a group, delicious food, but they need to make enough food, and I'd like it a bit more lively! .  stars if I could. Overall I'm a fan of this place. The food was good, the waitstaff was friendly and quick and I liked the atmosphere. I will say though that it is important to recognize that TBD has a single prix fixe tasting menu. They can modify it for people with allergies and other dietary restrictions but it is worth looking into the menu on their website in advance in case you're dealing with just plain picky eaters or have a large group. We had gulf prawn ceviche, carrots with mole, pork pozole, and flan. The ceviche was the weakest dish but was still ok I just would have liked it to have a little bit more bold and bright flavor. Loved the carrots and mole and the pozole though I wish they had served the pozole with a bowl instead of a flat plate because I didn't get much of a chance to enjoy the broth with the pork, hominy, etc in the pozole. We also added the josey baker bread with avocado, great but the portion size was huge. Too much for two people and I wish they would offer a half size portion of it because that would have been perfect. The staff at the restaurant were great too. Very professional, friendly, and everything happened at a reasonable pace. We overhead that the table next to us was late for a reservation and had an event and asked the staff to rush the meal and it seemed like they were very accommodating to this, which is the hallmark of a well run operation because clearly those customers were being kind of needy but the restaurant staff were able to deal with it with a smile on their faces. TBD, like AQ, has changed to fixed menu for $; the price on single items have gone up ($ for Josey Baker bread!). Disappointing. Great food! Special experience! It's unfortunate that it is buried away and challenging to find because it is worthy of multiple visits. TBD is an oasis for me in the neighborhood  a place that's casual enough to walk in and perch at the bar after work, yet maintains an ambitious menu that holds up against some of my favorite restaurants in the city. They recently changed formats to a set menu ( courses for $), which lets the kitchen focus on a few standout dishes each night (rather than the broader old menu, which frankly could be hit and miss). The flavor pairings are often unique (last week: sea bass with hot/sweet eggplant, fava purée and herbs) but invariably satisfying  the portions are also more than generous. Though the bar program only incorporates wine and beer, you won't be left wanting. The wine selection is a great cross section of local and old world, along with an incredible sherry selection. Definitely worth checking out their 'loophole' cocktails as well, especially the Nogroni. Excellent food, experience, and service! I would recommend this for any occasion. The camp fire concept is also very unique. Food was better than AQ. I have been to this unique and wonderfully fresh eating establishment a number of times now, and it is my new favorite restaurant.  I love the smell of the grill as you walk in the front door.  The decor is modern and inviting all at the same time.  The manager was very gracious inviting us to sit at the bar while our table was being prepared.  In very short order we were seated toward the back, where we could watch the chef and crew prepping and grilling.  A fun surprise were the drawers in front of each diner with clean flatware for each course. . . very innovative.  Every server that came to our table was friendly, helpful and efficient, so we never had to wait very long between courses.  I felt we were consistently attended to, without anyone hovering.  The beer cocktail was delicious and unique.  I loved it.  The food was outstanding, each course more interesting and special than the previous one.  And the s'Mores dessert was the perfect ending to a incredible evening with dear friends.  I would highly recommend this casual and rare SOMA gathering place, with a most inspired menu that changes often, so there is always something seasonal and innovative being offered. Mark, the chef consistently comes up with amazing combinations that enrich the tasting experience. . . . this is a wonderful restaurant in which  to spend an evening. I've had the pleasure of eating at TBD (and their big Sis next door, AQ) enough times now to appreciate the craftmanship and care that goes into every dish prepared. Cooking indoors over a wood burning hearth is no small feat, and doing it so well, with such an epicurean aesthetic, yet still rustic and hearty is quite an accomplishment. One I have yet to see mimicked, much less equaled. At TBD, the bar has a menu apart from the rather new, fixed menu for the seated area, and both of them change quite regularly. Highlights at the bar for me have been, Asparagus with a soft Egg, Cojito Corn, and the grilled Peppers. During my most recent visit to the dining area the menu (yelp. com/user_local_phot…) featured a delicious and perfectly seasonal Watermelon and green Tomato salad, a perfectly large piece of Seabass with a fava Bean blend and Eggplant (yelp. com/user_local_phot…), and a huge portion of Tri tip crusted in burnt onion and coffee. I'm a huge Tri tip fan; coming from down the Central Coast and the rub on this one was so flavorful and unique. The service stands out in my mind at TBD almost as much as the food. It's the little things that make a difference. Such as the server being congenial and very helpful; offering to bring tastes of the available wine to make sure we enjoyed the pairing beforehand, or like when I left for the restroom and returned to find my napkin refolded in its proper place; the smaller things go a long way with me. Overall, I consider TBD one of my favorite restaurants anywhere and I can't wait to return to see what's new from the grill. Cheers!   @LeeShep I love the new format at TBD!The food is inventive, quality sourced, seasonal and delicious.  Going there is like going to a friend's house for dinner (a friend who is an incredible cook) because the food is served family style in a casual, unpretentious setting. You don't have to think about what to order and there is always an interesting mix of dishes. I am a vegetable lover and the menu offers a great vegetable to protein ratio. If you go during the summer, get the side of corn  it may not seem particularly interesting but it is! I save TBD for special occasions and it wows me each and every time.  Shoutout to JD and the staff on providing such a tremendous experience.  The wine and beer list is one of the best I've seen in the city.  Where else can you go for such an in depth variety of Sherry?  Super cool to try new things like fish baked in a special way with parchment.    Perfect place to take a date, family or people visiting town! I love this restaurant.  I went with  BFFs and we sat upstairs at the long table.  Great place to sit for group of  .  Delish and provocative weekly fixed price menu (we had seaweed tagliatelle and lamb roasted over coals, both fabulous).  One of us ordered off the bar menu and had the fabulous gems and cauliflower and Josey Baker's grilled bread  so good.  Good beer and wine selection, and, surprise, an amazing sherry selection. Ambience hip and casual.  All table were taken on a Wednesday night when we went.  Can't wait to go again with my hubby.  Convenient and EZ walking distance from Powell St BART and cable car.  We found street parking across the street. Super meal and great service.   I am not always a fan of fixed price menu's;  however, I was pleasantly surprised by a more than excellent  course meal last Wednesday.   Every bite was delicious  beginning with the beef tongue "tonnato, the seaweed tagliatelle,  the entree of roasted lamb and finally the ricotta cheesecake for dessert.   Compliments to the chef for the excellent choices of good ingredients resulting in such delightful tastes.   I will recommend this restaurant to my friends and hope to try future fixed menus. Barb P While the revised format of having a Price Fixed Menu alongside some additional selections may not be for everyone who enjoyed the "original" TBD, I think people will be very pleased. Last night we both enjoyed the set menu very much. Every piece from the Chef's amuse bouche through dessert was balanced, flavorful and beautifuly presented. In each case the chef came to our table to describe and explain the dish (classy) and the waitstaff as well as the sommelier were personable and not pushy. The atmosphere was great and not stuffy. Because the menu rotates weekly you can be assured of creative options. I haven't been impressed with restaurants for awhile. Finally, I came across TBD. The concept was fun, food was creative and flavors were bright. Service was fine. My only gripe was that we had the pork rillettes that came with very little bread. When we asked for more bread, they never told us it was extra charge. When our bill came, we were charged $ for the  pieces of bread we got. You do smell like smoke when you leave so make sure you wear something you don't mind washing. Awesome spot, so "San Francisco" and I love it. The menu is amazing and really affordable. About $ for  courses! I loved the gem salad and I can't remember what else I had because I dined there last week, but I know it was awesome. On top of the tasting menu, my friend and I shared like  appetizers  all delicious. Good spot, but definitely super loud  you can't really have a quiet, conversational dinner here. i came here w/ friends to try out their new prix fixe concept.  the food is pretty good, but it sucks, b/c they don't let you substitute anything unless you're a vegetarian.  the entree was salmon, which i liked, but one of my friends is not a salmon fan (and we had made reservations long before we found out the menu of the week), so she basically had to have the veg special, which was roasted cauliflower.  we supplemented the meal w/ the josey baker toast w/ avocado, which was superb.  they had a great soundtrack of s music playing while we dined, and we found ourselves singing along frequently. Lovely appearing restaurant, with humble food. Nicely presented and above average. Not worth the price of the fixed menu. Great experience tonight at TBD. After reading some of the previous reviews, we were unsure (perhaps 'tbd') upon making reservations, but net net, it was really a quite enjoyable evening. The food was unique and well prepared from the balsamic fig salad to the fisherman's stew ending with the tres leches. We sat at the bar and received incredible service. There seemed to be a high degree of attention and genuineness on the part of the staff. With the prix fixe menu and limited choice, TBD is probably not for everyone and likely will vary from week to week, but if you're open minded, it's a great value and well worth it. In San Francisco, we have so many choices. It's nice to sit back from time to time and be guided through a well prepared meal. I also added the wine pairing and experienced some unique vintages and varietals I otherwise would not have tried  well beyond your standard Napa Cab or Sonoma Pinot. Love the decor. The food was delicious. TBD has only been open for   months now but I believe it's set up for success. Every dish we had embodied such intriguing flavors (descriptions on the menu don't explain it a tad bit) My favorites were definitely the short rib (fell right off the bone, so tender) and the catfish with garlic. Menus change every week so who knows if they'll ever serve those again. $ for pre fixe   course dinner (no subs allowed, unless you notified them before due to dietary restrictions). Overall, super attentive service (sometimes felt a bit rushed to finish dishes though). Overheard they use sherries instead of hard liquor for their cocktails. Id be interested in trying one next time! Great Experience. You can watch the Chef cook from upstairs view. This restaurant was wonderful when it first opened. The food was good, the service was professional. We came back after few months and it was still good. However, we went there last night for the third time and the menu was completely different. Food was average, choices were very limited, and wine was forgettable and overpriced. Either the chef was on a vacation or something going on with the team. It's not what it used to be. Last night will be the last time we ever come here. I went to TBD with my family last Friday night, great atmosphere and we had a wonderful experience.  The seasonal food as fantastic and the service was warm a friendly.  So far parking hasn't been a problem, I was able to find a spot almost across the street from the restaurant. TBD changed their menu format this week from a la carte to prix fixe for $ without any choices, plus some optional supplements.  They call it a four course menu, but the second course of roasted new potatoes seems more like a side than a course, making the meal seem too expensive for what you get.  While the food was good, it was not great.  Other restaurants, such as Camino, do the open flame cooking thing better.  Also, the space seems unfinished.  We were seated upstairs in a loft with a very, very low ceiling.  The service was just ok and not very organized.  We had to ask for spoons for our soup and serving utensils for the potatoes (everything but the soup is served family style).  Our food definitely needed salt and when we asked for some, our server brought a tiny ramekin with a quarter teaspoon of salt, which seemed precious for a table of six eating the same food.  We had to ask for more, which was irritating after having to ask repeatedly for utensils.  With so many restaurants in the Bay Area, this one just does not stand out. It was girls night out and we were looking for an exceptional meal with exceptionalatmosphere.  We received both and more.  What a treat after a long work day tobe greeted at the door, seated and then from :  : waited on and servedthe most delicious courses: Cool Melon Soup with King Salmon Cerviche and almonds,Pork Butt with smoky eggplant and Bing Cherry Clafoutis.  If I only had themelon soup and the Josey Baker Bread with seaweed the meal would have beena success  but it just got better.  And the wait staff seem to really enjoy workingthere.  Very relaxing atmosphere.  They were attentive but not overly so. Make reservations you won't be disappointed.  We're bringing out husbands backnext time! I really wanted to like this place, but overall, it was a huge disappointment.  Highlights: Ambiance is great. . . mix between cool and comfort Drinks are really good and creative The food as it's described on the menu sounds incredibly interesting, but nothing wows your taste buds and perhaps I missed the memo, but there is no flow to your meal. . . plates come out at random times And if you're on a low carb diet, pray they've run out of the Josey Baker bread because they won't substitute any other bread or carb. We were served mussels, French style, in a broth. With. No. Bread. The worse part?  The service!  Be prepared to have multiple servers and to wait a very long time for anyone to check on you.  Also, if you need a toothpick, don't ask, because your server will recommend that you go two doors down to the restaurant AQ for one (I kid you not!). In their defense, the Manager didn't charge us for our meal after my friend had a heart to heart with him about the terrible service and mediocre food.  It was very generous and unnecessary, as we would have preferred to pay money for a really outstanding meal! I'm really disappointed by my experience with TBD this week. I'd made reservations a few weeks in advance for a group of  girls for an evening with a friend coming in from out of town. I tried to increase my reservation this week by one person and was swiftly kicked to the events group. Long story short, they wouldn't let us dine there unless we committed to a $/person prix fixe menu of items we didn't really want, two courses + dessert (unwanted) only,  excluding tax or booze. Zero flexibility offered. If we were a party of more than , perhaps I'd understand.  But for one last minute addition?  Not cool. There are too many great places in the city to waste time on ones that aren't accommodating. This should maybe be . . Cute, functional concept (the menu's organized according to triangle, which correlates to size/price of dish), and the campfire thing mostly worked. Food was above average, if not amazing. Only one dish (sea bass) was truly awful (fishy, overcooked, poorly conceived and executed). Lamb, steak, cauliflower, sausage, salad, etc, etc all good. Dessert ok. Not worth detailing which dishes were good because the menu constantly changes. The issue was that our waitress sort of sucked. She couldn't answer basic questions, and then COMPLETELY oversold us. You only get one chance to order here, which is odd  you cannot order and then if it's not enough food, order some more (despite the smallish plates concept). So we ordered our dishes and she told us we needed at least  more. Worst advice ever. We'd have been fine with our initial order and should've trusted our own instincts. It was a gluttonous mass of food and we couldn't finish it. And we ended up paying about $ for , and that only includes  drinks. Then, toward the end of the meal, we (for some reason) were given a different waitress. This one was much better, more professional and less shaky, but when we got our bill, she asked us to contribute to a charity she supports, and gave us the URL etc to do so. Dude! We should've just donated those unnecessary  upsold dishes to the charity. While it was cute and some dishes were quite good, I don't think I'd go back. Great food and atmosphere. I enjoyed the cauliflower, asparagus lamb And steak. And the dessert was delicious. I would order the s'more and ice cream to share!Some people called the atmosphere smoky but I disagree. It was clear and my clothes didn't smell the next day. Overall, an awesome experience in an unassuming location (tucked between th and th, next to a Subway). The food itself was great, very diverse and creative menu. It's great for carnivores and fellow paleo eaters: lots of meats, vegetables and gluten free options. One thing I will say is I wish they had more seafood options when I went! Their wine and beer selection was pretty extensive. Don't forget about the dessert they were amazing! The service was great too, not too intrusive or negligent. Atmosphere was informal and friendly we conversed with people sitting nearby. It definitely has a rustic and cozy feel, with lot of wood, open fire/kitchen and hunting memorabilia. But at the same time, it has good lighting and an "airy" and light feel to the whole place. My only minor complaint is the price per actual weight of the food, especially if you are starving (like I was before my dinner!) and want a satisfying meal. You will easily spend + for a nice meal paired with wine. But, again it's San Francisco and food is king in this town. What a treat!This was the first dining experience I had in San Francisco, and it really set a fantastic tone and standard for dining.  I found that the staff were all very friendly and knowledgeable; they answered any questions we had, and were easy to suggest drinks or make special accommodations for dietary restrictions. We had the chef's tasting menu ($ ea. ) and were provided such a splendid variety of dishes on the menu, and in such quantity that we left stuffed and elated.  Although we didn't opt for a pairing menu, the bartender was very helpful with picking out matching beers for me, and wines for the other person.  I thought that the chef, Alex, coming to say hello to us and detailing the dishes was a fantastic and intimate touch to the meal; he was very attentive and had even asked if there was anything we didn't receive but wanted to try. The restaurant had a rustic vibe, plenty of seating, and even a little spot right in front of the wood fire grill (man, was it toasty!), which provided a view of the chefs at work.  I would make a reservation if you're dining around the rush of dinnertime, and suggest that anyone willing to make the trip will not be disappointed. This was a great meal, and a great evening! You can get a similar experience by attempting to cook food over a real campfire and throwing $ pp into the flames. Yep, it's that bad. ATMOSPHERE: It was scorching hot because of the furnace, which I imagine is really cozy in the winter time. However, it was not so pleasant during one of the few heat wave weeks of the year in San Francisco. Maybe TBD could turn down the heat during those weeks? The decor is really cute, though  open kitchen, rustic tables with pull out drawers for silverware. A great place for a wintery date. FOOD: I had the charred octopus, smoked cauliflower with raisins, roasted lamb, seaweed bread, and s'mores. Almost everything was executed poorly and burnt. The octopus was. . . chewy. There's pleasant chewy, which is al dente with a little extra chew, and then there's  second chewy. This was the latter. The smoked cauliflower tasted sour and burnt. The roasted lamb was a good texture and not burnt, which was a welcome relief. The seaweed bread was hard as a fire briquette, burnt, slathered in butter, and sprinkled with nori. I like the novel combination of nori with butter but the bread itself hurt my gums. The s'mores were tasty but nothing revolutionary, just the flavors of the classic campfire snack broadly reimagined as a fancy chocolate cake.  The fancy TBD s'mores are all one texture: finely ground graham crackers, finely sifted chocolate, finely emulsified marshmallow. I would've preferred the real textures of s'mores, or at least s'mores fondue. BILL: For a drink and a few dishes shared with my dining camp anion, it was about $ per person not including tip. The waitress said we ordered on the "light" side, too. Wow, that was a lot to eat some charred food in a sauna. For the record, I love sister restaurant AQ, so I really wanted this to work. Sorry, AQ, for the blistering review. If this cost less than $ for me and my partner, I would've given  stars for ambience and service. The food here, as others have commented, is too creative for its own good. Some too bland, some too salty, and some just dry as arizona in summer. If Im going to spend this kind of money, I'll go to AQ next door which is a bit pricier but X better in the cuisine department. Other than my hair smelling like campfire at the end of the meal, everything was excellent at TBD.  I enjoyed every dish we ordered, especially the clams with charred fava beans, charred octopus, and pork chop with charred strawberries.  Yes they have an open fire stove/grill and they love to char the hell out of everything. In the right way. I'd absolutely go back just for the  dishes mentioned above.  Also one of the chefs apparently likes mazzy star, great taste in music chef! Just wow. This place is another reason that SOMA has turned it around in the past number of years. If you're looking for a place that feels hip and will make sure friends have a great time and a great meal, I'd definitely recommend it. A few highlights:Sherry: They are one of the restaurants in SF that is on board with the sherry trend that popped up in London at Jose a while back. Instead of wine, try pairing some glasses of palo cortado or other semi dry sherries. The bartender was incredibly knowledgeable and got pretty excited when we expressed interest. Veggies: The almost Scandinavian preparations really came out with deceptively simple dishes like the charred leeks. Sitting at the bar: You can enjoy watching the chefs in their denim aprons manage the huge fireplace while talking to the bartender about the sherry selection. Hours of entertainment. Soft serve: Yeah, seriously. They have a flavor of the day. It was honey when I was there. Amazingly good. Guten free notes: Most things on the menu are gluten free. You'll be happy. One of my new fave spots in SF! While the decor is much more beautiful at AQ, I much more prefer the slightly better prices, better quality food, & more rustic vibe at TBD. RESERVATIONS: For Friday, pm. The staff was nice about our many last min changes. It was busy, not crowded, likely no wait. We sat at a communal table upstairs, around the corner: no view of downstairs, but at least the music was quieter. THE SERVICE: Great, patient, friendly, good recs & descriptions. THE COST: $ total (incl. tax/tip) for a filling dinner: x$ , x$, x$ , x$ dessert, split  ways. Receipt: yelp. com/biz_photos/tbd …MUST HAVES: Cauliflower, Grilled Asparagus, Grilled Artichokes, Roasted Lamb, S'mores. $ section yelp. com/biz_photos/tbd …* Seeded Fry Bread (english peas, dill, cottage cheese)   starspic: yelp. com/biz_photos/tbd …Comes room temp. The flavors: amazing, esp the fresh crunchy peas, but the bread was a little hard. * Cauliflower (smoked gribiche, golden raisins)  .  starspic: yelp. com/biz_photos/tbd …Tried a bite, love the charred/roasted flavors, the golden raisins. $ section* Grilled Asparagus (cured egg yolk, nori)   starspic: yelp. com/biz_photos/tbd …Didn't get to try this. Our group was getting  bills. We ordered  of these, & apparently the big plate we got was a double order (if they told us this, no one heard it), so I didn't try it, thinking that my order was still on its way. This did look delicious. $ section yelp. com/biz_photos/tbd …* Charred Octopus (kohlrabi, black truffle & green garlic)   starspic: yelp. com/biz_photos/tbd …Also room temp. Octopus: VERY tender, sliced thin. Went well w/ the other flavors. * Grilled Artichokes (spring veggies, breadcrumbs, nettle, whey)  .  starspic: yelp. com/biz_photos/tbd …My friend didn't like this, but I tried a bit & really liked the charred flavors, soft textures of the veggies, contrasted by the crisp breadcrumbs & crunchy kale. * Leeks Cooked in the Coals (smoked oyster verde, buttermilk)   starspic: yelp. com/biz_photos/tbd …Disappointing  couldn't taste the oyster, the leeks were soggy. * Smoked Beef Kielbasa Sausage (sauerkraut, caraway)  .  starspic: yelp. com/biz_photos/tbd …GREAT texture: grainy, homemade. But EXTREMELY salty. The sauerkraut: plain & cold. * Roasted Lamb (chermoula, dandelion, sunflower seed milk)   starspic: yelp. com/biz_photos/tbd …Fantastic. Soft tender texture, strong smoky flavor. The dandelion: very crisp, paired surprisingly well. $ section yelp. com/biz_photos/tbd …* Grilled Pork Chop (fennel  ways, wild herbs, strawberries)  .  starspic: yelp. com/biz_photos/tbd …The porkchop had a lot of fat, but was beautifully flavored. Fennel was unique. I didn't love the strawberries  an odd flavor pairing, though my bf really enjoyed!$ sidesCarrots (sesame tahini, mint)   starspic: yelp. com/biz_photos/tbd …Tried a bite  loved it! $ desserts yelp. com/biz_photos/tbd …* Grilled Rhubarb (whipped cream cheese, hearth graham cracker)   starspic: yelp. com/biz_photos/tbd …The rhubarb was very unique: still had some of its natural crisp & tartness! The whipped cream was light & smooth, graham crackers very crumbly. $ desserts* S'mores (marshmallow, chocolate, chicory pudding)   starspic: yelp. com/biz_photos/tbd …Amazing! Chocolate was the BEST: cold, dense, had sea salt. Too much marshmallow to chocolate ratio; we were left w/ just marshmallow at the end  not as enjoyable by itself. If I had a favorite ski chalet, this is what it would look like. Perfect for a date night, especially when the fog rolls in. We came in last night and were greeted by the friendly staff the smoke smell from the huge, roaring grill. We were then seated upstairs, where we had a prime view of said grill and the busy kitchen staff. Advised to order   dishes to share, although  + dessert would have been plenty. Some standouts: the tequila cocktail; Josey Baker bread with butter and seaweed; chicken sausage (house made is so much better than whatever else I've been eating); grilled asparagus and egg; and those damned s'mores in a big bowl. I'm not sure why there are so many negative reviews of TBD, we had a wonderful time there last night. As many have noted, the ambiance is sublime, I'd classify it as Alpine Modern. Service was attentive and knowledgable, and the food was simply delightful we started with a couple of well balanced and impeccably served cocktails, and then moved onto dinner where I was especially impressed with the Josey Baker bread & seaweed, the beef with house "A " sauce, and the s'mores for dessert. In short, I give it high marks all around. The only negative was the carrot dish, which I found a bit bland, and not terribly remarkable. A cozy and delicious spot, perfect for a chilly San Francisco evening. //Made a reservation here after seeing the menu and pics of the insane grill thing. SEEMED great! Alot of new places are getting back to using live fire and wood and I love the whole thing. So we went here after a few cocktails at AQ next door, which were great. At first I thought that TBD didn't have cocktails, but they actually do just not a full bar. Their 'Loophole' drinks are really good and worth it. Their beer list is impressive, as well. We got some complimentary Sherry. . . Tasty, thank you. The food, however. . . . well, unfortunately, we ordered ALOT. And not one thing was good. Not one thing was cooked properly. Not one thing was seasoned properly. The sum of the ingredients equaled ZERO.  Impossible to eat toasted bread for a bruschetta type dish. Couldn't cut it with a knife! We needed a band saw! Overcooked Hangar Steak. . A temperature wasn't asked for, and it came out well done. No juiciness, no love, no flavor, no salt.  Lame Pork Chop. Fatty, chewy, DRY, flavorless, overcooked. What a shame to kill a pig for this. We ate tons more, but I erased most of the meal from my memory, because it was just an insult. I felt personally insulted that someone tasted this food and sent this food out in its' condition and thought to their self: "Yo Bro, this shit is BANGIN! We rock! Michelin Star, here we come!!" The person in charge of the food this day should go away. Go back to Golden Gate park and forage some skill and technique beyond assembling some ingredients on a cool plate. A waste of an amazing grill, a waste of the $ or so spent there, a waste of time, a waste of what COULD be a great spot. . . . The NIGHT, however, was NOT wasted because we went to KIn Khao afterwards and ate a PROPER meal with some flavor. Thanks, Pim! Bravo!AVOID. DEATHWATCH. ALL that stuff. . . . get a new chef, please. Love the ambiance, but was really disappointed with the food. I think they need to focus their creative energies a little. The ingredients were all fresh, but I found the seasoning too salty and certain flavor profiles a little overwhelming. Would eat the cauliflower and octopus again, if I had to. Would go again but only if somebody else was dying to try it! Also, it's tapas style  so be sure to dine with a date that's not picky! :) And don't go for a first date since you'll both smell like smoke when you leave (which is not my choice of aphrodisiac. . . ). Cute concept. All the utensils are in a drawer. After loving AQ, I thought this place was just as good. I was disappointed. I eat pretty salty food and alot of it was overly salty and everything I ate looked like a jungle. cauliflower smoked gribiche & golden raisins not bad, minus the raisins. I just don't like raisins, but the cauliflower wasn't bad and not too salty. josey baker bread & seaweed pretty good and very filling. The bread was just a tad bid too hard for my liking. Some corn cake thing was too dryThe ham on a stone with pink daikon was my favorite. It went really well togetherSalad with all these random things in it. I did like the dehydrated onion that went with it. Not too heavy on the dressing. This was another good dishEgg with very burnt and tiny asparagus not sure what to make of this dish. Grilled artichokes a huge jungle. Not sure what I was eating. Steak was cooked perfectly, but nothing specialOn the menu it said sea bass, but we got groper it was horrible! over cooked and very smelly fish. None of us could finish this. Smores this was pretty good and not overly sweet. First visit. Say at the lounge area by the door. Love the deco and the feel if the place. Creative and simplicity of it is wonderful. The open wood burning cooking style, one of the unique concepts I've seen and differently gives the food a depth of flavor. Menu changes so not sure if what we had would be available but the fried bread was a no. Too hard and basically no flavor. Muscles with burnt bread. . . Absolutely one of the best cooked and flavored muscle dish I ever had. I had to order a second one. Looking forward to the next visit. Painfully loud. Few things screamed delicious: Josey Baker bread topped with seaweed and house cured butter. Two massive pieces were a $ steal considering*: venturebeat. com///….  Beef kielbasa smoked on the captivating focal point of the space  the open flame grill. Served on a bed of sauerkraut, it was searing in looks and in taste.  Grilled fished atop a double play of beets and Rancho Gordo beans. Texture didn't overwhelm but the flavor certainly did.  S'mores finale uniquely prepared as a block of fudge surrounded by graham cracker sprinkles and a chicory pudding. Pioneering perfection. But a few things were just too loud: Pain of the fish price ($) offset some of the pleasure.  Carrots both as a side and the ones served with the artichokes acted as more of a sponge absorbing all the sauces and seasoning. It was overdone.  Aforementioned artichokes suffered the same excessively flavored fate along with an excessive $ cost.  Two triangle ($ per the symbolic pricing) salad was a mix of greens, bacon and egg distorted by a dressing mess. We finished just half. Then there were a few noise violations: Male foursome nearby were loud and obnoxious. Oblivious to the world except for their incessant smartphones, they did a masterful job reinforcing the tech stereotype.  Shriek from my wallet glancing at the upwards of $/glass of wine.  Tables so close together it was like an airplane only we weren't moving. Make sure you come with someone you don't mind leaning in for conversation. Four star beginning was firmly in three star territory until I thought more about some of the quietest moments of the night: No offer to change our plates between extremely distinct courses.  No inquiry as to why some food was left unfinished (aka the salad).  No thank you as we left by either the server or the lingering staff. There were some wins. But there were a few more losses. Two stars speaks loudest. *Absolutely worth it: yelp. com/biz/the mill sa… Pros: Great ambienceSome of the chairs have fur. . Great for all the ladies out thereMenu is seasonal and hence changes frequently Thats's about itCons:We had a reservation for . . But had to wait  minutes to be seated at a table. Depressingly low quantities of food/drinks and ridiculous prices considering the quantities. Come on, even fine dining restaurants can do better. Drinks were tasty but each drink was probably around a quarter of a glass. We ended up ordering loads of drinks by the end. We looked up yelp before deciding to visit this restaurant. It seemed as if there were ample options for people with dietary restrictions (vegetarian, seafood only, chicken only etc).  At the time of our dinner, there was hardly any veg/chicken/seafood options. Menu was stuffed with beef and pork and some of us ended up hardly eating anything. We tried cauliflower (starter), baked beans (starter), smoked beef kielbasa sausage, smoked mussels, charred octopus, the whole hog ($), some beef item, s'mores (desert), semolina cake (desert), strawberry lime (soft serve ice cream of the day). Out of all these dishes, Mussels and s'mores were tasty, though ridiculously less quantities. Rest of the dishes were ok or intolerable. SF is a city of food lovers. We love trying new restaurants, pay a slightly premium price and will be happy to visit again and again (with more people) if a restaurant is good. But I will definitely not visit them again! a great tasting menu. totally reasonable, a huge amount of food spanning all of the highlights of the menu, with great service and beverage pairings throughout. it may seem like the nosebleeds, but the counter upstairs has a great view of the open kitchen and are the best seats in the house. you might smell like a campfire for a day or two from the open wood grill, but it's worth it. highlights: the cauliflower with smoked gribiche, cocoa lamb loin, the s'mores dessert, the the oloroso sherry i had after. one note: i loved the soundtrack of s alt rock hits (pixies, weezer, i think smashing pumpkins?) but it could deemed too loud for some. This has huge potential, but missed on execution. I wasn't blown away. Some dishes good. Maybe one was great. Concept is brilliant. Hopefully, they dial it in a bit and I'll go back. Very impressed!  We sat at the bar watching the big grill. The "old man and the sea" was a delicious cocktail.  The steak with the "A" was great.  The trout was cooked to perfection.  I will definitely be back. I don't go out to dinner much. When I do, I go with my adult children and tend to pick restaurants that they would like as much as I would. I picked TBD because it sounded like we could share a bunch of dishes, still get full and enjoy each other's company. To me, going out to dinner is much more about conversation and companionship. Food is important. . . but the atmosphere of the place has to be right. I made a reservation for pm and we were seated way upstairs at the far end of the communal table. At first, I was little annoyed because I like to people watch in restaurants. And there is no people watching up here. But I'm glad we were up there. The downstairs is super hot and noisy. No conversation possible at all. The music playing overhead was an interesting Pandora station and I must say that trying to guess which 's band was playing was hilarious. Good drinking game! Food: okay here's where my  stars comes from because the service was excellent despite other reviewers. They seem to have gotten this down well. The food was pretty good. I read other yelp reviews pretty carefully and got the idea of which were the must haves. . and I agree. The bread/seaweed dish is fantastic. Sure, it's salty. . . but I like salty! The arepa was very good. We ordered a second round of both of these. The kale salad had too much anchovy. . but it was still okay. We had pork chops, steaks and kielbasa and baked beans to kind of finish things off. All very good. Cooked perfectly.  The heritage carrots were a waste of time. The turnips that came with the steak were  star. . . where the hell do you get baby turnips? My only gripe for everything is nothing was hot. I dunno. . . I like stuff hot. People complain when I cook that everything comes to the table scalding! But that's just me. We had some great wine. Three bottles. . . that's how we do it in the !! It was the syrah. . . definitely a good choice and not too expensive. But if you're watching pennies, don't go here. It was $. For desert we got a small piece of the semolina cake [it was my birthday] and the soft serve ice cream. Awesome. I avoided the s'mores because they are served cold. . . WTF? Who has cold s'mores? The decor is interesting and I felt very comfortable here. The chairs are large and comfortable upstairs with sheep skin throws over them! Tables are large with plenty of room to spread out and see your food. I don't understand why people think this is an iffy neighborhood. It's perfectly fine. Born and raised in SF and I can tell you, this area has improved %. Parking was a breeze. One of the worst experiences in SF dining scene. Last night, group of almost  people having drinks at the bar while waiting to be seated. I ask for a specific glass of wine, the bartender poured me half glass saying "we don't have more of this wine but it's ok I  will charge you half the price". I replied jokingly that "since you cannot give me a full glass it would be nice from your part not to charge at all". The bartender said: " You're right, I'll take care of that". After minutes and while we were still at the bar, the host of the restaurant comes to me and in a very loud way tells me: " Sir, I hear that you don't want to pay for you wine". I explained to him what happened and he is trying to pull the glass from my hand saying : " I'll get you another wine but full glass". I replied that "there is no need, I'm fine with the half glass of the wine that I have". Next thing the host did was to go to some of the people in my group and "informed" them that I didn't want to pay for my wine!!   Such a disappointment. . . Never again. I had a wonderful meal  today. A wide variety. The portions could've been bigger but very inventive menu and great service Nice decor, nice staff, but the food was hit or miss. . . Came for a friends birthday dinner so the menu was set and served family style. The good:  Cauliflower: nicely roasted with a tasty sauce Pickled beets: I love beets and thought these were perfectly tart Sausage: good flavor and nicely cooked  S'more: fun take on s'more flavorsThe ok:  Bread and seaweed: bread was a little burnt and thought the seaweed was an interesting choice of accompaniment, not good, but not bad Beef: good flavor but a bit chewy Carrots: I don't like carrots but heard they were ok Grits: good flavor but very mild  Soft serve: pineapple flavored, was just ok, skipped it for the other dessert (s'more) The bad:  Octopus: Way too toughWhile the portions were good, we hoped that more dishes would fall into the "good" category. With so many great choices in SF, I probably wont make my way back here. . . Two stars for the ambiance, decor and creative menu. . . Was let down by all six courses my man and I shared. . . The trout wasn't bad, but all the other dishes were either bland, too salty or just mediocre. Will be trying AQ next. . . Loved the ambiance of TBD!  Some of the items were really good and some of the veggies or accompanying parts of the dish were really salty.  Your silverware is placed in a drawer in front of you (loved the concept). Food: Seaweed Bread (large pieces of bread slathered in butter and seaweed).  This was really salty and really heavy. Cauliflower: really delicious and perfectly charredBeef:  loved the beef and turnips, the greens were overly salted. Might come back here again but would hope to try less saltier dishes.  star cuisine,  star service. It shall be a classic business school case study: how shitty customer service can ruin great product. Sad. . . We made a reservation for a big party, for  p. m. Two of our party were late. We asked to be seated. The manager refused  according to their rules the whole party must be present. The restaurant was virtually empty, but he kept us waiting, hungry, for  min  they have the strict rules. They do important work; we, customers, create inconvenience for them. Felt like the Soviet Union : (Well, they lost our business We were sorely disappointed with our experience at TBD. The service was great, and the wine recommendation was outstanding, but that's pretty much where the positive notes end. We shared several starters and appetizers, and they were unremarkable at best. The most memorable part of the meal was (unfortunately) the Florentine steak, which took an hour to prepare. We were warned about the preparation time on the steak, and that was fine with us. However, when it came out WELL DONE (they didn't even ask us how we wanted it  we assumed it would be between rare and medium rare as a good steak should be), we were appalled. The rarest parts were medium, and parts of the steak were brown through and through. For an excellent Florentine steak, go to Cotogna instead. This was very disappointing, particularly in light of how excellent AQ is. Very well decorated interior that gives a warm vibe to the environment (perhaps it's best of the big fire burning at the back of the kitchen). The food is very thoughtful, flavorful, and different. Each dish we had were all full of surprises. I'd recommend ordering the beef or trout just to settle down the stomach though, as each dish are small in volume (but when you are packing very intense flavor into your dishes you do not want them to be big, so I understand why). I really liked the carrot while my girlfriend enjoyed the arepa. This is definitely a restaurant where everyone can find at least a dish that he or she can relate to. Food was surprisingly good. Been skeptical of places that try to be too inventive.  Loved the pork in tea leaves and this hen dish.  The ambience is a bit much for me. . . trying too hard to be hip and quirky, kinda like the entire Valencia street. No full bar which is a big negative My boyfriend heard about TBD in one of his GQ magazines and wanted to try it out since we live not too far. It's located in SoMa and if you don't know you're looking for it, it can be easily missed. The ambiance is very laid back with minimal decor, but it works for them. What I love is their open kitchen and how they cook with an open fire. If you enjoy a subtle, smokey taste this place is a must. If you don't, definitely give this place a go. Their menu changes seasonally and also depending on what is available, the items we grubbed on may not be on their menu all year longWhat we had: Beer (i think the name was "golden" something. . . yummy and fruity) Andouille sausage (a must get if on menu) duck blood sausage (never had it but happy my first time was here  amazing) Squid (very tasty with grapefruit)    Beans (I'm not a huge fan of beans, but the thick pieces of baconhad be enjoying every bite)Service was great everyone was knowledgable and attentice! I happened into this place because it was dinner night with Annie. We chose it on a lark, based on ratings of the parent restaurant, AQ. Super impressed! The food was fundamentally delicious, and super cute too. It's all small plates, and  of them for  people was a good dinner. Definitely full, not stuffed. The winner of the evening was the black trumpet mushrooms with farmer's cheese (in broth  eat the broth), but the seaweed bread is even more important to get for dipping. Service was attentive. Our server recommended a super good wine to go with our last course (we chose our own for prior courses), and that leaves. . . nothing to complain about. Decor was cute, too. The "drawer" silverware was adorbs and the southwest motif worked. (This IS a newer San Francisco restaurant so obviously it's not going to be quiet, you need a reservation even on a Monday night, and it costs money. ) Disappointing.  Liked the sound of most of the dishes, and since the  of us shared I got to taste most of the menu. Nothing was great. Nothing was horrible  although the octopus portion was so small it was hard to say. Good waitress and interesting decor.  I'd go back if it was nearby but wouldn't go out of my way. While there are a few meat based dishes here, most of the dishes are still vegetable heavy, and the experimentation here doesn't quite appeal to my tastes.  Also, while the open campfire feel of the kitchen was a nice touch, the smell of smoked wood drenched my clothes for the rest of the night.
