Too much like Bar Tartine  if you're a fan of that place, you will probably like this as well.  Not my cup of tea though. Excellent new restaurant in San Francisco. The way they prepare the food, over the open flame,  gives it such a great flavor.  It's not just the meat and sausage that come out great, also the vegetarian food was great. Best carrots I ever had. Also great andouille sausage. Great atmosphere and very nicely decorated as well. Highly recommended.

name: ICHI Sushi + NI Bar
review_text: I came here to get omakase with my roommate and my friend. We're talking about a swanky restaurant that has the feel of a bar and a sushi diner all rolled up into one, but one thing I will say is that you can't have both. As much as I liked the ambience at this restaurant, it lost some of the old school Japanese feel to it. You know what I mean? The one that makes you feel like you can wield a samurai sword and slice all the freaking fish in the restaurant on your own! ALL ABOUT THAT ACTION BOSS. But lets get down to the nitty gritty stuff. Let's talk food. This place was pretty damn good when it came to the omakase. We ate until we were stuffed and you know what?! No "REGRATS". Not even one letter. The place was awesome and the fish was fresh. Most definitely had my fill and I loved every single bit of it. I would definitely recommend getting there early though and putting your name down. You can easily put your name down and sit at the bar in the back to wait. That was pretty awesome. You can also just walk around outside if that is your cup of tea. Good thing there are a lot of random restaurants and stuff to look at outside! But anyways if you ever get a chance, definitely check this place out. The sushi at ICHI was definitely some of the freshest I've had in SF and I loved how they had a good variety of some more uncommon fish, like the delicious Baby Yellowtail and flavorful Katsuo Skipjack Tuna.   The Arctic Char, Amberjack, and Uni were phenomenal. The spicy scallop roll was excellent. My favorites of the night were the Hamachi Belly nigiri and the Amberjack sashimi. The Wagyu Beef sushi was just okay  they shouldn't have cooked it so much and kept it rare, since Wagyu really shines in the raw form.   We also got a Amberjack Collar which was just okay. The pork belly was good, but it was missing a texture contrast  perhaps the (delicious) chicharrones should have been more crispy to offset the fattiness of the succulent pork fat.   Also, I've got to give it some points for using real wasabi. I love going into sushi joints that use real wasabi and not the green dyed horseradish paste that % of sushi places use to save money. Good job, ICHI.   The sushi chef we had (not sure what his name was, but it definitely wasn't Tim) was kind of a douche. I mean, he wasn't very friendly  just very matter of fact and a bit pretentious. When I asked for some wasabi, he gave me this snobby response of: "All the wasabi you need is already in the sushi. It's made the way it should taste. " WTF, who do you think you are? Jiro?! Nobody's making documentaries about you. If I'm asking for more wasabi, it's because I like more wasabi in my sushi. And of course, after eating my piece of sushi, it turns out that there really wasn't enough wasabi in there. Asshole.   Anyway, as lame as the sushi chef was, I really was pleased with the quality of the sushi fish here. If you come for the omakase and really enjoy the nigiri/sashimi, ICHI is definitely up there with the best in SF. Omakase # on the  x  Things to Eat Before You Die list. I've had the omakase at ICHI on my "to eat" list for a while, so decided to come here for dinner with a friend. I made reservations a few weeks in advance for a :pm dinner on a Friday night however, there were still a couple of tables available along with seats at the sushi bar for walk in customers when we arrived. We were seated away, and I convinced her to do the omakase with me. Our server was really helpful, and thoroughly explained the different options we had with the omakase we could opt for sushi/nigiri only, or a combination of dishes + sushi/nigiri. We could also let them know if we had any allergies, or foods that we didn't like, and also if we wanted to eat something in particular. I loved the flexibility of their omakase, and we opted to go with a combination of dishes + sushi/nigiri, and let the chef choose for us. Our omakase consisted of: Cucumber Salad ($, yelp. com/biz_photos/ichi…): Delicious I loved the miso dressing they used for this salad, and the cucumbers were super fresh, crisp, and crunchy. I could eat a few bowls of this. Maguro Avocado Salad ($. , yelp. com/biz_photos/ichi…): Just ok. . the tuna was fresh, and I enjoyed this dish, but it wasn't so amazing that I'd want to order it again, especially for the price. Skip. Hirame ($) / Suzuki ($) / Tai ($. ) / Katsuo ($) [yelp. com/biz_photos/ichi…: I normally wouldn't order any of these as nigiri, and I didn't really love any of them, but they were all good since they were so fresh. Inada ($) / Shima Aji ($) / Wild Sake ($. ) / Shiro Toro ($) / Sanma ($) [yelp. com/biz_photos/ichi…: The toro and wild sake were definitely my favorites, but all the nigiri were really good since all of the fish were fresh.  Ocean Trout Dashi ($. , yelp. com/biz_photos/ichi…): Yum! I wasn't excited to hear that this was part of the omakase, but I was happily surprised. The ocean trout was cooked well, and the dashi had a good umami flavor recommended! Pork Belly ($. , yelp. com/biz_photos/ichi…): Good, but not amazing. Some pieces of pork belly had the perfect crisp to tenderness ratio, but one piece was overcooked and dry. Skip. Uni ($. / piece, yelp. com/biz_photos/ichi…): Good, but not amazing. I would only order this again if I had a craving for uni. Overall, we had a great dinner at ICHI, and if I came back, I would love to build my own omakase now that I know I can order just  piece of nigiri. One of the only negatives was the really small table my friend and I are short Asian girls, and we felt a bit cramped. Also, the seats weren't the comfortable, and my legs started feeling numb towards the end of the meal. The other negative is the lack of parking in this area there is very limited street parking, and very little parking that is really close to the restaurant, so you're almost guaranteed a short walk. The neighborhood isn't the best depending on which direction you walk, so be careful. Had an awesome omakase experience for our anniversary dinner!  delicious dishes, paired with a sake and sparkling wine (never mind the hangover next day), expertly delivered by Darren and his colleagues. Favorite item? The uni was sublime, but the seared snapper belly may just have taken the top spot in this lineup. Table of , Friday night reservation. There was room at the bar but we opted for a table. Didn't really have a great first impression because the layout of the restaurant is actually a maze. if you're sitting towards the front of the restaurant, you can only get out one way, and the tables are too close together to walk through. Figuring out how to get the bathroom also required a double take. There are a ton of options of the menu. Many people recommend the omakase on Yelp, but we were told it would be in the $+ range. Instead, we opted to try a few of their more izakaya style dishes. Miso Asari Clams: A salty mixed miso soup with clams. It was very oily but delicious. Then, some nigiri. We got the Maguro Zuke, Saba, and Shiro Toro. I didn't like the large amount of wasabi they put on these, since they used fake wasabi. The maguro zuke had very little flavor, and literally tasted like nothing. The other two were a bit more flavourful, but definitely not worth the $.   per piece price. We were pretty disappointed by the quality of the fish. We then got momo yakitori, which is chicken thigh. The meat was very tender and juicy, making us want to order another skewer. We chose the buta katu niku kushiyaki, which was pork shoulder. Also amazingly juicy and delicious. A single skewer was only $.  each, making it the best value to price ratio on the whole menu. I'm surprised no one is talking about these skewer dishes at all. We also tried the kampachi kama, which is amberjack fish collar, the best part of a fish. Very delicious and more filling than most items on the menu. This was $ and great for sharing. We were not full by the end of this meal, but had already spent ~$ each so decided to call it. The service was friendly overall, the interior is very modern and clean, although the layout really bothered me. The non sushi options on the menu are AMAZING, definitely recommend trying them over the overpriced sushi. I really wanted to like this place, based on what I've long heard about it. On the good side, the staff are very friendly. The sushi is also generally the star here, with the emphasis on the core ingredients and less on dressing it up (or disguising inferior fish). And there is a good emphasis on the daily specials  since when it comes to fish, it's always about what's freshly caught. They have many Japanese varieties you don't always see in SF sushi joints. And what you don't see are many of the unsustainably fished staples at most sushi restaurants, such as unagi, etc. You can also go full on omakase here, and the sushi chefs will take care of you with a variety of things to try out. This can get pricey, however, as I would call this place a little more expensive than the norm for SF sushi (especially given their smaller nigiri sizes). They have some nice sake options (cold, of course) on the menu as well. What wasn't so great about ICHI is that the sushi didn't shine here  for being the star attraction. The service is a bit discoordinated, as it's easy to order dishes that come completely out of the order you requested. There are also often long or short gaps between plates, as it is not well metered out. Then comes the weirder stuff. I didn't mind the gentle lecture on the proper way to prepare and eat nigiri, even if being told what you already know is a little like being a scolded child. So I get that any wasabi or soy added to the nigiri is at the sushi chef's discretion of taste (unlike the rolls). But if you're going to give me that lecture, you had better deliver wonderfully flavorful sushi where I wouldn't be tempted to change a thing. That did not happen, and the sushi fell a little short. Between that and a conversation with one of the wait staff about their cold sake ("we could make one hot for you"), I got the strange sense that ICHI is lost somewhere between sushi newbies and sushi patrons who know what to expect. And that's OK  there's nothing wrong with teaching or learning a few things. But there is a fine line between honoring a cultural tradition and parodying a cultural stereotype. Here ICHI seems to follow a number of paint by number superficial details of what makes a Japanese sushi bar while missing out on creating its soul. You get the "irasshaimase" greeting, but all the sushi chefs look like skateboarders from Orange County. As if they got together at a Vans sponsored skate park and decided, "Wouldn't it be cool if we acted Japanese and started a sushi place?"The rest of the wait staff is whiter than a Walnut Creek Cheescake Factory, thus it begs a question: how would you feel about a soul food restaurant run entirely by ethnic Chinese where they spoke in ebonics and lectured you on how to properly prepare and eat collard greens with grits?Asking for something a little more authentic of your sushi, whether it's steeped in Japanese tradition or something decidedly Western, shouldn't be a stretch. But hedging by trying to accomplish both is a recipe for failure. It might fly in Norman, OK, but not when you're just a couple miles from SF's Japantown. With so many better Western or traditional Japanese options in SF for sushi, I won't be back. Fan f*ckin tastic.  I'm unbelievably lazy, so you better believe it takes quite a bit to get me out to Bernal Heights.  The fish was to die, and prices were surprisingly reasonable.  Service was top notch.  Zero complaints.  Actually, one  they had no dessert.  But it wasn't a big deal bc Mitchell's is literally around the corner. Yes. Ichi sushi! This is my favorite sushi place in San Francisco. it just dazzles. It's fresh and flavorful and simple  no gimmicks or heavy sauces needed. Other dishes, such as the cucumber salad, deserve the same descriptors  fresh, flavorful and simple. Worth the drive (assuming you don't live in the neighborhood). Also, you can walk to Mitchell's afterwards for ice cream (and who doesn't want ice cream after a sushi dinner?) REVIEW IS FOR HAPPY HOUR ONLYM F : :Oh muh lord, the happy hour here is really good, and it definitely makes me want to come for dinner one day. Yeah, it's in Bernal Heights which is not hustling and bustling but at least it's easy to find parking, and hey, you can get Mitchell's for ice cream afterwards :)$ oysters YAS. And it doesn't get crowded here like most places in the city because it IS far from everything and it's not close to BART. . The oysters were really good. It came already dressed with ponzu  so you don't use the typical cocktail sauce. SO GOOD  simply: fresh & sweet. I believe the beers were $  or so? Phat pint! I forgot what brand of type of beer were offered but it was decent stuff (I think I got a Stella?! @_@!). We also had the Yuzu chicken wings which is usually $.  but I believe it was $ or  for HH. SO GOOD. Dry fried chicken wings with SO much flavor and light/crispy batter. PERFECTION. Perfect with the ber. The interior is modern, clean, and simple. It looks like their mission is going back to the tradition and basics of basically showcasing the fish / ingredients and not doing anything super crazy or adding a bunch of sauce. MY PHILOSOPHY WHEN IT COMES TO SUSHI AS WELL. Seeing all the good reviews for the omakase and having the nice service means I'm definitely coming back soon! This place! So much going for it! I would highly recommend doing the chefs choice, it was pricey but one of the best meals I have had in recent memory. I would definitely recommend it if you want to have a really nice dinner. Last night, I experienced omakase at Ichi for the first time, and I was completely swept off my feet. The freshness and flavor that is packed into every piece is a marvel simple flavors come together with incredibly fresh fish to form a complex. Even the pieces that aren't for the faint of heart, such as anago and uni, are so enjoyable that anyone can love them. My two favorite pieces were the inagi and shiro toro. The inagi was so fresh and wonderfully seasoned. Shiro toro completely melts in your mouth, and is exploding with flavor. Omakase at Ichi is truly an otherworldly, ethereal experience with food. Go, spend, eat, fall in love. Experiencing food like this is what life is made for. This place was so underwhelming it's insane. The second you step through the front door it smells like old fish, not a good sign. The waitresses are snobby and terrible, food was beyond forgettable, not sure what people see in this place. So good! The service can be a bit slow though. And getting into the restaurant is a nightmare. But the food is good. All the fish is fresh and delicious. Can't get enough of it. Forget the haters. This is easily some of the best sushi and service you will have in the Bay Area. The food was exquisite, the sake was unforgettable, and the service blew me away. Come here, and come here often. Oh my goodness! Where to start!?Come here if you are interested in nigiri sushi. It is not your place to go if you're jones in' for a spider roll. This is also not your place to go if you want to douse your sushi in soy sauce & wasabi it actually spells that out literally as writing on the wall. Fresh fish & fantastic season fish daily & a lovely large sake menu to boot! My husband & I sat at the bar & ordered ordered omakase & had about a dozen pieces each. Everything was good but over half were excellent! Darren was our sushi chef & he was fun & fantastic!! He is incredibly knowledgable & has been doing sushi for just under  decades! He got me to like octopus for the st time in my life!! :)With a great combination of friendly & knowledgable staff, cute trendy atmosphere, & incredibly great ingredients, how can you go wrong?Can't wait to go back again & hopefully we'll get Darren! Delicious! So good! Been hearing about this place for two years and it totally lives up to its rep. So fresh and savory  definitely get the omakase. But please beware of the bartender on weekends. I waited  minutes to order a glass of wine and then he was churlish, cranky and cruel. I can't believe such a lovely establishment wouldn't train that man in basic hospitality. Perhaps I am missing something? In my opinion this is overrated, overpriced, hipster sushi.  Top ten sushi in the city? Sorry but I beg to differ. my friend and i got omakase sushi here last week, and it was tasty.  we sat at the bar, and we had the chef make us whatever he wanted.  the sushi here does not require dipping, as all pieces are already flavored.  we ended up eating most of the specials and then requested a couple other more typical items.  all were good, and the price wasn't too bad. Probably the best sushi I have had in the Bay so far, though I haven't been to that many, in full disclosure (I'm from NY). Ordered omakase at the sushi bar and loved every piece. Very bold flavors. Not super traditional but delicious! Had a great time with the sushi chef also, who was very friendly and entertaining. Reasonable prices. Omakase for two ended up costing us around $! Will definitely come back again. What a fantastic place for omakase, and reasonably priced, too! Tadashi san was our sushi chef, and he was an absolute delight. This place is very good. I would say that this is my nd favorite sushi place in the US, right behind my beloved Yasuda in NYC. The fish here is amazing and the variety is great. Also the waitress was extremely knowledgeable about the fish and the tastes, I had asked her for a few recommendations and picked amazing fish. I didn't try the rolls I am more of a nigiri type of guy so I ate that. I was also really surprised with the price extremely reasonable, I had a party of  and we ordered a ton and we repeated many fish and had an $ bottle of sake. The bill came in just north of $ with tip. This to me was not bad at all. When I go to yasuda in NYC I spend that much for a party of  and with no sake. I will definitely update this when I go back,  hopefully in   months. I live on the east coast so I don't get out there too much but would recommend this place and for a first date is good too as long as the person you take really values good fish. I've had Omakase three times now and each has been an incredible experience. The nigiri is perfect and the small plates are great. Get a reservation a few weeks in advance, sit at the sushi bar, and let them amaze you! I LOVE Ichi. The folks who run the place are some of the sweetest I know, and the chefs are incredibly talented. My boyfriend and I made a reservation, and were super excited to see the new space. When we showed up, the group ahead of us was just wrapping up so the hostess suggested we have a drink at the bar while we wait. No biggie. The server at the bar was helpful in recommending a sake and we had the Ichi beer, which was full of flavor but refreshing, as well. Then, we went a little crazy ordering from the bar menu: clams, eggplant, chicken wings, cold somen. Everything sounded delicious. I had to remind my bf that we still had omakase to make room for. He was undeterred. He said we could do it. Our table at the sushi bar opened up more quickly than we anticipated and before our dishes arrived at the bar in the back. But, the hostess said that they'd get delivered to us at the sushi bar and helped us with our drinks. The seating at the sushi bar is a little squishy but not uncomfortably so. Perhaps the people next to us were just taking over more than their allotted space. Either way, it was cozy, in a good way, for the two of us. Our sushi chef, Daniel, introduced himself. We told him we wanted omakase, that we eat any and everything, and that we had ordered a bunch of dishes from the bar already. He said no problem; he'll take good care of us. Then, the influx of food came  one dish at a time so not overwhelming. The clams with pork was amazing. I wanted a bigger bowl of that. I would eat that all day. The grilled eggplant was super flavorful. The chicken wings were tender and juicy. For the sushi, I can't remember all of what we had because we had so much but the standouts were the scallop (incredibly sweet and buttery), the shrimp two ways (raw body on rice and fried head on the side  the fried head was delicious; I wish more places served fried shrimp head), and the uni (amazing how something can taste so much like the sea). I was stuffed. I couldn't even eat the last complimentary piece that Daniel put in front of us. Everything we had was delicious, exquisitely prepared, and all the nigiri had the right balance of warm rice and cool, perfectly seasoned seafood. I would put a bite in my mouth and just let it sit there for a second before chewing and savoring the flavors and textures. My boyfriend, who I was a little concerned about since he likes dunking his sushi in soy sauce with lots of wasabi, was beyond okay in trusting Daniel. He didn't ask for soy sauce or wasabi, and enjoyed each bite. That's a huge win. And, as for the price, it was totally reasonable for how much we ate and drank. So, for the quality and creativity of the food and the attentive but not overbearing service, Ichi is on the top of my list of sushi places in SF. It all started in the wrong way. We sat at the bar ( awful position for a bar ). The bartender was not looking comfortable at all. After we asked her a suggestion for a sake, she gave it to us but never came back to ask if we liked it (unacceptable from a professional)The hostess "almost" pretended to be friendly and caring. Once we sat at the table, we had to wait  minutes to receive the menu ( mind that it was not in the rush of service ). The food from the kitchen was good. Didn't blow my mind but properly prepared. The sushi was absolutely disappointing. Definitely overpriced ( even the not so exotic items )The rice seemed cooked in rush. Or at least I hope for them, otherwise . . . . It does happened that if you get super busy, you need to cook rice in the middle of service. Good luck !Bottom line, seating at the table was disappointing. Wait staff not prepared. Busers very polite. From far, it seems that the sushi men are proper: people seemed entertained. I will not go back. This place is definitely good for their Nigiri sushi. They are confident that it's prepared and seasoned just right so there is no soy sauce on the table for you to kill the flavor with.  Cold and Hot plates were good too but don't  bother with the rolls. + Toro Nigiri (Fatty Tuna) *+ Butterfish *+ Hotate Nigiri (Scallop) *+ Squid Salad  *+ Miso Clam Soup *+ Nice Modern Clean Decor with Fun Wall Mural+ Service was great but we also went early on in the night Rolls ** Seating Space (Reservations Recommended) maybe too much green tea salt on the omakase set. but still very tasty and fresh! Their sushi is incredibly fresh. The nigiri is mind blowing although the seaweed wraps can be a little chewy. Their rolls are really good too, though same problem with the seaweed. The sake list is amazing, though, and so tasty! The waitstaff if attentive and courteous, however the food is overpriced and mediocre.  In an area with many quality dining options you can do better than Ichi Sushi.  Take your hard earned elsewhere. Ichi has never failed us  the fish is always fresh, service impeccable, flavors perfectly balanced, and I would trust the omakase selections any day.  I've had sushi all over the Bay Area, and this place is always one of our very tops.  It's just hard to get in sometimes because they are so darn good!  And let's not forget the proprietors, Tim and Erin Archuleta.  They are amazing.  Love, love, love. The fish wasn't fresh. On a Thursday night, our maguro and ocean trout sashimi had that old, fishy taste to them. In fact, we maybe should have guessed from the fishy smell when we walked into the place. It wasn't all bad  the beef tataki was excellent, and the hotate and wakame salad were fine  but bad fish at a sushi restaurant is the cardinal sin. Sorry to say I won't be back. Showed up right as they opened and were granted seats at the bar. +Sake shiso maki: small rolls with salmon and shiso. Simple. Shiso, typically known as the wasabi receptacle (you know, that leaf), is insanely delicious in a sake roll; the leaf makes it almost refreshing. +Inari nigiri: deep fried (kinda sweet) tofu stuffed with rice. Tasty as a dessert. +Umi masu sashimi: three slices of ocean trout goodness. Incredibly delicious and sustainable. Gluttony sans the guilt, can't get any better than that. +Spicy yellowtail specialty roll: simple, but with a spicy green sauce drizzled on top. Pretty good. +Miso soup: basic. Did I detect a hint of booze in there? Weird. Cute joint ensconced in a not so cute neighborhood. Great service and fair prices (for the quality of sushi). Definitely give it a try if you're into basic, but delicious, sushi. Born and raised native with a foodie palate. . . I gotta be honest. This place is a pure rep of gentrification right here. Food is clean, no doubt. But way over priced and nothing crazy mind blowing original. I spent almost$ for two of us. Full of white folks, with no neighborhood rep whatsoever. And that says something. I had to check to white girls from getting in line at opening bc they thought they could  cut  bc "they had reservations". . . that kinda place.  We ordered the house ichibier  ($), maguro and hamchi  nigiri, chicken wings ($. ) beef tataki (. ) pork belly (. ). . . cali roll (. ). . . mostsu nikomi (tripe and short rib) ( . ). . . tataki we order one Skewer of pork shoulder (. ) and one Skewer of flank stea (. ). . . seriously everything was good. But really NOT GREAT. To. much cash for the what it is. I would come to just try nigiri and short ribs dish. The service was dope but food took forever to come out. Im bummed. Thats a lot of cash to spend on a dinner. Good lord, I think I found heaven. I'm a sushi snob, so when my friend suggested this place, I was a bit wary. At the end of it I was % wrong and I'm glad I did. When we first got there, it was a wait so we put down our number for a text. An hour later, we got the text and headed over there. We sat by the sushi bar and our server was really helpful in assisting us in what we wanted. We were able to select a set menu and ate to our hearts content. I'm  a big albacore sushi fan and I can still taste it in my mouth. When I say it's like an orgasm in your mouth, I am not lying. It was better than sex. It was better than Nutella. Heck, it was better than sex AND Nutella. SO. DAMN. GOOD. The baby barracuda was banging as well. I think by the end of it I may or may have not proposed to my waiter, that's how good it was. It's a bit pricey, but it is worth it if you love good sushi! Showed up and put our names on the wait list, because they don't take reservations. Waited  hours, and at the end of the  hours they told us the restaurant was closing and they wouldn't be able to serve us. Wow.  I mean. . . . Wow. Yay! Was able to walk in without reservations on Fri at pm. Although we were told to get out by :pm sheesh. . . The food is super fresh tasting. We were so hungry, we wolfed everything down. We had the crab roll, the spicy halibut roll, got some Japanese eggplant which is to die for! There weren't anything extra creative that makes them different from other sushi places. I mentioned to my friends that that sushi in Hawaii, they get so creative and different with the rolls. You know, like a signature roll that they created/invented. Order bit by bit cuz there were the  of us and couldn't fit all the food. Small table, ya know?No desserts, bo. . . not even mochiService is excellent! Food arrived promptly. Finally got reservations here!  We haven't visited since they moved and expanded to Ichi Ni.  We had super fond memories at their original location, in fact I went around telling friends + others it's the best sushi in SF.  Well. . . Ichi Ni isn't quite how we remembered our experience but I would like to say the sushi is fresh and different from what you'd get at your average Japanese / sushi restaurant.  We were fortunate to sit at the sushi bar and had to order the omakase.  We had  pieces  baby yellowtail, amaebi + mackerel from Japan  probably the best fresh mackerel I've ever had, Hokkaido uni, and it goes on were the most unique.  Something about the rice didn't seem on par  I couldn't put my finger on it.  I wish there was more seasoning on some of our pieces like how I remembered at Ichi.  We tried  hot dishes  sea bass collar which was pretty basic but the sushi chef recommended it.  I probably wouldn't order this again.  The nd was the chicken meatballs that you dip in a egg yolk with green onions and this was on point.  Super moist and really tasty  I recommend trying.  If we ever do make it back I hope to see in Tim's corner.  I think this would make the experience more enjoyable. m best amaebi I've ever had.  They fry the head and then put it on top of a corn soup that blew my mind.  Sushi was pretty good  If i can remember correctly, I had the squid, tuna, albacore, scallop, salmon, uni, and they were all o so very good i had to order the second piece for every single one.  Dollar oysters and the yellow tail kama was also great for happy hour.  hmm debated giving them  stars for allowing the half order of nigri ( peice) but if i come back and still love this place then ill bump it up to a . I ate at ICHI last night, and it was wonderful.  We sat at the bar, and enjoyed omakase from Eric.  Everything he served was delicious, truly as good as could be.  The waitstaff was very friendly and nice, and kept me plenty full of ICHIbier (which you must try  it is lovely).  I will be going back to ICHI soon, and will likely become a regular there. For full disclosure, I'm a sushi snob.  I'm used to eating some of the best fish available, and as such, have insanely high expectations.  It is rare that I find a place that hits my five star sushi rating.  ICHI is just such a place.  Do read some of my one star sushi reviews if you're looking for some color on what a bad sushi experience feels like to me. We had omakase here and, it exceeded all my expectations. My friend said he was there with the owner as their omakase chef, and noted it was better. I can't possibly imagine how much better it could've been. There were some pieces of nigiri with fish that I had never heard of. . . They were so delicious! I can't wait to go back. I hear their happy hour is pretty rad. . . Service by staff was okie  .  stars service by sushi chef  was fabulous  stars atmosphere  very nice and modern food quality  very fresh and well prepped food presentation  good Overall  had a good time! will come back and recommend! Just got home from a meal of mediocre sushi and crazy over priced sake ($ for house hot sake  yeah, that's house hot sake we're talking about). Atmosphere was lacking. The service was friendly but a bit slow. There are many other options around the city that give a way better performance for the amount of money spent. All in all, a disappointing experience. Their happy hour is pretty boss. The collar is one of my favorite parts of a fish and you can get a variety of them for $ before pm. Like  different ones. Really no reason not to get them all (we had four). The $ oysters are also quite good and other izakaya stuff like great nasu dengaku, decent wings, and shishito peppers. They also have this pesto somen that's in credible and worth each person getting their own. It's super clean tasting and fits all that rich fish well. We came here for drinks and snacks on a Friday and ended up appropriately sitting at the bar in the Ni bar side of things. The atmosphere of the place was less than stellar  a little cold, IMO. The food was good but value ratio a little off. Drinks were okay  selection is on the smaller side. Service was friendly but slow. Would like to come back for dinner to get a better sense of the place, but am not really in any hurry. First, I found the set up of this place absurd. It was divided up into the sushi section and the hot dish section. I had to pick where I wanted to sit and couldn't order food from the other section. Because it's Friday evening and the sushi side was full, we settled in the 'hot dish' section. What was strange about the hot dish section was there was sashimi (raw seafood without the rice underneath) on its menu. So it wasn't hot dish only. The whole point of divvying up the restaurant into raw and hot sections was moot? (Not to mention I have never been to a 'Japanese' restaurant that has this kind of set up) To add to confusion, I tried to order the one and only (sake) cocktail on the menu and the waitress had trouble knowing if it's available and took her more than  minutes to check both sides to find out. If you had only  cocktail on the menu, you better frigging know if you are serving it or not. As for the food, the quality to be fair wasn't bad but just of tiny portion. Real Japanese portion. So the sticker price may not seem much, it adds up when you have to get full. In the end I paid $ for food and a couple of drinks and was still kind of hungry. I always lament the fact that there aren't many good Japanese (or Asian) restaurants in the city (given its reputation as a foodie haven) and this is another shining example of this inadequacy. Stay away unless you have no better options. WOW! I don't know why people write such bad reviews here, but I had a lovely first time experience. Party of  and we got the the restaurant around pm on a Tuesday night! We didn't have any reservations but decided to try if we can get a table. Lucky for us we got seated right away in a little corner booth! Since we were going to do the omakase. . I guess sitting at the bar is better! We asked the waitress if we can sit at the bar instead and just our luck,  bar seats opened up! Our chef was amazing! super friendly and very informative of what he was serving us! We never had to wait long for our sushi it just kept coming to us in a timely manner! our waitress was very attentive and always walked by to see if we needed anything extra!Everything we had was wonderful! every bite was a burst of different flavors that all went amazingly well with each other! I've never experienced eating sushi like this and I love it!Bonus, chef's are fun to look at and Mitchell's is right around the corner for dessert! :) My two friends and I had a great meal at ICHI Sushi. Even on a Wednesday night, we couldn't get a reservation until :, but we had a drink at the bar and ended up being able to get seated earlier. We were at sushi bar the whole night, so pretty much all of our interaction was with the sushi chefs. They were great  personable, funny, and they were good at choosing and explaining the sushi. We ended up deciding to let the chef choose  pieces of nigiri for each of us to try. The fish was really fresh and delicious, and we all got to try things that we may not have ordered ourselves. One of my friends is a little pickier and he catered to what she said that her dislikes and likes are. We ordered a couple of rolls and the pork shoulder as well, which were all good, but the nigiri was definitely a stand out for me. When the bill came, we were all pleasantly surprised that the price matched up with the quality of food and experience. Especially since we let the chef choose and he did give us things that are usually more expensive like toro and uni. It's so nice to find a sushi place that is actually good and not outrageous!The reason why this place is getting five stars is because once I left, I knew I wanted to come back. I wouldn't say this was the best meal I've had in my life, but it was great, and the sushi chefs, atmosphere and price make ICHI sushi a keeper. I realized how rare it is to leave a restaurant knowing you want to return (even when the food is fabulous). ICHI must be doing something right (: This place is kind of the hip place right now and I have no idea why. The staff is stuck up, it's WAY overpriced, and it wasn't an overall pleasant experience. Sure the atmosphere is hip and cool, the food is good, not great, and there are way better sushi places in the city that treat you way nicer and you get a better value for equally if not more so unique and adventurous sushi. Decided to try this spot for dinner. We arrived about  minutes before opening and were first in line. By the time it opened there were about  other people in line behind us.  Pork Belly Appetizer: tasted more fatty than other pork belly I've tried.  The albacore and salmon were the best and most fresh tasting fish out of everything we ordered. Definitely recommend the albacore. We also tried a few rolls and other nigiri  they were good, but nothing memorable. Food was nicely presented and the service was fine. The decor is modern with seating for about  (including the bar). We sat at the table closest to the window  the seats have no backrest and there is no place for your coat or purse. There is no signage on the building so you'll have to look for the black/dark grey unit. My wife and I had been to the old Ichi before, but in our first time at Ichi's new space, we had a similarly great experience, only with less wait, since it's much bigger now. We went in on a Friday night around , and they quoted us  minutes to wait, and almost exactly  minutes later, I got a text from the hostess saying that a seat at the bar was ready. Even though we didn't wait there for the  minutes, I appreciated that we could've hung out at the bar in the back while waiting for the table. I agree with all of the other positive reviews saying that you should go with the omakase, although what I appreciated most if that the sushi chef asked us to order some things we liked, and then he could add some sushi that would complement what we ordered. It wasn't that we just had to pay a ton of money without any control  instead we were able to tell them what we liked and didn't like and ordering a bunch of other interesting things at the same time. Everything the chef prepared for us were delicious and fresh, and the only things we didn't like were the things we ordered. Unfortunately, two of those things that were not great were the two beef dishes we ordered. The beef tataki was a bit on the tough side, perhaps just a bit overcooked. Also, the wagyu nigiri had a great taste to it, but was also a bit on the tough side. It didn't melt in your mouth like other similar dishes I've had at other high end sushi places. All the fish was great, but the beef necessitates a one star "penalty. " However, that won't stop be from getting great sushi at Ichi in the future. Man, I really don't write bad reviews of places anymore and this review is late but I recently read something about Ichi and was reminded by the great bursts of red clouding my vision about why I will never eat there or recommend it to anyone I know ever. Basically, Ichi was responsible for my  super bummer of a birthday a couple of years ago (). I'd heard so many great things about the place that I definitely wanted to celebrate with delicious sushi on my birthday.  When we got there, the hostess quoted a wait time of  minutes which was cool, so we went next door to drink margaritas. An hour and twenty minutes later, she still hadn't called so I went back over to check and she told us that they wouldn't be able to seat us before the they closed so we were, pretty much, shit out of luck. In sum, the hostess couldn't even be bothered to call and tell us we wouldn't get a seat and had us sitting around for almost an hour and a half waiting to not get seated. Even if it hadn't been my birthday, it was a pretty dick move, so I celebrated at Emmy's where the hostess was far more competent and accommodating even if it wasn't exactly the celebratory meal I had been hoping for. I mean, I guess they've probably replaced their hostess by now but that experience is something that really ruins restaurants for people forever. Reading reviews here it is hard to know what about many restaurants that attract the diverse and contentious crowd of people who might later post their thoughts on Yelp. Nonetheless, wading through the absolutist partisans and enemies of a place like this one is left with a certain amount of anxiety, even fear; can ANY place live up to the expectations  positive or negative  expressed on a forum like this? I doubt it. In any case, we dived in, sitting at the bar and going for a joy ride. Our chef (in the station next to the boss man), was amiable, solicitous, and seemingly competent. He asked us if we had any things we wouldn't want to miss or anything we particularly didn't want, and then proceeded to produce a fairly steady stream of nigiri from the fish under the glass in front of us. Without referencing any other sushi venue in the city, or indeed without mentioning any sushi place I have ever been anywhere, and even without worrying about anything that the restaurant's owners might or might not have said about the food, their concept, or anything else, but just letting the seafood and rice speak for itself, we can pronounce ourselves fairly satisfied with the experience, and left  with a good taste in our mouths, happy to have taken the time to visit the place. On the plus side, the fish, scallops, and shrimp we had were served in pretty interesting ways, tasted fresh, and while not truly plentiful in portion, were not stingy, either; the drinks service was conscientious and, as mentioned, the sushi chef was attentive and eager to please. There was lots of good tasting sushi. On the down side, much of the sushi, despite being fish of different species, for instance, all tasted the same. It is really hard to understand this given that I have never experienced this anywhere else. I have to wonder if it is not somehow a function of the drive to make of the experience eating here some kind of ritual of sushi "purity", whatever that might be. Our chef offered in passing when setting down our first nigiri that it was "seasoned the way it was supposed to be" or something similar; of course, since we had heard that Ichi does not brook the use of extra wasabi and soy sauce, this aside was absorbed without comment, and even with some pleasurable anticipation. But the fact is that all the effort then to make the sushi "special" really just boiled down to applying a fairly narrow range of seasonings (including various ponzu concoctions, a number of spicy or salty condiments, etc.  and none of them bad, mind you) to whatever fish was on hand, without, it seemed, any particular thoughtfulness about why that particular combination might be especially apt. Our conclusion was that in a perhaps misguided attempt to pursue something like "perfection" the concept of honest ingredients of the highest possible quality was somehow distorted by a penchant for novelty for its own sake. Our chef was, as far as we could tell, following a playbook as rigid as that which controls every action of a burger flipper at Mickey D's; instead of a spontaneous interaction between the chef, the materials, and us, we got a fussy, preset packaging of the fish of the day which ultimately produced something akin to mass production, even though, I will happily add, it was all pretty darn good. We thought that perhaps by combining this level of passion and skill with something less self conscious and more open hearted, this place really might have a chance of becoming the "best" sushi place in the City, whatever that means instead of a + star novelty with potential. . . This seems to be my first review on yelp. It was so bad that forced me to post something here. We found this place on a  restaurant list(obviously). I suppose they spent some money on the marketing. the food was so so.  the waitress were okay. But the waiting part was horrible. And it's so expensive. . How dare they charge so much with such bad service? We were waiting there for about more than two hours just to got a few pieces of sushi. . . . If you are hungry you would be starved there. This is the worst part of my pride weekend! I highly recommend you not to go. . . Why does everyone hate on here?  Is it because it's in Bernal Heights? Is it because it's hipster and not exactly what you'd find in Tokyo?  Please people, relax!I went through a sushi craving to the point where I started perusing high end sushi experiences, and saw that ICHI has been getting a lot of press (for starters, x features them on the  things to eat list).  We made a reservation for a Friday night at :pm and when we showed up, this place was PACKED! Sitting at the sushi bar was an absolute must for me, but unfortunately that meant we had to wait  minutes to be seated.  I'm not sure why or how that makes sense, and if it weren't for the fact that the sushi was amazeballs, I'd probably have more complaints about the fact that I didn't receive a single piece of food until pm, or  minutes after my reservation. Ok, moving on. So, if you're going to remember anything from this, it's that you MUST order the omakase.  Not to be a snob, but for the people who sat next to me who ordered the two orders of the California Roll, why did you waste your time coming here? We went about  pieces deep, and threw in the chicken wings and fried fish collar from the hot food item list.  It was definitely an aggressive night, but hey, my LA Kings won the Stanley Cup that night and I was going to celebrate. Highlights from the omakase included the hirame with chili and green onion, the saba with the egg yolk vinagrette and fried leeks, the barracuda, and the super sweet hotategai (giant scallop).  The tamago ended the evening, and while it wasn't warm, it was definitely quality.  The excellent quality of the fish here is what really blew both of us away.  The rice wasn't overly salty, and our sushi chef graciously put the shoyu or additional sauce on for us, so we never needed anything else. Dinner came out reasonably priced, including the hot food and some beers.  Something "strange" that we noticed was that we were charged per piece, not as a general "omakase" pricing.  Either way, ICHI sushi was definitely a great experience and while their sushi isn't what you'd find in the traditional sense, their quality of fish is absolutely on point. Good quality fish spoiled with copious amounts of yuzu sauce. Just serve the fish with some soy and wasabi. Our server was nice and suggested what to get. The girl working the "ni bar" was in a terrible mood and wasn't pleased to help. Music is too loud and you need to yell over it. Price is ok, but there are other higher end places that cost about the same but give a much better experience. Had a very good meal here, ordered Omakase, which is apparently the way to go.  I would concur since many of the sushi we received, I would have never known to order. Off the hot menu, the chicken wings, were dry and none of us got what the big deal was. They need some sort of sauce to compliment and the beef, was just ok.  Next time I think I'll try the pork belly and the clams, my friends weren't into either.  We went on a Tuesday at :pm because that was the only time we could get a reservation.  I was baffled during our whole dinner why Open Table said they were so booked and when we called the restaurant directly to see if we could get a pm reservation they couldn't accommodate us, but during the entire length of our dinner, at least  hours, there were open tables all around us.  I think the hype of it being the best sushi restaurant in the city maybe just that, hype. However, the food was good and the service excellent with a nice looking space and vibe.  I will go back.  Especially since it's down the street from where I live. I'd give this joint  stars if I could. Here's why:) The music is BOMB. Go eat tea sandwiches with your mom somewhere else if it's too loud. ) Erik. Effin. Marinovich. He did the mural. Yeah, that mural. ) Freshest fish in town!) Best sushi chefs you can find (yeah, that means you Erik!)) The staff is accommodating and there to help you. Hats off to Shasta for holding it together!) In every piece of sushi/sashimi you can taste the freshness of the fish  regardless of what they add to the fish, be it yuzu, soy, scallions, ginger, etc. You taste the FISH in all of it's amazing glory. ) Best fish collars. For days. ) The chef/owner Tim comes out and greets us. He's awesome. Maybe even super awesome. ) They got Almanac to brew them a signature beer. A bay area beer brewing darling makes ICHI a special beer! Aw yeah. ) They make all the other sushi joints seem overpriced for what those other joints offer. There you have it.  points for the ten stars they deserve. If you think they're too expensive or too fancy or too loud or too pretentious or too anything other than awesome then go somewhere else. Amazing nigiri and a great experience if you sit at the bar. Our sushi chef Darren was so interesting and talented. Some of the best nigiri we've ever had! If you like typic Japanese place with an American twist, this the perfect spot. With a good sake collection. My nd favorite sushi place in SF. I was scared to come here because I heard the hype, but the reviews weren't too good and that confused me. the bad reviews are a lie!Some things: always expect a wait. for two people at dinner it was like  min which wasn't bad. they text you when the table is ready.  such fresh fish it's unbelievable. . . order the shrimp nigiri and you get a fried shrimp head!Some bad things but not enough to let me remove a star: why is miso soup $. ? the decor is good, but then also slightly reminiscent of a chipotle? The food was good  good enough for my friends and I to enjoy while we catch up. Yuzu fried chicken wings were my favorite (in addition to pickled cucumber)! The sake was very smooth  I definitely wanted to try some more. The only thing that annoyed the entire dinner was that you cannot order food from Ichi Sushi if you are seating at the Ni Bar (even though they are not really separated). It could have been very nice if the host told me that there are separate menus before I cancelled the reserved table. This was one of the most disappointing meals I've had in San Francisco and I eat out a lot.   "chef' ONE STAR    Service    Price      Music   Conflicted about ICHI: Some really great fish Many of them are masked by all the toppings and citrus Favorites: Kuushi oysters, kohada, saba, tataki, umimasu, uni Friendly and knowledgeable servers Casual and fun vibeReasonable for omakase: veggie app,  oysters and  pcs of sushi EACH, plus a ml bottle of daiginjo.  $ without tip.  Would give it another go purely for the variety of fish and the quality. The quality of most Fish here was very good. (I didn't try tuna as usual because most places in the US have awful tuna. Toro is OK mostly but "Akami" in the US just sucks. I stopped eating Tuna after moving here from Japan. ) Why  stars if the quality of fish is very good? I didn't agree with "chef's choice of garnish/sauce" on a lot of nigiri pieces. It is sometimes simply better with a touch of wasabi and soy sauce on nigiri than Yuzu, etc. I appreciate this restaurant is showing that sushi or sashimi is not supposed to be over dipped in excessive wasabi and soy sauce but I also want to enjoy my nigiri as the best way possible. They seem to use a lot of Yuzu on nigiri but some fish really just call for a touch of wasabi and soy sauce instead of Yuzu. Would I be back? Maybe. If I figure out how to ask for a little wasabi and soy sauce without offending the chef. I'm Japanese and I never use too much wasabi or soy sauce but just a touch of it on some nigiri so that it taste even better. . . Other cooked items were just OK too. I have yet to find a better sushi place in San Francisco. I have been here a few times now  mainly for the omakase and the excellent sake selections  and have never been disappointed. In fact, whenever I am entertaining an out of town client I suggest ICHI and they always rave about the experience as well. Went here last night and our group must have tried   pieces of nigri each, as well as shared a couple of the hot dishes. Everything was delicious and flavorful. I see some reviews complaining about the prices at ICHI, which I will readily admit are on the higher end. But you have to realize you are not going to get a  star meal for a  star price in a place like San Francisco. I suggest ICHI for special occasions and going with true sushi lovers. Dropped in Ichi on Saturday night for omakase at the Ichi sushi bar. We had a resy for : and arrived on time, but had to wait about  minutes for  spaces to open up at the sushi bar. With open seats at the Ni bar in the back this didn't bother us one bit as we sat drinking a pint of Hitachino until a spot opened up at the Ichi bar. The atmosphere is more trendy than traditional, but the sushi although modernized with their spin isn't just hype. This is not your traditional Japanese sushi place, so traditionalists would probably not like it, but if you want a modernized spin on sushi then Ichi fits the bill. I also respect that they don't give you soy sauce and a bunch of wasabi at the sushi bar so you can make some horrendous concoction of wasabi soy sauce to overpower your sushi. People who are complaining about how the sushi chefs want you to eat the sushi the way they have prepared it make me laugh. You want to dress up your crunchy roll go to another spot. We started with a cucumber salad and ordered a bottle of Hakkaisan Junmai Ginjo Sake. Every piece of nigiri hit the spot and the combination of flavors and creativity are on point. Our sushi chef Eric walked us through about  different pieces of nigiri and one piece of cod collar. I would say the only piece that missed the mark was the tako (octopus), it was a little tough which can be common in octopus if you don't work it before you prepare it. Since dinner resys are hard to come by, I never understand the people that come to a sushi place and order california rolls and chicken teriyaki. The people wearing their scarves inside sitting next to us kept glaring at all the assorted cuts of fish the sushi chef was handing to us feeling jelly that they went with the california roll. I think the sushi is just ok but very expensive. You can have very fresh fish like Tekka on balboa for that price. Its really over price here. The quality of the fish here is top notch. It's up there with the best sushi spots in SF. Sadly, the new space is a total departure from what made the old ICHI great and I will spent my money at Saru or Maruya with my friends and visitors instead. The new place feels more like a Chipotle than high end sushi joint. It has a modern feel with tall ceilings and slate gray walls. One of the walls even has some cheesy sushi related words painted on it. There is also loud music playing. Combine the decor with the music and the loudness from everyone talking over the music and it feels like Chipotle opened a night club that served excellent sushi. It was nice hanging out at the NI bar before dinner, but with the amount of space that they have, it seems like just adding more tables would have been a better idea. They don't seem to be going for an intimate feeling with the way the floor plan is already, so I'm not sure why they decided to add the bar. ICHI, I will try to remember you like you used to be and block out my trip to your new space from my memory forever. Some reviewers mentioned pretentiousness, I see it as entertainment. It is a little difficult to take young(er) people following "traditional rules" seriously. If there was a  year old chef at the counter threatening to boot me out for asking for soy sauce, I can go with the flow and shut up. When someone much younger does it, hell yes, I'm going to ask for soy sauce just to see what will ensue. This is not a giant piece of fish on a giant slab of rice place; the flavors are delicate and layered, the rice is compact and well shaped, the flavors can be unexpected, just enough to wake my senses in the middle of auto feeding to say, "hey, slow down, something special's going on here. " Back to the soy sauce, there aren't any on the tables, there also wasn't a lump of wasabi with every plate things I've gotten used to seeing in sushi restaurants. When asked, we were told each piece was appropriately sauced/wasabi'd as the chef intended fair enough and I agree. But, upon further pressing to different table attendants, we were given the tiniest pencil eraser size ball of wasabi and a bottle of soy sauce that was soon taken away from us by another server while we were distracted. Asides from the excellent pork belly, flavorful barracuda nigiri, and scrumptious skewers, acquiring and losing that soy sauce bottle was pretty good entertainment for the eve. In retrospect, maybe the beer influenced our amusement. We arrived at : on Monday once the shop opened, it was fairly full by , but had plenty of walk in seats in the rear for small groups. The crowd and the styling of the place leans to the young, but the food quality will satiate all fine sushi fans. It can get a little loud when full, very attentive staff. No desserts on the menu, but Mitchell's Ice Cream is around the corner. A solid place, a good place to eat on your own so you can focus on the flavor. The restroom has hand lotion, nice touch. I've finally had a chance to sit at the new sushi bar a few times and the food and service is just as good as ever. The best way to experience Ichi is to sit at the bar and order omakase (the chef will choose your meal for you). Also, the yuzu chicken wings are a must try. I must say, when I found out that my former favorite sushi spot in the city had closed, I was pretty bummed. Then, I ate here. Honestly, if you like sushi, just sit down and ask for omakase. You will not be disappointed. Everything is super fresh and expertly prepared, and each dish is a journey. Make reservations!! Food was great but we waited over an hour at the side tables to order sushi since we couldn't actually order it at the place we were sitting ( I can't rationalize it ) . . So dear owner . . When people want to order more food and spend money. . why say no?!? Frustrating and disappointing. . Really had a lovely meal here.  Extremely well made nigiri.  Uni sashimi screams fresh.   Love the vibe of the restaurant.  Modern contemporary setting yet authentic sushi.  Please order the steamed clams the broth was amazing with some sort of spicy chorizo diced up to give the kick to it.  Did the chef choice menu Omakazse which you can tell the chef to stop feeding you food when you start to feel full   makes the experience fun.  Cost for food before drinks and tax/tips was around $ $.  Great value for the quality you get. Overall, .  stars. Ichi is the best!  The sushi is fresh and delicious and the oysters are near perfect.  They've ruined me for all other sushi.  Damn their deliciousness!  The new space is much bigger than the old one and the place is always buzzing.  They also brew their own beer called Ichibier which is also quite good.  It's perfect with their fried chicken wings. If there's a place to do omakase, it is here. It was so hard to get a reservation during a normal dinner hour! Book early. We came and sat at the sushi bar and had the omakase. Try out one of their barley Sochus, they're like a smoother, lighter whiskey. I'm no sushi expert, but I'll tell you what we had, much of it came with green tea salt which was heavenly.  Kakushigura: Barley sochu Nanban Zuke: Fried fish in vinegar with onion Cucumber Salad: Raw cucumber with sesame & peanut dressing Kampachi Kama: Yellowtail Maguro: Bluefin tuna Kisu Tai Inada Aji Shima Aji Hotategai Umi Masu Shiro ToroThe sushi chefs were very nice & talkative and wanted to explain and share with us what we were eating. For the above + a beer and two glasses of wine we paid $ total. Not bad. First and foremost: I am a vegetarian who will occasionally (i. e. twice a year) eat fish. So, I am not a sushi connoisseur. That's what my boyfriend is for. So, after being featured on best of lists, I thought it would be a great treat for him and I to experience a new sushi spot. The reviews would lead you to believe that this is the Holy Grail of sushi in San Francisco, and while this is better than Barracuda (sorry, neighborhood sushi spot!) it also wasn't as mind blowing as expected. We arrived a bit early (how did MUNI get us to our destination early, I'll never know), so we sat in the back of the restaurant, the NI Bar, as it were. I was half expecting this place to be overrun with people, given how highly publicized this place has been, but it was actually comfortable for a Friday night. The decor was very simple and, in actuality, left a bit to desire. I felt like it was very "Ikea". Perhaps I am used to my sushi joints being a bit more 'divey', but this felt like it was trying to be elevated, but didn't quite hit the mark. Our reservation time came and went  we weren't seated until  minutes after our : reservation. The host seemed a bit frazzled  she couldn't remember names (not really a problem) but we didn't get much of an apology for the extra wait. Again, not much of a big deal, but reservations usually mean avoiding some wait. We were seated at the bar itself, which was not a problem for , but could be for larger groups. The dining area feels a bit tight  I wouldn't recommend this place for large groups (which can be great, as there weren't any birthday parties doing sake bombs. . )We placed our orders directly with the chef, who was friendly and knowledgeable. The man next to us seemed to be going through an extensive run on the menu, receiving piece after piece, causing a reaction that led my boyfriend to describing it as an "O face. " Needless to say, I didn't have the same experience, but this is where my aforementioned lack of sushi eating experience may make me biased. However, everything I did have was delicious, and despite pondering aloud what we would eat later in the evening, we left pretty full. Highlights included the Spicy Albacore and Vegetable Futomaki. I did not partake in it, but my boyfriend loved the Tuna Tataki. We also opted to start with the Shishito Peppers as an appetizer, which were roasted with great flavor. So, in the end, it was a pleasant experience, despite an underwhelming decor and delayed service. I don't think it will be high on the list of places to return to, but perhaps this is the place for you if you are true sushi connoisseurs. Sometimes  stars is not enough. While the sushi is undoubtedly next level the humble chicken wings  is the eye opening (as in  this can be done with chicken?) dish at this place  these wings literally smell like waffles  which results in a total senesthetic mindblow. . I've spent over  hrs at Ichi, and every dish was an unexpected surprise. Its literally difficult to imagine a restaurant continually improving on the previous dish for over  items but this is the place that pulls it off. There's possibly only one other place that can do this in SF that i've experienced (its american dim sum. . . ). Srsly next level sushi yo (also helps if you go with Aaron V). Im very frustrated. I had heard about Ichi from some of my friends who really enjoy sushi. I took their advice and went with my family. I did not make reservations, which I should have done. I'm planning to go there next month. The reason I am writing my review now is because the woman who helped me was very rude. She made me not want to visit the restaurant again. I hope not all the staff at Ichi is like this! I do hope the food is better than the costumer service! I'm looking forward to eating there soon. Oh man, guys. This place is an experience!  I could go on and on, but suffice it to say that this is  hands down  the best sushi place in the city.  Freshest fish, dishes that allow the diner to really experience the taste of the fish, not dress it up with gross mayo sauces or hose it down with soy sauce.  Be prepared to let the food melt in your mouth. The cocktails and sake are great.  The customer service is friendly, accommodating, and everything I want and need a San Francisco mom and pop to be.  And the prices are absolutely reasonable and a great value for the flavors and fun ambience.  I highly suggest gettin' crazy with the Omakase style and let the chef choose your dishes for you.  During my second visit, we gave the server a per person budget and threw out some favorite fish and flavors of ours. The dinner that followed was extraordinary and, of course, exactly what we were willing to spend.  Plus we learned a lot about dishes that we didn't know before and were served new items that we wouldn't have ordered on our own but are now new favorites.  See what I mean?  A total experience. ICHI Sushi + NI Bar is amazing. My family and I had a wonderful dinner here, sampling a bunch of dishes from their new izakaya menu. From the seared pork belly to the somen with shiso, everything was delicious. Equally as impressive is the atmosphere. From the second you walk in, ICHI is incredibly warm and welcoming, and the staff is super friendly and helpful. You should definitely try ICHI if you're in SF. Hell, you should go to SF just to try it! I was really excited to try ichi after hearing it as a recommendation from some other people as a good sushi place in the city. I understand that this is a new location and the menu has expanded and changed.  We came in on a Wednesday night for my sisters birthday.  The location is a bit meh, a bit far from us and parking was not difficult but not super easy.  There is this weird dead end street that did not have signs and our only option was to back up.  The space is nice!  Love the paint color and cartoonish wall and decor and furniture.  The service was also top notch.  The staff is super friendly and helpful. We had the cocktail which was a surprise.  it was called a cats meow. salted plum, shiso and other stuff. salty, not sweet at all. Onto the food.  I was not impressed to say the least and dont feel like I would want to come back here.  Good sushi for me is really hard to find.  I want quality  fresh fish.  I also want a semi authentic experience. I say semi because who i am i kidding here? Its california, not japan.  I also want value   i dont want small ass pieces of fish on small ass pieces of rice.  I want simplicity  fish on rice.  nothing fancy.  no bells and whistles. I think maybe part of it is expectation not meeting reality.  When this place was recommended, i thought it was an authentic japanese spot for sushi. That is not what i got.   japanese people dont come here.  we started with oysters.  they were fresh.  there was a sauce on them. dont get me wrong, the sauce was good. but sometimes i just want to taste the oyster.  there was no option as the sauce was already on there.  We selected a few things from the regular sushi menu and these were good as well  ikura, tobiko.  Then we went to the specials menu and thats when i started noticed that almost everything we chose came pre sauced.  we also tried the somen with shiso pasta and also seared pork belly.  it was not seared.  it was deep fried.  why would you call it seared if it is deep fried?  confusing . . . . damage was $ per personI appreciate what they are trying to do here.  Put a new spin on sushi.  Its just not for me. Hipster vibe. Manageable sake list. A sushi bar that does omakase. Sushi chefs that look more like a lineup for startup guys. But I rather the waitress not mention that one can get omakase at the table. It turned out that the service is slow and waiting  minutes between each  seconds of devouring  pieces of delicious sushi is not that enjoyable. And P:E ratio is kind of high. We have to go binge on Mitchell's ice cream afterward to fill up. Couldn't have been more pleased!  Everything was outstanding.  The food was amazing!  Chef Tim has brought the art of food preparation to a whole new level  and that's saying a lot when it comes to San Francisco Sushi restaurants.  The staff were friendly and attended to every need.   This place is simply awesome! Party of  on a busy Saturday night  service was exceptional. Tried about  different dishes. Favorites were the Yakotori Chicken, Fried Chicken, Noodles, Kobe Beef and Nigiri. If you wanted to go out to dinner and find a fun spot with a great crowd and good drinks then let me tell you. . . look somewhere else. This was one of the most disappointing meals I've had in San Francisco and I eat out a lot. Completely uncreative sushi that all tastes the same, mediocre nigiri and they're too pretentious to offer dessert. There are so many outstanding sushi places in the city, don't even think about coming here. Feels like a poor man's Roka Akor Nothing special.  Questionable hygiene (food placed in direct contact with bamboo mat in fish case instead of on dish). Enjoyed cold somen. I'm fairly new to sushi and sake and usually order the basic California Roll at sushi places  to play it safe. But. . . . I went to ICHI ready to try new things.  We sat at the sushi bar  best place to sit in my opinion! The waitress came over to take our drink orders and offered sake from their list.  I told her that I wasn't a big fan of sake and she brought me a taste of something that non sake drinkers like.  The sake I've had from sushi places usually ends up tasting like nail polish remover but the sake she brought me was tasty! The chef started us with a cucumber salad which was very crisp, fresh, and tasty!The chef was very nice and knowledgeable and made us the sushi piece by piece and didn't rush us.  The mural they have fits perfectly in the mission district and it serves as an educational piece about sushi and sushi etiquette.  The colors, decor, style and design were so chic and contemporary.  I went to ICHI to get an education about sushi and Japanese food and I got one! Thank you for that ICHI! The barracuda was my favorite!! Ok, seriously I don't know what I just ate. Ocean trout, pork belly, noodles. I'll never understand what nigiri, sashimi and all that is. But, shit, this is good!Amazing food!!The wifey ordered everything, she's the sushi pro. . . . even baby niko got his own avocado. Highly recommend you try this place! Wow. That is all I have to say. Wow. Words cannot explain how good ICHI was but I will do my best to describe the deliciousness y, goodness y heaven I infested tonight. Let me start off by saying I love sushi. And not the spider roll, fried sushi kinda sushi. I'm talking salmon roe with quail egg and monkfish liver kind of sushi. I had read about ICHI in x and how it was voted best sushi in the  Eat + Drink Awards and I knew I had to try it. I can say with certainty it was the best sushi I've had in San Francisco. I even overheard (ok, let's be real, I was totally eavesdropping) a chef saying that the fish was flown in that today fresh from Japan and will have another delivery on Friday. Talk about fresh! Right when you walk in the door, you're greeted and hit in the face with fresh fish smell. We had  different things that we ordered, but I'll talk about the highlights. The first thing we tried was on the daily special sheet, the Samekawa Karei (aka Japanese Sharkskin Flounder). Wow. I think this was the best tasting piece of sushi I've ever had. They quickly cooked the skin with a blow torch and placed it on top of the fish. Wow. You could taste every little flavor that was on that piece and it was amazing. The Kampachi Kama (salted Albacore collar) was mouth watering ly good. I'm sitting here drooling just thinking about how good it was. Came out hot (which is huge in my book) and so absolutely tasty. It's so hard to describe, but just trust me when I say to try it. The Ikura (Salmon Roe) was also the best I've ever had. I make it a point to try it at every sushi place I go to and ICHI had by far the best. We had Daniel as our sushi chef and he was wonderful. I will be for sure requesting to sit in his area every time I go here. Not only did he know what he was talking about but was able to make great sushi (which was a given I'm sure but he seemed better than everyone else!). Two times I asked him to surprise us and he did not disappoint. First we had a roll with eel and cucumber which was still warm from the freshly cooked eels. NOMS! Then he made us uni with cucumber and salmon roe and a fish crisp to start. Everything worked together so perfectly I wanted another one but resisted. Overall, I recommend this place to true sushi lovers. I can't wait to go back and try all new things because I know that it will not disappoint. Thank you Daniel for the wonderful experience and looking forward to your new treats!

name: Leatherneck Steakhouse
review_text: This is a very classy steakhouse in the nob hill area. I was looking for a steakhouse in the area and was pleasantly surprised to find this one which also came with a great view of the city!It's on the th floor of the Marine's Club building and the customer base seems to be older, white folks so don't expect a very hip vibe but do expect an old school, classic steakhouse vibe. This means chairs come with clever, unnoticeable wheels so you can easily slide in and out of the table. This made my life a lot easier when I was stuffed at the end of the meal and I could leave my table with ease!The food:Rib eye ( oz)  Perfectly charred on the outside and cooked medium rare, just the way i like it. I'd say not as good as other steakhouses i've been to but its definitely up there. Tater Tots  Get these! Not like other tater tots in that its not ground potatoes but I think they are mashed potato tots. So they are super light and crispy on the outside. Ask for extra steak sauce so you can dip these in it. Prime rib  Very good, obviously not as good as a place like house of prime rib but It was pretty damn good, very flavorful. It didn't come with any au jus but you can ask for the horseradish sauce which complements it well. TIPS  ) Ask for sauces. I recommend the steak sauce and the horseradish sauce. They will gladly give you more than one if you ask. ) When making the reservation, ask for a table next to the window. We made our reservation the night of so we had to take what we can get. Overall, i'd come back for sure! This is a great place to go on a romantic date. I think the food is reasonably priced and you can't beat the views. Amazing restaurant. I don't really understand some of the negative reviews. I took my wife here for her birthday. I made reservations  week before and they were ae to accommodate. I was  min early and was seated at the window after I politely asked for that seat. Let's start with the view. . wow! Amazing views of my city. My waitress was quick to ask us for our drink selections and provided phenomenal service through our dinner. The food was delicious (calamari, salad with blue cheese, tater tots, cream spinach and prime rib and rib eye). It was all cooked to perfection. They even sang happy bday to my wife and brought her dessert. I really enjoyed the piano playing as well. Where do I begin. Went to the bar to order our drinks while we waited, bartender was extremely friendly. Older couple next to us seemed to be regulars as they conversed w/ staff on first name basis'. Great to hear. When our table was ready, our host did something I've never seen. He took my girlfriend's drink off of the bar top and walked it to our table. Then, as I was about to grab her chair for her (no really, I had planned on doing this!) he quickly grabbed it and opened it as she sat. Then immediately opened and placed her napkin on her lap. Now, keep in mind, we don't visit top notch restaurants often, but having experienced this before we even looked at the menu. EXCELLENT. Then we looked up. . . . . . . WOW. What a view. Great view of the San Francisco High Rises, as night lit up. Exactly what we were looking for. With such an awesome view and impeccable service thus far, we couldn't wait to order. She ordered the filet mignon medium, came out very juicy and perfect! I ordered the ribeye. Awesome! same as the filet just a bigger cut obviously, juicy and perfect. We had a great time here and will definitely be back. Be aware there is a dress code listed on their website. Visited November  Party of   everyone thoroughly enjoyed their food, our service was great, and the view (as many reviewers share) is breathtaking. Dinner rolls were accompanied by roasted garlic  so good. Filet mignon was wonderful, cooked perfectly, everyone cleaned their plates. Ice cream sundae is huge & basic & delicious  we shared two of those and a berry crisp for dessert. Ambiance is hard to beat  loved the live piano music, the view (as mentioned), the lighting, and the Christmas decorations. Our  hour dinner flew by. We will be back! I decided to make a reservation here for my boyfriend and I's anniversary mainly because of the view. We thought the view was absolutely gorgeous but it didn't make up what was lacking in the food and service that we received. For appetizer, we ordered the calamari and there wasn't anything special about it that made us go, "Wow!". It was very basic. I mean, it was good, don't get me wrong, there just wasn't anything special about it to make it memorable. For our entrees, I ordered the prime rib and my boyfriend ordered a steak but I forgot which. The prime rib was on the fatty side. I love prime rib and its fattiness but this prime rib was just too fatty. I'd say % fat. So I couldn't eat a good chunk of my entree. On the other hand, my boyfriend enjoyed his steak and have no complaints. We also had the truffle tator tots and my boyfriend enjoyed those little tots! Lastly, we had bread pudding for dessert and I honestly don't remember if I liked it or not. That's how unmemorable some of their food items are. As for service, I felt as though our server didn't even want to serve us. He gave off a certain vibe that kind of made me feel uncomfortable. Also, I was kind of expecting Leatherneck to greet my boyfriend and I when we checked in with 'Happy Anniversary' or something because I made the reservations months in advance and I stressed that it was our  year anniversary so I wanted it to be extremely special. The whole time it was as if we were there like any other night and they didn't really make us feel like we were celebrating. I mean, my boyfriend and I knew but I guess I shouldn't automatically assume the restaurant would put cute little details here and there to indicate that we were celebrating. I feel as if the least they could do was to write 'Happy Anniversary' on our dessert plate. Maybe I was just expecting too much from a restaurant who appears to be romantic because of the view that comes along with it. All in all, I wouldn't come back to Leatherneck to celebrate anything. My spouse and I are members of the Marines' Memorial Association and we visited Leatherneck Steakhouse every morning and evening while we were staying at the hotel.
